– FAQ’s
What is the Employee Retention Tax Credit (ERTC) and how is it different from the
Payroll Protection Program (PPP)?
The
Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act
(also known as the
CARES
Act
) was
signed into law on March 27, 2020. It included two programs to assist businesses with
keeping workers employed: the
Payroll Protection Program (PPP)
administered by
the
Small
Business Adminstration
and
Employee Retention Tax Credit (ERTC)
administered by the
Internal Revenue Service.
PPP funds are distributed based on 2.5 months of payroll and a minimum of 80% of the
funds must be used on payroll to be eligible for forgiveness. Additionally, PPP funds
are not taxable as revenue and you may still take deductions for the payroll covered by
PPP.
ERTC tax credits, however, are credits (or refunds) for a percentage of payroll in each
quarter that you qualify. There are specific rules for determining eligibility by
quarter, and limiting the dollars that can be claimed for each employee.
ERC eligibility requirements
Employer eligibility is largely determined by one of two key factors, at least one of
which must apply in the calendar quarter the employer wishes to utilize the credit: Full
or partial closure due to a government order. A business is eligible for the ERC if they
were forced to fully or partially suspend operations (FPSO) or reduce business because
of a government COVID-19 order. Credit applies only for the part of the quarter the
business is suspended, not the entire quarter. There are certain businesses that
generally do not meet this description and would not qualify:
Those considered essential, unless they have supply of critical material or goods
disrupted in a manner that affects their ability to continue to operate. Businesses
shuttered but continuing their operations largely as normal (telework). A significant
decline in gross receipts
For tax year 2020, the business must have seen a 50 percent drop in gross receipts when
comparing a quarter in 2020 with the corresponding quarter in 2019.Beginning in 2021,
businesses must have seen more than a 20 percent drop in gross receipts in Q1 and Q2
compared to the same quarter in 2019. A new business is allowed to use gross receipts
for the quarter in which it started business as a reference for any quarter in which it
did not have 2019 figures.
What are “qualified wages” and how to claim credits?
Qualified wages are compensation paid by an employer to some or all FTE’s in the relevant
quarter. Qualified wages include the employer’s qualified health plan expenses that are
allocable to the wages.The ERC is applied to employer’s contribution to Social Security
& Medicare taxes and is fully refundable. In order to claim ERC, you must calculate
total qualified wages and the related health insurance costs for each quarter, and
retroactively claim the credit through Form 941-X.
The Million Dollar Question is . . . Do They Have The Time?
Do they have the time to dig into the text of American Rescue Plan Act of 2021
And its accompanying referenced laws like:
CARES Act, Families First Act, Payroll
&
Healthcare Enhancement Act, PPP Payroll Flexibility Act
and the
Consolidated
Appropriations Act.
Time to read the
IRS Interpretations and FAQ’s
? And cross-reference those
definitions with that of PPP which was separately defined and dissimilarly
interpreted in the
Small Business Administration’s Bulletins and IFRs?
Do they have the time to ensure accuracy in eligibility determination, maximize your
computation and create the supporting documentation you’ll need to support an IRS
audit of employer taxes?
So far, we have not found a bookkeeper who is able to take all this on, while handling
the day-to-day of bookkeeping. If yours can, then take them up on their offer. We’re
happy to take a second look.
How does the number of employees factor into the ERC?
The rules are different depending on how many employees you have. The updated 2021
program bumped these categories up from 100 full-time employees (FTE’s) in 2019 to 500
FTE’s in 2019. Employers with 500 or fewer FTE’s in 2019 can apply the ERC towards all
qualified wages paid to employees during those quarters, whether or not employees were
working at the time. Employers with more than 500 full-time employees can apply the ERC
towards qualified wages paid to employees who were not working during a quarter because
the business suspended operations or had a significant decline in gross receipts. These
employers can only count wages up to the amount that the employee would have been paid
for working an equivalent duration during the 30 days immediately preceding the period
of economic hardship.
I got PPP funds already. Can I also get ERTC?
Initially with the
CARES Act,
employers could choose to apply for PPP or claim
ERTC credits, but not both.
PPP was more beneficial than ERTC for most businesses (for reasons we won’t go into here)
and so most businesses with under 500 employees received forgivable PPP Loans.
On March 11, 2021,
The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021
was signed into law and
included many modifications and expansions to existing elements of previous stimulus
programs.
Noteworthy modifications for business owners included:
Businesses who applied for and received PPP funds could now also claim ERTC
credits.
ERTC credits could be
retroactively claimed
for businesses that qualified in
2020.
ERTC credits were extended through 9/30/21 with lower qualification requirements.
The per-employee cap on qualifying wages increased from $10,000 for all of 2020 to
$10,000 per quarter for the first 3 quarters of 2021.
The refundable credit amount increased from 50% of qualifying wages in 2020 to 70%
in 2021.
So the short answer is
“Yes”
. . . you can claim ERTC even if you received PPP
funds.
How do I apply for ERTC tax credits?
Unlike the
Payroll Protection Program
(administered by the Small Business
Administration), there is actually no “application process” for the
Employee
Retention Tax Credits.
You simply claim the ERTC tax credit like you would any other tax credit – by asserting
to the IRS that you can legally claim the credit.
When you claim a child tax credit, you do so by asserting this fact on your Form 1020
Personal Income Tax Return.
The difference is that when you claim an ERTC tax credit, you do so on your Form 941
Employer Quarterly Tax Filing.
For prior quarters, you must file an amended form (the Form 941-X) to reduce your current
quarter’s tax contribution and request a refund of excess credits (which is highly
likely).
Another perk of ERTC, is that since you can often estimate these credits in advance of
distributing cash for payroll, you can file a Form 7200 to receive a cash advance to
avoid waiting until the end of the quarter to apply for the refund.
My revenue in Q1 2021 is back to pre-pandemic levels - so I must be ineligible - right?
Even though you may feel like revenue is back to normal, there are some items you want to
consider before passing on this ERTC assessment.
First, even if revenues have returned to “normal” in 2021, you
may have qualified in
2020 and you can retroactively claim those credits.
That eligibility criteria in
2020 was based on revenue declines from 2019, or if your business was partially or fully
closed due to governmental mandate.
Second, while your revenue may have returned to “normal” in Q1 2021, remember that
we
are comparing your Q1 2021 to Q1 2019.
If 2019 was a year of growth for your
business, then your revenue levels 2 years ago may have been much less than Q1 2020.
And lastly, if your revenues were down in
Q4 2020 by just 20% compared to Q4 2019,
then you may also be eligible for Q1 2021. There is a safe harbor provision that few
advisors are talking about, and it means that many businesses are qualifying for $7,000
per employee in Q1 2021.
I know, it seems too good to be true, but the government wants to incentivize and reward
you for keeping US residents employed and money flowing through our economy as we
rebuild bigger and stronger than before.
I thought payroll taxes deferred in 2020 had to be re-paid. Does ERTC work the same way?
You are most likely referring to a provision of the
CARES Act
that allowed
employers to defer the deposit and payment of the employer’s share of Social Security
taxes. Those deferrals must then be repaid – with at least 50% of the balance due by
12/31/21 and the remaining balance due by 12/31/22.
ERTC credits are
NOT
a deferral. They are dollar-for-dollar credits against wages
you’ve paid. Not taxes you’ve paid, but actual wages.
These credits can offset future tax contributions or you can receive a refund check –
it’s your choice.
And you will
NOT
have to re-pay these funds (unless, of course, you don’t provide
adequate documentation in the course of an audit).
Why isn't my bank talking about this?
Your banker was probably very helpful when it came to getting your PPP funds because they
were effectively signing you to an SBA-guaranteed loan. The SBA paid the bank
administrative fees based on the PPP loans they made, and so they were incentivized to
educate you about the program and get all your paperwork in order.
Compared to the ERTC, the PPP program was also a rather simple calculation. 2 ½ times
your average monthly payroll including health insurance and state unemployment taxes.
From the conversations we’ve had with bankers, they have no interest in involving
themselves in your employment tax compliance. For them it is a liability and beyond
their scope of services.
Will my Tax CPA handle this for me since they handle my income tax returns?
Whether your tax accountant is a CPA or EA, he or she most likely only prepares your
Federal and State Income Tax Returns. However, ERTC credits are claimed against
Employment Taxes on Form 941, and cash advanced through Form 7200.
The complexity of the ERTC program is a beast unto itself and every tax accountant we’ve
talked to has said they focus on staying up-to-date on the ever-evolving income tax
code, and they can’t now become experts in the ERTC program as well.
If your tax accountant is comfortable determining your eligibility by quarter and year,
computing your credits, and preparing contemporaneous documentation to support an IRS
audit, then you should certainly let them handle all of this.
If you want a second set of eyes on this, we’re happy to take a look.
What about my Payroll Service Provider? Shouldn't they be on top of this?
Your Payroll Service does an excellent job of executing the fundamentals of paying your
employees, paying your employment taxes and filing your quarterly reports.
But computing your ERTC credits requires visibility into your P&L and PPP forgiveness
applications. Not only that, but the complex requirements around eligibility and
allocating ERTC credits at the employee-level while accounting for annual and quarterly
qualifying wage gaps and . . . well, you can probably tell why Payroll Services are not
offering to do all of this for you.
The Payroll Services that we’ve worked with so far are happy to provide the payroll
registers that we need to perform the allocations. And they are happy to file the
Amended Form 941-X
with the IRS on our client’s behalf.
But that’s the extent of it.
In fact, most wise Payroll Services are asking clients to sign an indemnification waiver
before submitting a Form 941-X because the Payroll Service can take no responsibility
for the accuracy of the ERTC credits you are claiming.
For them to involve themselves in the intricacies of this calculation, it is a liability
and beyond their scope of services.
Why did the IRS issue a warning about 3rd party processing companies?
The IRS issued these warnings, as there are many fly-by-night, so-called ERC “experts” or
“consultants” that are misrepresenting their experiences and the parameters of the ERC
program to employers. The ERC is a complicated tax program that requires deep expertise
and understand of the nuances. When choosing an ERC company look for companies with a
proven real track record and watch out for red flags (e..g, large upfront cost, no CPAs
or tax professionals on staff)
How long does the IRS have to audit my ERC?
“The IRS Audit period for ERC is:
3 years for 2020 and Q1,Q2 of 2021
5 years for Q3 of 2021 “
Are there any restrictions on how I can spend my ERC refund?
Unlike a loan or other form of business funding, the Employee Retention Credit (ERC) is a
fully refundable tax credit that does not come with limitations on how it can be spent.
As a result, businesses that qualify for the ERC can choose to spend their refund in any
way they see fit.

Are You Eligible?
Do you need to be a scientist to be eligible for R&D tax credit? NO
R&D tax credits are available to all organizations that engage in certain activities. Opportunities
also exist in industries that are not known for conducting R&D activities like Software development,
Agriculture, Architecture, Construction, and Engineering, Restaurants, Retail.
If you are conducting qualified research and development projects, it is beneficial to claim the R&D
tax credit regardless of your company’s taxable income. R&D tax credits can be carried forward to
offset future income tax liability. Typically, credits that cannot be used immediately will carry
forward for up to 20 years. Also, companies can often claim the R&D tax credit retroactively by
filing amended returns.
Examples of R&D activities include but are not limited to the following:
Developing or engineering a new or improved product, process, formula, or software
Evaluating the feasibility of a product, process, formula, or software
Developing engineering architecture
Developing experimental models & prototypes
Testing an experimental product, process,formula, or software
Beta testing
Improving processes or the manufacturability of a product
Technical design reviews
Participating in technical meetings
Documenting the results of research
Maintaining research equipment
Compiling research data
Fabricating experimental models
Experimenting with innovative technologies
Creating more efficient and environmentally
friendly designs
Supervising technical personnel engaged in R&D
R&D Tax Credit Criteria
Qualified Purpose
To develop a new or improved business component including product, process, software, technique,
invention, or formula to enhance functionality, performance, reliability, or quality.
Technological in nature
The business component’s development must be based on a hard science, such as computer science,
engineering, biological sciences, or the physical sciences, including testing, developing
models, software, patents, or prototypes.
Technical Uncertainty
From the outset, the organization must have faced technological technical uncertainty when
designing or developing the business component. For example, this technical uncertainty can be
related to the capability or methodology of the development or improvement, or the
appropriateness of the design.
Process of experimentation
The company must have evaluated multiple design alternatives or employed a systematic trial and
error approach to overcome the technological uncertainties.

– FAQ’s
What is the R&D tax credit?
Established in 1981, this incentive rewards US-businesses for investing in research and
development (R&D) activities. This incentive lowers the income tax liability for businesses
that develop new or improve existing products, processes, software, or formulas.
How do I know if I qualify?
The definition of qualified activities is pretty broad. Because of this, there is no cookie
cutter industry or company profile that determines eligibility. If you have developed a
product, process, software, or formula that relies on either physical, biological,
engineering, or computer science, it’s very likely you qualify.
How much is it worth?
The credit is generally worth 10% of your qualified expenditures such as wages, contractors,
hosting and infrastructure, and supplies.
How do I use this credit?
The R&D tax credit is designed to lower a company’s tax liability. For established
businesses, it is used as a direct dollar-for-dollar reduction of your income tax liability.
If you’re a startup, you may have the option to use this credit against the employer’s
portion of social security taxes up to $250,000 per year. To be eligible as a qualified
startup, you must be within your first five years of gross receipt, and be under $5 million
in gross receipts for the tax year in consideration.
I won’t have an income tax liability for this year. Is it still worth it to claim this
credit?
Yes! These credits have a 20 year carry forward period to be used against future income tax
liabilities.
How do I claim this credit?
You claim this credit by filing an additional tax form along with your company’s annual tax
filing. Occams will prepare the necessary additional tax forms for you, and you will provide
them to your CPA to be filed alongside your annual filing.
I’ve never claimed this credit before. Can I go back and claim for previous years?
You can amend previous tax returns to claim any unclaimed credits. Based on the statute of
limitations for amending previous returns, you can go back up to 3 years to claim the R&D
credit.
In doing so, you may potentially get a refund based on income taxes you paid in those years,
or you can carry forward those credits to future years.
I already have a CPA. Is this something they can do for me?
Great! We partner with hundreds of CPAs to help their clients claim these tax incentives. We
find this to be a bit of a specialty service – think of your CPA as a general practitioner,
and Occams as a cardiologist.
Occams does not file any forms on your behalf – we prepare all the necessary forms to be
included with your annual filing. In this case, you would pass along our work to your CPA,
and we’ll work with them as needed to make sure everything gets done accordingly.
Is this a one-time thing?
No. This credit can be claimed for every year in which you incur R&D expenses. There is no
limit to the number of times you can claim this credit, and there is no cap on the amount.
What is the process to claim the credit?
There are two important parts to an R&D tax credit study: substantiation and calculation. Our
team of experts will help you build the case for why you qualified for the R&D credit
(substantiation), and work with you build the financial framework to calculate your credit.
We try to take on most of the heavy lifting so you don’t have to. The timeline varies from
company to company, but traditionally a study takes about 3-4 weeks.
What do I do if I get audited?
As long as your filing does not contain errors, you are guaranteed to receive a credit based
on the expenses you claimed. However, the IRS may request documentation to prove that your
expenses meet the criteria for qualified research. This is what we’re building during our
process.
We make sure your R&D claim is bulletproof. Even if the IRS disagrees with the amount of your
credit, they won’t charge you penalties or interest, just the difference in calculation.

The Path Forward: Fragility vs. Resilience
Introduction
Money is the foundation of economic activity. It dictates how value is stored, transferred, and measured. Yet, beneath the surface, the structure of a monetary system defines its fragility or resilience. In today’s world, we operate under a fiat standard, where money is created through debt. But an alternative is emerging—a Bitcoin standard, where money is tied to energy and computation rather than credit expansion.
Fiat Standard: Debt = Money Supply
Under the modern fiat system, money does not exist independently—it is issued into existence through debt. When a central bank issues money or a commercial bank extends a loan, it simultaneously creates a liability. This means:
Total Money Supply ≈ Σ (Outstanding Debt)
New credit issuance expands the money supply. Debt repayment contracts the money supply. If debt creation halts, money disappears, leading to deflation.
Example: The Debt-Expansion Feedback Loop
Imagine an economy where the government and private sector hold $10T in debt. If interest rates are 5%, the system requires $500B in new money just to pay the interest. This forces further borrowing:
New Debt = Old Debt + (Old Debt × Interest Rate)
If credit growth stalls, debt defaults start cascading, leading to a financial crisis. This is why fiat economies are inherently fragile—they require infinite expansion in a finite world from a resource standpoint.
Bitcoin Standard: Energy + Computation = Money Supply
Bitcoin is fundamentally different. Instead of money being issued as debt, Bitcoin is issued as a function of thermodynamic proof-of-work. It is backed by energy and computational work, making it a closed-loop monetary system.
New Bitcoin Supply = f(Energy Expended, Computational Difficulty)
Unlike fiat money, which can be printed arbitrarily, Bitcoin’s issuance follows a predictable curve:
Total BTC ≤ 21,000,000
This makes Bitcoin structurally anti-inflationary. Rather than requiring infinite credit expansion, its security model is rooted in thermodynamics—real-world energy and computation.
Explaining f in the Equation
In the equation:
New Bitcoin Supply = f(Energy Expended, Computational Difficulty),
The function f represents a complex algorithm that governs Bitcoin mining. It adjusts the mining reward based on:
- The amount of computational work done (hash power used by miners).
- The difficulty level, which is adjusted roughly every two weeks to maintain a steady block time of ~10 minutes.
This ensures that new Bitcoin is issued in a controlled and predictable manner, regardless of fluctuations in mining power.

Fiat vs Bitcoin at a glance
The Path Forward: Fragility vs. Resilience
The fiat system is fundamentally fragile because it requires constant credit expansion. Bitcoin, by contrast, is resilient because its monetary base is independent of debt dynamics and secured by physical energy. As Occams Advisory continues to explore Bitcoin’s role in financial architecture, one question remains:
Do we want a system built on perpetual debt, or one anchored in immutable scarcity?
The answer to that question may define the FUTURE OF MONEY.

Introduction
In today’s dynamic business landscape, navigating the complexities of financial transactions can be a daunting task. Occams Advisory, a global financial advisory and professional services firm, offers a unique solution through its proprietary fintech platforms. These innovative platforms are designed to streamline financial processes, enhance risk management, and empower businesses to achieve their growth objectives.
Real Life Situations
Consider a thriving e-commerce business struggling to manage its payment processing infrastructure. Occams Merchant Services (OMS), a comprehensive payment processing platform, can seamlessly integrate with the business’s existing systems, providing a single source for all payment processing needs. OMS simplifies merchant account onboarding, payment gateway integration, fraud prevention, and chargeback management, enabling the business to focus on its core operations.
Another real-life scenario involves a business seeking to reduce costs associated with traditional credit card payments. EquiPay, Occams’ paperless checking solution, offers a cost-effective alternative. By accepting payments directly from customers’ bank accounts, businesses can eliminate credit card processing fees and streamline their payment processes.

The Big Takeaway
Introduction
In the high-stakes world of financial and professional services, where relationships and trust dictate success, lead generation isn’t just a business function—it’s the engine that powers growth, revenue, and industry leadership. Yet, many businesses treat it as a box to check rather than the strategic imperative it truly is.
As a
Senior B2B Lead Generation Specialist,
I’ve seen how transformative a robust lead generation strategy can be. Done right, it’s not just about finding leads; it’s about building a dynamic ecosystem that attracts, engages, and converts the right prospects, time and time again.
Let’s dive into why lead generation is the beating heart of B2B success and how it can redefine the growth trajectory of your business.
1. Fueling the Sales Pipeline: From Chaos to Consistency
Picture your sales team as a highly skilled crew aboard a ship—but without a steady stream of leads, they’re navigating aimlessly in open waters. Lead generation acts as the compass, charting the path to new opportunities.
A Steady Stream of Leads:
A well-oiled lead generation strategy ensures that your sales pipeline never runs dry. It creates momentum, turning sporadic wins into consistent victories.
Empowering Sales Teams:
With a predictable flow of qualified leads, sales professionals can focus on what they do best: closing deals and nurturing relationships, rather than scrambling to find prospects.
Why it matters:
In financial and professional services, where buying decisions are high-value and complex, consistency isn’t a luxury—it’s survival.
2. Building Brand Awareness: Visibility Breeds Trust
In a world where expertise is currency, you can’t afford to be invisible. Effective lead generation doesn’t just find potential clients; it puts your brand on the map, amplifying your voice and authority in the marketplace.
Be Seen, Be Trusted:
A robust strategy increases your visibility where it matters most—whether it’s on LinkedIn, industry forums, or through thought-provoking webinars.
Establishing Thought Leadership:
Offering valuable insights through whitepapers, blogs, and industry reports positions your brand as the trusted advisor prospects turn to when they need answers.
Example:
A financial advisory firm sharing actionable insights on navigating economic uncertainty isn’t just educating—it’s cultivating trust and making its name synonymous with reliability.
3. Identifying Ideal Customers: Precision Over Guesswork
Not every lead is created equal, and in B2B, chasing the wrong ones can be a costly mistake. Modern lead generation helps you zero in on your ideal customer profile with pinpoint accuracy.
Insights That Matter:
Advanced tools and analytics help uncover who your ideal customers are, what they value, and where they engage.
Personalized Outreach:
Once you know your audience, tailored messaging and solutions make your business irresistible.
Why this works:
In professional services, personalization isn’t optional—it’s expected. High-value prospects respond to tailored outreach that speaks to their unique pain points.
4. Measuring Marketing Effectiveness: Metrics That Drive Growth
Lead generation without measurement is like sailing without a map. Knowing what works—and what doesn’t—is critical to evolving and scaling your strategy.
Track What Matters:
Metrics such as cost per lead, conversion rates, and lead quality scores provide a clear picture of performance.
Data-Driven Decisions:
Armed with data, you can double down on high-performing strategies and cut the fat from underperforming campaigns.
Pro Tip:
In financial services, data isn’t just a tool; it’s your competitive advantage. Use it not only to optimize campaigns but to predict future trends and client behaviors.
5. Fostering Long-Term Relationships: From Leads to Lifelong Clients
Lead generation is often seen as transactional—generate a lead, close the deal, move on. But in industries where relationships are king, that mindset is shortsighted.
Nurture to Win:
Building trust with consistent, value-driven communication turns prospects into loyal clients.
From Clients to Advocates:
Happy clients become your biggest champions, bringing in referral leads and amplifying your reputation.
Real Impact:
Imagine a law firm nurturing a lead with personalized updates about industry legislation. When the lead finally needs representation, guess who they’ll call?
6. Gaining a Competitive Edge: Dominate, Don’t Just Compete
In B2B, it’s not enough to keep up—you need to stand out. A well-executed lead generation strategy doesn’t just keep you in the game; it positions you as the frontrunner.
Outshine Competitors:
By delivering value before the competition even gets a foot in the door, you establish yourself as the obvious choice.
Market Share Growth:
A consistent flow of quality leads translates directly to increased revenue, market share, and industry influence.
The Bottom Line:
In financial and professional services, trust is hard to win and easy to lose. Lead generation is your opportunity to make a strong first impression—and keep the momentum going.
Strategies to Supercharge Your Lead Generation
Ready to transform your approach? Here are strategies that have delivered exceptional results in financial and professional services:
1.
Content Marketing:
Share high-value insights through blogs, whitepapers, and webinars that address real-world challenges.
2.
Social Media Marketing:
Leverage LinkedIn and other platforms to engage directly with decision-makers and build your professional network.
3.
Email Marketing:
Use targeted campaigns to nurture leads with personalized, actionable content.
4.
Paid Advertising:
Platforms like LinkedIn Ads and Google Ads help you reach high-intent prospects with precision.
5.
Partnerships and Networking:
Collaborate with influencers and industry organizations to expand your reach and credibility.
The Big Takeaway
Lead generation isn’t a one-and-done activity—it’s a living, breathing process that drives the growth of your sales pipeline, builds your brand’s authority, and keeps you ahead of the competition.
As a Senior B2B Lead Generation Specialist, I’ve seen how businesses in financial and professional services can flourish when they make lead generation a strategic priority. It’s not just about finding leads—it’s about forging connections, solving problems, and creating lasting value.

Executive Summary
The landscape of Research and Development (R&D) tax credits is evolving rapidly, driven by the proliferation of emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain, and the Internet of Things (IoT). These advancements present both opportunities and challenges for businesses seeking to maximize their R&D tax credit claims. Additionally, energy-efficient building incentives like 179D and 45L tax credits offer significant benefits for companies focusing on sustainable development. This white paper explores how companies can adapt to these changes, ensuring they remain competitive and fully benefit from available incentives.
For companies looking to navigate these complexities, expert guidance is crucial. Occams Advisory specializes in R&D tax credit services, offering tailored solutions to help businesses maximize their benefits.
Introduction
Research and Development (R&D) tax credits have long been a cornerstone of innovation policy, providing financial incentives for companies to invest in new technologies and processes. As we move further into the 21st century, emerging technologies are reshaping industries at an unprecedented pace. To stay ahead, businesses must not only integrate these technologies into their operations but also navigate the evolving landscape of R&D tax credits. Additionally, the 179D and 45L energy-efficient building incentives offer substantial benefits for companies aiming to improve their energy efficiency.
Understanding Emerging Technologies
AI encompasses machine learning, neural networks, and natural language processing, offering transformative potential across various sectors. Companies leveraging AI in their R&D activities can benefit from significant advancements in automation, data analysis, and product development.
Blockchain technology, known for its secure and transparent transaction capabilities, is revolutionizing industries such as finance, supply chain, and healthcare. Its applications in secure data sharing and smart contracts present new avenues for R&D.
IoT involves interconnected devices that communicate and exchange data. This technology is pivotal in creating smart environments, from homes to factories, enabling real-time monitoring and optimization of systems.
179D and 45L Energy Tax Credits
The 179D and 45L tax credits are crucial for businesses focusing on energy-efficient building projects. The 179D tax deduction provides benefits for commercial buildings that achieve specific energy efficiency standards, while the 45L tax credit applies to energy-efficient residential properties. These incentives complement traditional R&D tax credits by promoting sustainable innovation in building technologies.
Identifying Qualifying R&D Activities
To qualify for R&D tax credits, AI projects must demonstrate a clear advancement in the field, addressing scientific or technological uncertainties. Examples include developing new algorithms, enhancing machine learning models, or creating AI-driven applications that solve complex problems.
R&D in blockchain may involve developing new protocols, enhancing security features, or creating innovative applications for decentralized systems. These activities must show a systematic approach to solving technical challenges and advancing the technology.
Qualifying IoT R&D activities often include designing new sensor technologies, improving data communication protocols, or developing advanced data analytics platforms. Projects should focus on overcoming technical obstacles and advancing the integration of IoT systems.
Energy-Efficient Building Projects
Qualifying activities under the 179D and 45L tax credits involve designing and implementing energy-efficient building technologies. This includes developing new HVAC systems, lighting solutions, or building envelope improvements that meet or exceed energy efficiency standards.
With the rapidly changing technology landscape, having a knowledgeable partner can make all the difference. Occams Advisory provides specialized expertise to ensure your projects meet the necessary criteria for R&D tax credits.
Documentation and Compliance
Accurate and comprehensive documentation is crucial for substantiating R&D tax credit claims. Businesses should maintain detailed records of project objectives, methodologies, and outcomes, along with time tracking and expense reports.
Compliance with Regulatory Requirements
Adhering to the latest regulations and guidelines is essential. Companies should stay informed about changes in R&D tax credit legislation and ensure their activities meet the criteria set forth by tax authorities. For energy-efficient projects, this includes ensuring compliance with the standards required for 179D and 45L tax credits.
Case Studies: Early Adopters of Emerging Technology R&D
AI in Healthcare
A healthcare company developed an AI-based diagnostic tool that improves the accuracy and speed of disease detection. By systematically documenting their R&D process and demonstrating the tool’s advancement over existing technologies, they successfully claimed R&D tax credits, reducing their tax liability significantly.
Blockchain in Supply Chain Management
A logistics firm implemented a blockchain-based system to enhance transparency and security in their supply chain. The project involved developing new protocols and overcoming technical challenges, qualifying them for substantial R&D tax credits.
IoT in Manufacturing.
A manufacturing company integrated IoT sensors into their production lines to monitor equipment performance in real-time. The project required developing custom sensors and data analytics platforms, allowing them to claim R&D tax credits for their innovative efforts.
Energy-Efficient Building Projects
A construction firm focused on developing energy-efficient residential properties qualified for the 45L tax credit by integrating advanced insulation and HVAC systems. Another company improved the energy efficiency of a commercial building, meeting the standards for the 179D tax deduction through innovative lighting and building envelope technologies.
Adapting Documentation and Compliance for New Technologies
Leveraging Technology for Record-Keeping
Emerging technologies can also aid in maintaining compliance. Utilizing blockchain for secure documentation, AI for automated record-keeping, and IoT for real-time data collection can streamline the R&D tax credit claim process.
As governments adapt to the rapid pace of technological change, R&D tax credit regulations may evolve. Companies should establish processes to monitor legislative updates and adjust their R&D strategies accordingly. This includes staying informed about changes to the 179D and 45L energy tax credit requirements.
Occams Advisory continuously monitors regulatory changes to provide clients with up-to-date advice, helping them stay compliant and maximize their R&D tax credit benefits.
Future Trends in R&D Tax Credits
Governments worldwide recognize the transformative potential of emerging technologies and are likely to enhance R&D tax credit schemes to support innovation in these areas.
Future R&D tax credits may place more emphasis on projects that contribute to sustainability and environmental goals, encouraging companies to develop green technologies. The 179D and 45L tax credits are prime examples of this trend, promoting energy efficiency in building projects.
The trend towards open innovation and collaboration across industries and borders may influence R&D tax credit policies, promoting joint ventures and knowledge sharing.
Conclusion
The future of R&D tax credits is intrinsically linked to the adoption and development of emerging technologies. By understanding the nuances of these technologies, meticulously documenting their R&D activities, and staying compliant with evolving regulations, businesses can maximize their tax credit benefits. As governments continue to recognize the importance of innovation, companies that adapt to these changes will be well-positioned to thrive in the future.

A corporation may be eligible for the R&D Tax Credit if it spends money on research and development activities. The credit works to lower a company’s Corporation Tax by 25% of the qualifying expenses (CT). A business may seek for a credit that is payable in instalments if its CT liabilities have been offset in both the current and prior years.
A business might be eligible for the R&D Tax Credit if:
It falls under the jurisdiction of CT in Ireland
if qualifying R&D activities are carried out in either Ireland or the European Economic Area (EEA) and
It falls under the jurisdiction of CT in Ireland if qualifying R&D activities are carried out in either Ireland or the European Economic Area (EEA)
Which documents are needed to qualify for RnD tax credits?
What paperwork do I need to submit to get the R&D tax credit?
When requesting a tax credit for R&D, the IRS does not define what constitutes “adequate proof.” However, because it is the taxpayer’s responsibility to provide evidence, your company should save as much proof of your R&D endeavours as you can in case of an audit. Some of the records you need to have on hand are the following:
Payroll data for personnel actively participating in research and development, as well as for personnel or managers in charge of them
General ledger reports that differentiate between company costs and suppliers connected to R&D
Copies of the agreements and bills paid to any contractors that conduct third-party research for you
Maintaining timesheets for meetings, payroll, work plans, and other events to demonstrate their connection to R&D
Design schematics, test results, blueprints, status updates, marketing materials, and any other paperwork that demonstrates how your study was conducted and its relevance
Can the research tax credits for my small business be increased?
The R&D tax credit is available to small enterprises in a variety of ways. Small enterprises that meet the requirements may apply for tax credits to offset rising research costs. You must demonstrate that your costs have grown from the prior year of operation in order to be eligible for this credit.
Up to $250,000 in payroll taxes may be deducted from this deduction if your eligible small company has no income tax obligation. Small enterprises that qualify must have yearly gross revenues of less than $5 million and five years of total gross receipts. As a result, even if your small firm isn’t currently making money, you may still claim tax credits for research costs.
Startups may now use the federal R&D tax credit, even if they do not pay federal income tax, to offset up to $250,000 of their FICA payroll tax during their first five taxable years thanks to the PATH Act of 2015, which made the benefit permanent.
They must, however, have gross revenues in the tax credit year of no more than $5 million and no gross receipts in any of the five taxable years before to the tax credit year.
Rules for Business Tax Credit Limitations
The total of your Qualified Research Expenses (QRE), which might include salaries, contractor fees, and supplier prices, determines how much you are reimbursed in R&D tax credits. Most taxpayers’ QREs are made up almost entirely of wages.
Your tax credit is only worth up to the amount of your tax bill that exceeds $20,000, as stated in Section 38 of the IRS tax law. A startup may not be able to immediately benefit from the R&D tax credit if it has little to no revenue or current-year tax burden. In this scenario, the firm will have carryforwards for unused R&D tax credits, but it will only be able to utilise them once the company is successful, at which point it may not require as much money for an R&D tax credit.

Debunking 4 Common Tax Myths You Should Know Before Filing Your Return
If you’re like most people, taxes can be a source of anxiety and confusion. With all the information out there, it’s easy to fall for myths that could end up costing you money or landing you in trouble with the IRS. In this blog post, we’ll explore 4 common tax myths and provide the facts you need to know before filing your return.
Introduction
Filing your taxes can be a daunting task, but it doesn’t have to be. By knowing the facts and avoiding common tax myths, you can file your return with confidence and avoid potential penalties or audits. Let’s dive into the myths and uncover the truth.
Myth #1: “I don’t need to file taxes if I didn’t earn enough income”
Many people believe that if they didn’t earn a lot of money, they don’t need to file taxes. This is a common misconception. The truth is that even if you didn’t earn enough to owe taxes, you still need to file a tax return if your income exceeds certain thresholds. For example, in 2022, if you are a single filer under the age of 65, you need to file a tax return if your income is $12,950 or more. Failing to file a tax return when required to do so can result in penalties and interest charges.
Myth #2: “I can deduct all my home office expenses”
With more people working from home, there has been an increase in the number of taxpayers claiming home office deductions. However, not all home office expenses are deductible. To qualify for the deduction, you must use a portion of your home regularly and exclusively for business purposes. Additionally, the deduction is limited to the income earned from your business.
Myth #3: “I can avoid taxes by moving my money to offshore accounts”
Some people believe that they can avoid paying taxes by moving their money to offshore accounts. However, this is illegal and can result in severe penalties and legal consequences. Additionally, the IRS has increased its efforts to crack down on offshore tax evasion, so it’s not worth the risk.
Myth #4: “I don’t need to report cash transactions under $10,000”
Another common tax myth is that you don’t need to report cash transactions under $10,000. However, this is not true. Any cash transaction, regardless of the amount, must be reported if it involves a business or activity that is required to be licensed or registered with the federal government.
Conclusion
Filing your taxes can be a complicated process, but by knowing the facts and avoiding common tax myths, you can file your return with confidence and avoid potential penalties or audits. YouTube as a Powerful Marketing Tool for Your Business
In the digital age, YouTube has emerged as a dominant platform for content consumption, entertainment, and information. However, YouTube is not just limited to personal use. It also holds immense potential as a marketing tool for businesses. This article explores the importance of YouTube in modern marketing and provides strategies to leverage this platform effectively for your business.
The Importance of YouTube in Modern Marketing
YouTube has revolutionized the way businesses connect with their target audience. Here’s why YouTube is a critical component of modern marketing strategies:
1. Vast Reach and Engagement: With over 2 billion monthly active users, YouTube offers an enormous audience for businesses to tap into. The platform’s engaging nature, long watch times, and diverse content attract users who are actively seeking information, entertainment, and solutions.
2. Visual and Engaging Content: YouTube’s video-centric nature allows businesses to showcase their products, services, and brand personality in a visually appealing and engaging manner. Videos enable storytelling, demonstrations, tutorials, and testimonials, fostering deeper connections with the audience.
3. SEO Benefits and Search Visibility: YouTube is the second-largest search engine after Google. By optimizing your video content with relevant keywords, tags, and descriptions, you can enhance your search visibility, drive organic traffic, and increase brand visibility.
Strategies for Leveraging YouTube for Business Marketing
To leverage YouTube effectively for your business marketing, consider implementing the following strategies:
1. Create Compelling Video Content: Produce high-quality and engaging videos that align with your brand and resonate with your target audience. Develop a content strategy that educates, entertains, and adds value to viewers’ lives. Consistency, storytelling, and authenticity are key to building a loyal subscriber base.
2. Optimize Videos for SEO: Conduct keyword research to identify relevant search terms and incorporate them in your video titles, descriptions, tags, and captions. Utilize appropriate thumbnail images, engaging titles, and compelling video descriptions to increase click-through rates and visibility.

Lessons In Remote Jobs From The Covid-19 Boom
Nov 06 2020 |
Occams Marketing
94
0
In most cases, on a quicker timeline than any of us may have recommended or signed up for before the pandemic, the spread of Covid-19 prompted a major, unprecedented move to operate from home.
These were daunting tasks, performed in a matter of weeks, if not days. It was a bumpy ride for most businesses. Just 24 percent of IT leaders said their companies experienced no downtime, according to data from Insight, and 44 percent experienced more than two weeks of downtime.
But the results have been overwhelmingly positive across sectors. Corporate America has learned that certain tasks and operations can be conducted remotely in a highly efficient way using today's communication resources and networking.
Although we do not yet grasp what the equilibrium between on-site and remote work would be, drawing on the experiences of our recent experience will help minimise friction when and where we have to pivot again. Here are a couple of cases I have observed.
Our customers are much more versatile than we thought before, and so are we.
In cities across the world, after stay-at - home directives went into effect, IT leaders had to ramp up programmes and pursue innovative solutions to challenges we had never encountered before to keep our staff up and working remotely.
To successfully navigate this transition, it was crucial to immediately have safe access to collaborative resources and equipment for thousands of team members. The crisis generated the necessity for my company to complete the conversion of our team members to Microsoft Teams and Cisco WebEx fast, providing our team members with the resources to communicate safely from anywhere, at any time.
As several other companies, equipment shortages, especially computers, have slowed us down. We found a fast remedy as a dealer for a major electronics company: buying laptops we had in our distribution centres, and imaging and deploying them in record time.
Importantly, by
consumer apathy
or opposition, we were not slowed down. Our team mates were with us right there, moving for our shared purpose of helping our clients in unusual circumstances. This experience taught us that members of our team are eager and ready to embrace new ways of operating more easily than we previously believed. And it proved that we can work quicker on big releases of technologies, as an IT team, while also retaining adequate controls and delivering good performance.
The insights that IT will give our businesses go way beyond technology.
Before the pandemic, most companies still had certain team members who were distant. It can be difficult, though, to be the only remote entity when everyone else is in the workplace. This can mean skipping casual sidebar discussions or not getting the ability to talk up in staff sessions as much as possible.
Today, even more staff members are in the "same place," collaborating remotely and supporting video conferencing and networking technologies. This reform was a great equaliser, creating a more egalitarian work climate for office staff in general. But, particularly for individuals who lead teams, there are difficulties. When you can't both be in the same place, how do you build a team dynamic? When "managing by wandering around" isn't practical, how do you inspire people?
As our peers in our respective organisations are beginning to understand, we already have the answers in IT. For us, it's nothing new to accomplish targets by scattered teams, with just partial co-locations. We still had people operating both remotely and during off-hours. We have already learned how simulated teams can be engaged and their effectiveness maximised.
When firms start getting some workers back into the workplace, IT professionals have an opportunity to share their experiences and help their businesses draw on the positive behavioural improvements that occurred through the crisis. This could involve taking stock of main functions that can already be conducted together and designing operating models that generate continuity across diverse work environments.
Covid-19, of course, pushed enterprises to make numerous more rapid technological improvements, from massively expanding consumer interactive experiences to rethinking customer service, and more. Yet no transition touched more staff members or provided more options than the surge in remote work to involve our teams differently. Now is the time for Us to look inward, develop outward and help our organisations establish new operating models that improve mobility and allow us in the new normal to better address the needs of our employees.

Employee retention credit: Navigating the suspension test
Mar 10 2023 |
Occams Marketing
117
2
Establishing eligibility for the employee retention credit (ERC) by satisfying the business operations suspension test (suspension test) is similar to venturing into remote parts of the world: The payoff from a successful journey can be tremendous, but the road is arduous. Complexity adds uncertainty, guidance is lacking, and what appears to be an easy path may lead you off a cliff.
While the ERC program has fully sunset, employers may still file claims for any credits they were entitled to in 2020 through the third quarter of 2021, and interest remains strong. Like a sign on a path warning of danger ahead, this item is intended to help mitigate risk for those still pursuing the ERC by (1) breaking down the suspension test into its core components and (2) shedding light on areas to proceed with caution. As an aside, this is a complex analysis with many moving parts, most of which are beyond the scope of this discussion, and consulting someone with experience is advisable.
The suspension test overview
Under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, P.L. 116-136, and Notice 2021-20, an employer can be eligible for the ERC if it experiences a full or partial suspension or modification of operations due to COVID-19-related orders from an appropriate governmental authority. This is the suspension test, and it is one of three means for eligibility, the others being relatively objective determinations of whether a business experienced a “significant decline” in gross receipts or qualifies as a “recovery startup business.” Unlike those other methods of qualifying for the ERC, the suspension test is highly subjective, based on facts and circumstances, lacks a significant amount of guidance, and is subject to additional limitations. To help understand the test, it is best broken down into its core components.
The suspension test is a two-part test, applied on a quarterly basis, in which an employer must establish:
It is subject to a governmental order in effect, and
The order has more than a nominal impact on its business operations, either due to suspending them or requiring modifications to them.
For establishing that suspensions and modifications of business operations have occurred, Notice 2021-20 provides employers with safe-harbor tests, as will be discussed in more detail later. For a suspension, employers must show that
more than a nominal portion
of business operations were affected. For a modification (for example, a change made to satisfy social-distancing requirements), employers must show that the modification caused
more than a nominal effect
on business operations. It is critical to distinguish between whether a suspension or modification has occurred in order to apply the relevant safe-harbor test. Employers with one or more components of their operations suspended or modified should strive to meet the applicable safe harbor, as failure to do so increases the risk that the IRS may challenge their eligibility. In the event an employer cannot meet a safe harbor, it still may be eligible for the ERC if it can otherwise show that the governmental order impacted business operations more than nominally.
Test 1: Governmental order
The first part of the suspension test is whether the employer is subject to a relevant governmental order. Eligibility for the ERC under the suspension test requires an order, proclamation, or decree from a federal, state, or local government that limits commerce, travel, or group meetings due to COVID-19. The level of enforcement of the government order is irrelevant for these purposes. Notice 2021-20 indicates that an issuing state or local government must have jurisdiction over the employer’s operations.
Satisfactory examples of a government order include a state governor’s mandating that all nonessential businesses must close until further notice, a city mayor’s requiring all businesses to limit occupancy to 50% of legal capacity, and a local health department’s ordering all establishments to close four hours early to clean and disinfect the premises to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Critically, note that in each instance, compliance is
mandatory;
conversely, government action that does not qualify would include a government official merely encouraging diligence in maintaining social distancing or avoiding unnecessary travel or guidance issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), as compliance is voluntary.
It is highly recommended that employers save copies of the applicable governmental orders, identify the effective date ranges of the orders and the applicable language impacting the employer, and provide a robust narrative detailing the specific impacts of the order on their operations. As noted above, while an employer can still be eligible for the ERC under the suspension test if it does not meet either of the safe harbors, discussed below, that scenario demands a detailed and compelling narrative that establishes that the government order imposed more than a nominal impact on business operations.
Test 2.a: Suspension: More-than-nominal portion
The second part of the suspension test is whether the government order has more than a nominal impact on business operations. There are two available safe harbors for demonstrating this. To the extent an employer’s operations are
suspended,
the employer should utilize the more-than-nominal
portion
safe-harbor test. Under this test, the impacted portion of an employer’s operations will be deemed “more than nominal” for the quarter in which the employer is testing eligibility if either:
The gross receipts from that portion of the business make up at least 10% of the employer’s total gross receipts (both determined using the gross receipts from the same calendar quarter in 2019); or
The hours of service performed by employees in that portion of the business make up at least 10% of the employer’s total employee service hours (both determined using the service hours performed by employees in the same calendar quarter in 2019).
Example 1:
A restaurant must close (i.e., a suspension of business) its on-site dining due to a governmental order (test 1 met). The restaurant is allowed to continue sales to the public via carryout and delivery. Because it can no longer offer on-site dining, which represented 30% of the restaurant’s total gross receipts in the same quarter of 2019, a more-than-nominal portion of operations has been impacted (test 2.a met). As both parts of the suspension test are met after applying the appropriate safe harbor, the restaurant is eligible for the ERC.
Caution:
This “lookback” test considers historical information from 2019. While at face value it seems simple, the guidance is not clear on how the factors (i.e., numerator and denominator) should be considered for complex organizational structures (e.g., franchises in multiple jurisdictions with varying levels of suspension, aggregated employers with multiple separate and distinct trades or businesses, etc.). Without clearer guidance on how to utilize the safe harbor for these complex scenarios, questions remain as to how to apply the test properly.
Test 2.b: Modification: More-than-nominal effect
To the extent an employer’s operations are
modified
, the employer should utilize the more-than-nominal
effect
safe-harbor test. Under this test, a modification will have more than a nominal effect if it results in a 10% or more reduction in an employer’s ability to provide goods or services in its normal course of business.
Examples of ordered modifications that
may
result in a more-than-nominal effect (note the authors’ caution below) include:
Requiring occupancy restrictions and six-foot distancing; and
Requiring performance of services only on an appointment basis.
Examples of modifications that likely do not result in a more-than-nominal effect include:
Requiring employees and customers to wear face coverings; and
Installing plexiglass or other barriers.
Example 2:
Assume the same facts as Example 1, except three months later under a further governmental order (test 1 met), the restaurant is permitted to offer indoor dining service, subject to a 50% capacity restriction (modification). This capacity restriction results in the restaurant having to turn away customers from eating indoors, and indoor sales are down considerably compared with the normal course (25% decrease in customers served, compared with the same quarter in 2019, showing a more-than-nominal effect (test 2.b met)). As both parts of the suspension test are met after applying the appropriate safe harbor, the restaurant is eligible for the ERC.
Caution:
The mere existence of a modification, including occupancy restrictions and requiring appointments for services, is insufficient. An employer must still establish that the mandated modification had more than a nominal effect on business operations, which can be demonstrated by showing a 10% or more reduction in the employer’s ability to provide goods or services in its normal course of business. Unfortunately, Notice 2021-20 fails to provide quantifiable parameters by which this 10% reduction can be measured. As stated above, without clearer guidance, questions remain as to proper administration of the safe-harbor test.
Other considerations
There are also additional matters to consider in determining whether an employer qualifies for the ERC.
Comparable operations via telework:
Some employers found themselves subject to governmental orders closing their workplaces entirely. At face value, this may seem like a clear-cut case to establish eligibility, yet this too requires additional analysis. In these situations, the employer still must establish that it was unable to continue comparable operations via telework. Notice 2021-20 provides four factors to consider when determining whether the employer could continue comparable operations via telework:
Employer’s teleworking capabilities;
Portability of employees’ work;
Need for presence in employee’s physical workspace; and
Difficulty or delays in transitioning to telework operations.
Limitations on qualified wages:
Two often-overlooked limitations apply to the suspension test:
Limitation to the period the order was in effect:
An employer may only count as qualified wages those wages for the period that the order was in effect. For example, an employer’s operations may have been temporarily suspended for two weeks in the second quarter of 2020. Only wages pertaining to that two-week period can be treated as qualified, not all wages for the second quarter of 2020.
Limitation on trade or business:
The law and guidance appear to limit qualified wages to the specific trade or business that was suspended, and not all wages paid to all employees of the employer if the employer comprises multiple trades or businesses. Unfortunately, available guidance does not appear to contemplate this scenario, and the analysis is further complicated for employers spanning multiple jurisdictions.
Be cautious about taking aggressive positions
Where clear guidance is unavailable, ERC positions should be based on reasonable interpretations of current law and supplemental authority. The ERC was intended to provide relief to employers from the impact of COVID-19 but was not intended to be universally available. It seems clear the IRS will be examining credits claimed with intense scrutiny, as evidenced by Congress’s extending the statute of limitation for assessment of payroll tax returns on which the ERC is claimed to five years (Sec. 3134(l)) and the issuance of Treasury regulations directing erroneous ERC claims to be treated as underpayments of payroll taxes and subject to assessment (T.D. 9904). Interest and penalties can additionally be assessed on erroneously claimed credits.
Employers deciding on their ERC position should also consider the significant cumulative costs of a failure to sustain the ERC upon audit, including costs to calculate the credit, compliance costs related to amended filings for claims and subsequent amendments to repay, costs to defend the position upon audit or in court, and the actual repayment. Further, it is possible that the ERC audit might not conclude until after the statute of limitation has expired for the income tax return on which the employer appropriately did not claim deductions for wages giving rise to the credit, as required by CARES Act, Section 2301(e), and Sec. 3134(e). In this case, the employer would be unable to amend its income tax return to take the deductions, meaning it effectively paid tax on a credit it had to repay. Employers should consider these risks carefully and determine whether they are comfortable with the levels of exposure before proceeding.
Some ill-advised arguments when pursuing the ERC under the suspension test include:
The employer was following nonmandatory guidance issued by the CDC and/or the Occupational Safety and Health Administration;
The employer relied on the narrowly applicable suspended-supplier exception on account of macro-level supply chain bottlenecks (including supply shipments stuck at ports); and
There were increases in costs in order to successfully maintain pre-pandemic levels of operation.
Seek all available resources
The ERC rules are complex, and guidance, while limited, includes substantial warnings for employers that aggressively interpret the rules or fail to conduct appropriate due diligence before reporting the credit. The AICPA has many resources to help members understand the rules (see
Employee Retention Credit Guidance and Resources
). The authors recommend that you use all available resources when it comes to the ERC.

Factors Contributing to the Rent Payment Crisis
Various factors contribute to the rent payment crisis among small businesses. Some of these factors include:
1. Economic Downturn: The recent economic downturn has led to decreased consumer spending, impacting businesses’ ability to generate revenue.
2. Pandemic Aftermath: The ongoing effects of the COVID-19 pandemic have left many businesses with reduced capacity and increased operating costs.
3. Rising Rent Prices: Rent prices have continued to rise, putting further strain on small business budgets.
Real-Life Scenarios
Scenario 1: A local coffee shop has experienced a significant decline in foot traffic due to remote work and social distancing measures. This, coupled with rising rent prices, has made it increasingly difficult for the owner to cover their monthly expenses.
Scenario 2: A small retail store faced temporary closure during the pandemic. Despite reopening, the store has struggled to regain its pre-pandemic customer base, leading to lower revenue and an inability to pay rent.
Potential Solutions for Small Businesses
4. Government Assistance Programs: Small business owners can explore government-funded programs, such as low-interest loans or grants, to help cover expenses during difficult times.
5. Rent Negotiations: Businesses may be able to negotiate more favorable rent terms with their landlords, such as rent reductions or deferrals.
6. Business Model Adaptation: Small businesses can adapt their business models to fit the changing economic climate, such as pivoting to online sales or offering new services.
FAQs
What percentage of small businesses are struggling to pay rent?
41% of small businesses are currently struggling to pay rent.
What factors contribute to the rent payment crisis among small businesses?
Factors include the economic downturn, pandemic aftermath, and rising rent prices.
What solutions can help small businesses overcome rent payment difficulties?
Solutions include government assistance programs, rent negotiations, and business model adaptation.
How can small businesses access financial assistance programs?
Small businesses can apply for financial assistance programs through participating lenders or directly through the Small Business Administration.
Conclusion
In summary, the rent payment crisis among small businesses is a pressing issue that requires immediate attention. By understanding the contributing factors and exploring potential solutions, business owners can better navigate these challenging times and work towards a brighter future.

Introduction
As a seasoned graphic designer, I’ve witnessed firsthand how the visual landscape continually evolves, shaping not just aesthetics but the very core of business success. It’s more than just making things “look pretty”—it’s about strategic intent, understanding human perception, and harnessing the power of visuals to drive tangible results.
The power of graphic design lies far beyond its surface appeal. It is a strategic tool that builds brand equity, fosters user connection, and drives measurable results. As a graphic designer in today’s age, I must stay attuned to the evolving visual landscape, including the pivotal trends shaping 2025, such as
hyper-realism, font prominence, and art-directed AI tools.
This is essential for maintaining relevance and impact. These trend tools, when wielded with skill and strategic intent, allow us to communicate more effectively and shape perceptions in an overcrowded marketplace. Focusing on clear, informed, and forward-thinking design is like investing in the clarity, competitiveness, and future success of your brand.
The Role of a Graphic Designer
As a graphic designer, I am responsible for crafting visual concepts that communicate ideas and captivate audiences. By combining creativity with technical skills, I develop layouts, illustrations, and branding materials that support marketing strategies and enhance brand recognition. Whether working on digital content, print media, or visual identity systems, I ensure consistency, clarity, and aesthetic appeal in every project. My ability to transform complex ideas into compelling visuals makes me an essential part of any creative or marketing team.
The Indispensable Value of Graphic Design for Companies
I believe graphic designers offer significant value to a company by elevating brand recognition, enhancing user experience, and driving engagement that can lead to increased sales and conversions. Through strategic use of
color, typography, imagery, and layout,
I craft cohesive visual identities that resonate with target audiences. I also help streamline communication materials, support marketing initiatives, and contribute to consistent branding across all platforms. My creative expertise not only improves visual appeal but also plays a key role in shaping perception, building trust, and boosting a company’s overall competitiveness and return on investment.
Brand Identity and Recognition:
I meticulously craft visual identities that are unique, memorable, and instantly recognizable, fostering strong brand recall and loyalty.
User Experience and Innovation:
My designs prioritize intuitive navigation and engaging visuals, leading to a seamless and enjoyable user experience that drives engagement and satisfaction.
Increased Sales and Conversions:
By creating compelling visuals that communicate value and inspire action, I directly contribute to higher conversion rates and increased revenue.
Cost Efficiency and Time Savings:
A well-defined visual strategy and consistent design assets, which I develop, reduce the need for constant redesigns and inconsistencies, saving both time and resources in the long run.
Collaboration and Teamwork:
I seamlessly integrate with marketing, sales, and product development teams, ensuring that visual communication aligns with overarching business goals and objectives.
The Importance of Graphic Design Trends
From my perspective, graphic design trends are not merely fleeting fads; they are vital indicators of cultural shifts and evolving consumer psychology. By understanding and actively integrating these trends into my work, I ensure that the projects I create communicate and connect with your audience in a timely and relevant way. It’s a testament to my continuous learning and my deep engagement with how consumer interests are evolving.
As writer and activist, Toni Cade Bambara famously said, “The role of the artist is to make revolution irresistible.” In other words, graphic design trends aren’t only a sign of the times, they’re sometimes a catalyst to change themselves! I see myself as an artist in this sense, shaping visual narratives that can spark new ideas and drive progress.
Key Graphic Design Trends for 2025
Here are the graphic design trends of 2025 that I’m observing and actively incorporating into my strategic design approach:
Diversity and Inclusion:
While diversity and representation should undeniably be an industry standard and not a fleeting choice, it continues to become more of a priority amongst brands and designers. As a designer, I’m committed to pushing this forward. In graphic design, it means we’re seeing more faces and people in design. But not the standard picture-perfect models. We’re seeing more tattoos, more unique fashion and hair choices, more diversity, and more acceptance of the human body just the way it is. Woohoo!
Example: The
“Now add you” campaign by Sickdogwolfman for Moro
exemplifies designers diving into diversity unapologetically, highlighting the many looks, perspectives, and lifestyles of the beautiful people on earth. Our strengths as a society lie in our varying outlooks on life. Why not celebrate it?
AI Realism:
One of the newest graphic design trends to hit the scene, and one I’m particularly excited about, is the strategic use of
AI platforms and tools.
While this might seem counter-intuitive to some, I’m using my creative mind to art-direct AI tools and take graphic design to the next level. We’re seeing hyper-realistic visuals of storefronts, and digital art that resembles hand-drawn illustrations created by digital artists.
Reddit’s rebranding
is a prime example, being one of the first brands to embody this trend with its 3D mascot and logo symbol.
Example:
Ori, designed by Red Antler
, also leverages AI imagery and technology to create surreal visuals, demonstrating the boundless potential of this integration.
Maximum Contrast:
I’ve always believed in the power of visual impact, and maximum contrast is a trend that truly delivers. This involves using stark differences in
color, size, and even texture
to create designs that immediately grab attention and guide the viewer’s eye. Think bold, opposing colors, large-scale typography paired with delicate accents, or smooth surfaces juxtaposed with rough textures. This trend is not just about aesthetics; it’s about making a powerful statement and ensuring your message cuts through the noise.
Fonts at the Forefront:
Last year we saw experimental font trends take over graphic design. But this year, that’s changed… Just kidding! Exciting fonts are still in, but the words themselves are being used as the focal point. Sometimes the right words in the right font pack a bigger punch than all the design tricks in the book.
Example: Consider the bold and conversational take that
Slather
used for their sunscreen. The font choice elevates the word itself into a memorable brand element.
I’ve also found display fonts are taking center stage as I experiment with how far legibility boundaries can be pushed while maintaining clarity. Display fonts can vary significantly, but I predict a rise in
elongated and handwritten fonts and abstract lettering.
Note: As a responsible designer, I always exercise caution with this trend. Sacrificing legibility for cutting-edge design can backfire, and the goal is always clear communication.
Doodles and Handwriting:
In an increasingly digital world, the human touch of doodles and handwriting offers a refreshing sense of authenticity and personality. I find that incorporating these elements can make a brand feel more approachable, relatable, and unique. Whether it’s a hand-drawn illustration, a playful annotation, or a custom handwritten font, these elements can add warmth and charm that more polished designs sometimes lack.
Anti-Design:
This is where things get interesting for me. Anti-design challenges traditional notions of beauty and order, embracing
asymmetry, unconventional layouts, and even what some might perceive as “ugliness.”
It’s a rejection of overly polished and predictable aesthetics, aiming to disrupt and provoke. I see this as an opportunity to create truly unique and memorable experiences, pushing the boundaries of what’s expected and making a strong statement.
Simple Geometry:
While some trends embrace complexity, I also see a powerful resurgence in simple geometry. Clean lines, basic shapes like circles, squares, and triangles, and minimalist compositions create a sense of calm, order, and sophistication. This trend is about clarity and efficiency, using fundamental forms to communicate ideas directly and effectively. It’s a timeless approach that emphasizes strong visual hierarchy and impactful messaging.
Biophilic Design:
As we spend more time in digital spaces, there’s a growing desire for connection with nature. Biophilic design in graphic elements incorporates
natural patterns, textures, and organic forms,
often with earthy color palettes. I find that this trend can evoke a sense of tranquility, well-being, and environmental consciousness, making brands feel more grounded and harmonious. Think botanical illustrations, leaf motifs, and natural gradients.
Conclusion
By understanding and strategically applying these trends, I aim to consistently deliver designs that are not only visually compelling but also deeply impactful, driving growth and success for the brands I work with.
