Introduction
The dreaded IRS audits. It’s enough to send shivers down anyone’s spine. Images of mountains of paperwork, confusing jargon, and stern-faced agents flash before our eyes. But fear not, taxpayers! An audit doesn’t have to be a nightmare. With the right knowledge and preparation, you can navigate the process with confidence and minimize any potential stress or tax burdens. Occams Advisory is here to equip you with five essential tips to turn that audit from a monster under the bed into a manageable bump in the road.
Real Life Scenarios:
Imagine this:
You receive a notice from the IRS requesting additional information about your tax return. While initial panic is understandable, remember, audits are routine and not necessarily a sign of wrongdoing.
Another scenario:
You’ve relied heavily on a tax professional for your return. While their expertise is valuable, it’s crucial to understand potential conflicts of interest with “promoters” pushing questionable tax schemes.
FAQs
Do I need a lawyer for an IRS audit?
It depends on the complexity of the audit and your comfort level. Consider seeking legal counsel for high-stakes audits or if you feel overwhelmed.
What happens if I disagree with the IRS findings?
You have the right to appeal the outcome. Consult with a tax professional to discuss your options and initiate the appeals process.
How long does an audit typically take?
It can vary significantly depending on the scope and complexity of the audit. Simple audits might be resolved within weeks, while complex ones can take months or even longer.
Can I deduct the cost of a tax professional for an audit?
Yes, in most cases, professional fees related to IRS audits are deductible as miscellaneous itemized deductions.
What happens if I don't respond to the IRS about an audit?
Ignoring the IRS can worsen the situation. Failing to respond can lead to penalties and additional tax assessments.
5 Essential Tips:
Know Your Rights and Resources
: Before the first knock on the door, familiarize yourself with the rights and resources available to you. The IRS website is your friend, offering a wealth of information on audit procedures, taxpayer rights, and even downloadable guides. Understand what the IRS can and cannot do, and don’t hesitate to consult with a qualified tax professional if you need additional guidance.
Organization is Key
: The audit process is all about paperwork. Gather your tax returns, receipts, and any relevant communication with the IRS in a well-organized system. This not only saves you time and stress, but also demonstrates professionalism and preparedness to the IRS agent. Remember, a well-organized taxpayer is a confident taxpayer.
Honesty is the Best Policy (Sometimes)
: While the temptation to hide any potential errors or discrepancies might be strong, consider the long-term consequences. Coming clean early on, with accurate documentation, can often lead to a more favorable outcome. The IRS appreciates transparency, and proactively addressing mistakes showcases your willingness to cooperate and rectify the situation.
Build Your Case Like a Pro
: Don’t just passively accept the IRS’s findings. Research your case! Utilize the Internal Revenue Manual, case law, and tax regulations to support your claims. Prepare clear and concise responses to anticipated questions, and practice your communication skills. Remember, the clearer and more articulate you are, the better chance you have of defending your position.
Seek Professional Guidance When Needed
: Don’t be afraid to call in the cavalry! Complex audits, unfamiliar tax situations, or simply feeling overwhelmed? Consulting with a qualified tax attorney or CPA can be invaluable. They can provide expert advice, represent you during the audit, and ensure your rights are protected throughout the process. Remember, investing in professional guidance can save you time, money, and a whole lot of stress.
Beyond the Tips:
These five essential tips are just the foundation for a successful audit experience. Remember, knowledge is power, and staying informed can significantly reduce your anxiety. Stay up-to-date on tax laws and regulations, and don’t hesitate to ask questions. Occams Advisory is always here to provide you with reliable information and expert guidance.
Conclusion:
An IRS audit doesn’t have to be a terrifying experience. By equipping yourself with the right knowledge, preparation, and resources, you can navigate the process with confidence and emerge unscathed—or even with a newfound understanding of your tax obligations. Remember, Occams Advisory is your partner in audit preparedness, ready to support you every step of the way. So, take a deep breath, stay organized, and face your audit with a smile. You’ve got this!

The Impact of Technology on the Future of Finance
Jun 23 2021 |
Occams Marketing
137
0
▷
In the United States, technology-driven innovation is changing the way we offer, access, and profit from financial services and markets. Financial technology (“fintech”) companies are improving efficiency and transparency, broadening equity, access, and inclusion, reducing costs, and expanding choice and opportunities for consumers and businesses by using internet and mobile platforms, machine learning, automation, and other modern technologies to deliver financial products and services.
Though internet, mobile, and computing technologies have been spreading throughout financial markets and services for decades, COVID-19 set off significant global upheavals in 2020, accelerating these developments. Economic inequities are becoming more visible, and the desire for change is growing. Government relief efforts have been delayed as a result of distribution or technical inadequacies, highlighting the need to modernise financial infrastructure in the United States. Consumer behaviour and tastes have continued to alter in the face of a continuous public health crisis, economic instability, and unique societal limitations.
As individuals have gotten more used to digital access, fintech solutions have emerged as important tools for bridging our real and virtual activities. Consumers are now more inclined to move their money online as they earn, save, and invest for the long term, rather of physically exchanging cash with staff at checkout. Large and small businesses alike are quickly adapting to these developments by improving their digital services. Though the COVID-19 epidemic will ultimately pass, the financial environment will continue to shift as fintech solutions become more integrated into our everyday lives.
From the creation of the abacus to the gigantic supercomputers that are used to run sophisticated financial models today, technology and finance have always been inextricably linked. As a result of this combination, the fintech sector was formed, and currently the bulk of financial activity is conducted on mobile phones, allowing more individuals to access financial services.
Apart from broadening access, technology has ushered in a slew of significant changes to financial institutions throughout the world, upending whole industries in certain cases, such as
mobile investing applications
and stockbrokers. However, the fintech revolution is ongoing, and clever entrepreneurs are driving some of the most important themes that will shape the future of banking.
Protection
Security has been one of the key problems that all stakeholders have had to deal with as financial services have migrated from face-to-face to remote contacts. Ransomware payments are quickly becoming a normal operational expenditure for many businesses as cybercrime continues to increase at an alarming rate.
To address this, biometric solutions are becoming more popular as a means of obtaining the greatest levels of security possible, as biometric markers are difficult to duplicate or hack. Fingerprints have long been the gold standard, but public health concerns are driving interest in contactless biometrics identification.
Banking that is open to the public
To maintain a competitive edge, financial organisations have always guarded their client data with zeal. This has generally included restricting access to prospective rivals, but it has also frequently seen banks deny consumers complete ownership over their data. Due to increased data protection regulations that enable consumers to access and transfer their data as they choose, as well as more collaboration between fintech businesses and traditional banks, the open banking idea has experienced a comeback in recent years.
Regtech
Governments and regulatory agencies across the globe have been playing catch-up with new laws and regulations to cover each new breakthrough as fintech businesses have continued to create solutions on new technologies. Fintech businesses now have to cope with a patchwork of rules in each nation where they operate as a result of this.
Adoption of cryptocurrencies
Far from the early days when cryptocurrencies were on the outskirts, major financial services businesses began to use them in 2020. In November, PayPal stated that all U.S.-based customers will be able to purchase, store, and trade cryptocurrencies on its platform.
As the number of people who utilise cryptocurrencies grows, so will the number of businesses that accept them. Because cryptocurrencies have downsides (such as security and volatility), the market will reward firms who can supply solutions to those shortcomings.
Payments through mobile device
Cash is not extinct. Yet. However, as the world moves away from personal touch and mobile payment methods become more widely available, it is definitely on its way out. Mobile payments have become a focus in the financial services sector, from tiny startups to technology behemoths like Apple and Google.

Introduction
In the dynamic and consumer-centric business environment of today, organizations face a persistent challenge: striking a balance between profitability and customer satisfaction. Effective collections and customer service strategies are pivotal in achieving this equilibrium, not only for financial well-being but also for fostering a positive customer experience. This blog elucidates the invaluable contributions of collection and customer service departments to businesses and underscores their indispensable role in the modern economy.
Building Customer Relationships:
Customer service has transcended its traditional role of merely addressing complaints or answering inquiries. It now encompasses the cultivation of meaningful relationships with customers. Contemporary consumers anticipate personalized, empathetic, and timely interactions. When customer service teams demonstrate genuine interest in resolving issues, it not only expedites solutions but also enhances customer loyalty. In fact, a satisfactory customer service experience can transform potentially negative encounters, such as billing or collections-related matters, into opportunities for strengthening customer loyalty.
Effective Communication and Transparency:
A crucial aspect of contemporary collections is the practice of transparent and honest communication. The era of confrontational demands for payments has passed, replaced by an approach that emphasizes explaining payment options, offering flexibility where feasible, and conveying empathy. When customers feel informed and respected, they are more inclined to respond positively, even in situations where payments are overdue.
By fostering transparency in collections, businesses establish a supportive environment that encourages customers to proactively seek assistance. When customers comprehend the rationale behind collection actions and perceive options that align with their circumstances, it becomes easier for them to cooperate and find mutually agreeable solutions.
An empathetic approach to collections can yield significantly better outcomes compared to aggressive or impersonal tactics. By humanizing the collections process, teams demonstrate a company’s commitment to comprehending each customer’s unique circumstances. For instance, offering extensions or adjusting payment plans based on a customer’s individual financial situation fosters goodwill and encourages timely payments. Empathy-driven collections not only enhance collection rates but also safeguard a company’s reputation.
Leveraging Technology for Efficiency and Personalization
Technology has revolutionized both collections and customer service, enhancing efficiency and personalization. Automation streamlines processes, such as sending reminders or managing payment schedules, liberating customer service representatives to focus on complex cases that require personalized attention. Chatbots, artificial intelligence (AI), and data-driven insights enable companies to anticipate customer needs and tailor communication accordingly.
For instance, AI can analyze customer payment histories to suggest optimal times for collections or identify potential issues proactively. By integrating technology with human interaction, companies can optimize the customer experience while achieving operational efficiencies.
Driving Financial Health and Business Growth
Successful collections process directly impacts a company’s financial performance, ensuring a consistent cash flow and facilitating growth. When companies prioritize collections as an integral component of their financial strategy, they mitigate the risk of outstanding debts hindering operations. In the current economic climate, where cash flow is paramount for business resilience, collections play a pivotal role in determining a company’s financial health.
Furthermore, well-managed collections can liberate resources that can be reinvested in customer service initiatives or product development. When collections are conducted with a customer-centric approach, businesses can achieve financial stability without compromising customer relationships.
Compliance and Ethical Standards
In today’s business landscape,
stringent regulations govern debt collection and customer data protection, necessitating compliance as a paramount priority. Collections departments must ensure their practices align with legal standards, including providing transparent terms, adhering to privacy regulations, and treating customers with fairness. Compliance extends beyond legal requirements; it reflects a company’s ethical principles.
When collections and customer service teams operate within ethical and legal guidelines, they uphold the company’s reputation and contribute to a positive brand image. This commitment to ethical practices has gained increasing significance among consumers, who prioritize transparency and fairness in their interactions with businesses.
Conclusion
The Future of Collections and Customer Service: Adaptability and Innovation
As customer expectations evolve and economic conditions fluctuate, collections and customer service must remain adaptable and innovative. Embracing a proactive approach, investing in technology, and adapting to changes will ensure business resilience and competitiveness. Future trends may include the increased utilization of predictive analytics, advanced self-service options, and more collaborative approaches to managing payments.
In conclusion, collections and customer service are interconnected entities that support financial health and customer satisfaction. By prioritizing empathy, transparency, and technological advancements, companies can establish enduring relationships with their customers, foster trust, and drive sustainable growth. In today’s business environment, these two departments are not merely operational necessities; they are potent tools for creating a positive, customer-centric experience that benefits both businesses and their clients.

Introduction
The dreaded IRS audits. It’s enough to send shivers down anyone’s spine. Images of mountains of paperwork, confusing jargon, and stern-faced agents flash before our eyes. But fear not, taxpayers! An audit doesn’t have to be a nightmare. With the right knowledge and preparation, you can navigate the process with confidence and minimize any potential stress or tax burdens. Occams Advisory is here to equip you with five essential tips to turn that audit from a monster under the bed into a manageable bump in the road.
Real Life Scenarios:
Imagine this:
You receive a notice from the IRS requesting additional information about your tax return. While initial panic is understandable, remember, audits are routine and not necessarily a sign of wrongdoing.
Another scenario:
You’ve relied heavily on a tax professional for your return. While their expertise is valuable, it’s crucial to understand potential conflicts of interest with “promoters” pushing questionable tax schemes.
FAQs
Do I need a lawyer for an IRS audit?
It depends on the complexity of the audit and your comfort level. Consider seeking legal counsel for high-stakes audits or if you feel overwhelmed.
What happens if I disagree with the IRS findings?
You have the right to appeal the outcome. Consult with a tax professional to discuss your options and initiate the appeals process.
How long does an audit typically take?
It can vary significantly depending on the scope and complexity of the audit. Simple audits might be resolved within weeks, while complex ones can take months or even longer.
Can I deduct the cost of a tax professional for an audit?
Yes, in most cases, professional fees related to IRS audits are deductible as miscellaneous itemized deductions.
What happens if I don't respond to the IRS about an audit?
Ignoring the IRS can worsen the situation. Failing to respond can lead to penalties and additional tax assessments.
5 Essential Tips:
Know Your Rights and Resources
: Before the first knock on the door, familiarize yourself with the rights and resources available to you. The IRS website is your friend, offering a wealth of information on audit procedures, taxpayer rights, and even downloadable guides. Understand what the IRS can and cannot do, and don’t hesitate to consult with a qualified tax professional if you need additional guidance.
Organization is Key
: The audit process is all about paperwork. Gather your tax returns, receipts, and any relevant communication with the IRS in a well-organized system. This not only saves you time and stress, but also demonstrates professionalism and preparedness to the IRS agent. Remember, a well-organized taxpayer is a confident taxpayer.
Honesty is the Best Policy (Sometimes)
: While the temptation to hide any potential errors or discrepancies might be strong, consider the long-term consequences. Coming clean early on, with accurate documentation, can often lead to a more favorable outcome. The IRS appreciates transparency, and proactively addressing mistakes showcases your willingness to cooperate and rectify the situation.
Build Your Case Like a Pro
: Don’t just passively accept the IRS’s findings. Research your case! Utilize the Internal Revenue Manual, case law, and tax regulations to support your claims. Prepare clear and concise responses to anticipated questions, and practice your communication skills. Remember, the clearer and more articulate you are, the better chance you have of defending your position.
Seek Professional Guidance When Needed
: Don’t be afraid to call in the cavalry! Complex audits, unfamiliar tax situations, or simply feeling overwhelmed? Consulting with a qualified tax attorney or CPA can be invaluable. They can provide expert advice, represent you during the audit, and ensure your rights are protected throughout the process. Remember, investing in professional guidance can save you time, money, and a whole lot of stress.
Beyond the Tips:
These five essential tips are just the foundation for a successful audit experience. Remember, knowledge is power, and staying informed can significantly reduce your anxiety. Stay up-to-date on tax laws and regulations, and don’t hesitate to ask questions. Occams Advisory is always here to provide you with reliable information and expert guidance.
Conclusion:
An IRS audit doesn’t have to be a terrifying experience. By equipping yourself with the right knowledge, preparation, and resources, you can navigate the process with confidence and emerge unscathed—or even with a newfound understanding of your tax obligations. Remember, Occams Advisory is your partner in audit preparedness, ready to support you every step of the way. So, take a deep breath, stay organized, and face your audit with a smile. You’ve got this!

Tax Day is Coming: 19 Million Americans Needing Extensions
As Tax Day approaches, a record-breaking number of Americans have filed for tax extensions. In this blog post, we’ll explore why so many people are filing for extensions, what to do if you need to file an extension, and provide tips for filing your taxes correctly and avoiding potential penalties.
Introduction
Tax Day is the deadline for filing federal income tax returns in the United States. For the 2022 tax year, the deadline is April 18th, due to the observance of Emancipation Day. However, a record-breaking number of Americans have filed for tax extensions this year, indicating that many people are struggling to meet the deadline.
Why Are So Many Americans Filing for Extensions?
There are many reasons why someone might file for a tax extension. For example, they may need additional time to gather all the necessary documentation, or they may be experiencing financial difficulties that make it difficult to pay their taxes on time. Additionally, the pandemic has created a unique set of challenges for taxpayers, such as delays in receiving tax forms and changes to tax laws.
Real-Life Scenario #1
Let’s say a self-employed individual has experienced a significant decrease in income due to the pandemic. As a result, they are struggling to pay their taxes on time and have filed for an extension to avoid potential penalties.
Real-Life Scenario #2
Now let’s say a taxpayer has not received all their necessary tax forms due to pandemic-related delays. They may need additional time to gather all the necessary information and have filed for an extension to avoid making errors on their tax return.
What to Do if You Need to File an Extension
If you need additional time to file your taxes, you can file for an extension using Form 4868. This form must be filed by the tax deadline, which for the 2022 tax year is April 18th. Filing an extension gives you an additional six months to file your tax return, but it does not give you additional time to pay your taxes.
Tips for Filing Your Taxes Correctly
To ensure that you file your taxes correctly and avoid potential penalties, here are some tips to keep in mind:
Gather all the necessary documentation
Double-check your math and calculations
Consider hiring a tax professional for complex tax situations
Avoiding Penalties for Late Filing
Failing to file your tax return by the deadline can result in significant penalties and interest charges. If you are unable to pay your taxes on time, it’s still important to file your tax return by the deadline to avoid additional penalties. Additionally, you may be eligible for an installment agreement or an offer in compromise to help you pay your taxes over time.
Conclusion
Tax Day can be stressful, especially if you need to file for an extension. However, by taking the necessary steps to file your taxes correctly and avoid potential penalties, you can ensure a smooth tax season. If you are unsure about how to file your taxes or need help navigating the tax code, consider consulting with a tax professional.

What is the deadline for filing federal income tax returns in the US?
For the 2022 tax year, the deadline is April 18th.
What happens if I can't file my tax return by the deadline?
Failing to file your tax return by the deadline can result in significant penalties and interest charges.
Can I file for an extension to pay my taxes?
Filing an extension gives you additional time to file your tax return, but it does not give you additional time to pay your taxes.
Should I hire a tax professional to help me file my taxes?
Hiring a tax professional can be beneficial for complex tax situations or if you are unsure about how to file your taxes.

Introduction
The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly disrupted global economies, with self-employed individuals among the most vulnerable groups. The Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), enacted in March 2020, aimed to provide economic relief to various segments of the population, including self-employed individuals. One of the key provisions of the FFCRA was the introduction of refundable tax credits for self-employed individuals who were unable to work due to the pandemic. This research paper explores how these Self Employed Tax Credits (SETC) have affected the financial stability of self-employed individuals during the COVID-19 pandemic, with a focus on the role of advisory firms like Occams Advisory in facilitating access to these credits.

Several studies have highlighted the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on self-employed individuals. The SETC were designed to mitigate these adverse effects by providing financial support to those who were unable to work due to illness, quarantine, or caregiving responsibilities.

Strategies for managing audit risks associated with a pandemic
Dec 08 2020 |
Occams Marketing
111
0
As specialists in almost every industry on the planet, because of the coronavirus pandemic, auditors have experienced a tremendous interruption to their daily activities.
But the severity of the fallout of the pandemic will only begin to become apparent as communication teams prepare plans for future consumer feedback and audits for 2020 and conduct simple practises such as audit sampling.
At the AICPA ENGAGE 2020 online conference in July, Lynford Graham, CPA, Ph.D., a consultant in Short Hills, N.J., is expected to lead the 'Audit Methods for Greater Performance' and 'Audit Sampling-Not It's Rocket Science' workshops. He clarified that the lessons that auditors have learned over the years from dealing with consumers would mean very little in 2020.
"You may have to rip up this year's usual strategy and start fresh," said Graham. "You have to look at this business as it is in 2020."
Many public sector audits and certain private company audits use a control-based methodology, which Graham said depends strongly on the willingness of a customer to retain adequate financial management controls over the year. It also has the advantage of saving the inspector from having to perform a large amount of substantive research at the end of the year.
But in 2020, such a control-based approach could not be feasible.
Were those checks really in effect throughout 2020? 'Asked Graham. Perhaps they were in January; perhaps they were in December. But what about the time in the middle? Did any of those safeguards slip by the wayside when the key entities were not there and company procedures changed? ”
The possibility that the safeguards of a client will be less reliable than in previous years will also determine how the interaction team approaches its sampling of customer accounts.
"If you don't get your leverage from your controls or if fraud risks are identified, the sample size that you used for your substantive revenue test and cost tests last year may have to be raised quite significantly," Graham said.
"If the operations were continuous, you could take a random sample of the entire population, as in many previous periods, and it would give you a reply with regard to the financial statements," he said. "But you could have had very different activities this year." Certain industry lines could have begun to operate as they had during 2019 in the first couple of months of 2020, but the pandemic and lockout started a disruption with an end date that is still unknown.
"What you may want to do is stratify your sample so that the period that was abnormal is more intensively sampled," Graham said. When company gets back to normal late in the year, he said, auditors will want to more intensively sample the middle phase and look together at the start and end of the year.
The severe disruption to the economy from the pandemic threatens plunging many businesses into ruin, and private companies may pose higher risks than public companies.
Graham reported that, traditionally, auditors face the possibility of lawsuits in about 80 percent of bankruptcies because the creditors of the client may accuse them of failure to recognise the degree to which the financial condition of the client declined prior to the bankruptcy. When a customer is purchased, the purchasing company may sue the auditor if the buyer discovers any failure after the sale is closed or considers mistakes in reporting in the newly acquired company that it decides it is significantly overpaid. Since it is all but inevitable that for the rest of 2020 and maybe until 2021, an exceptionally high increase in bankruptcies will mar the corporate climate, Graham predicts that litigation targeting auditors will also rise.
"That's going to be a dramatic environmental change," he added. The unusually extreme litigation threats facing the profession, in his opinion, put an increased urgency on carefully mapping the plan for each interaction and being exceptionally diligent in collecting the records and recording the facts reviewed while carrying out simple procedures such as sampling.
"You have a very interesting year, where the traditional auditing approach and the usual risk assessment approach may not be the same," Graham said.
Graham said that the implementation of the FASB Accounting Standards Update No. 2014-09 guidelines, Income From Arrangements With Consumers (Topic 606), offers a clear indication of the complexities of auditing sampling procedures after the pandemic.
"You should not issue an opinion that you can not defend from litigation exposure and professional standards perspectives," he said. "This kind of atmosphere is going to place the auditor at risk to know where you really don't have enough evidence, with certainty of saying,' Sure. This sector is as presented at this point in the financial statements."

It takes work-and risks to create a business. Yet there are some more dangerous threats than others. Here are a few threats that should be kept in mind by any company owner.
Running an organization needs hard work that can yield client benefits, sales and happiness. Although the ultimate goal is achievement, market risk can prevent you from achieving the goals you set.
However, there are precautions you should take when it comes to risk assessment. Here are seven forms of market risk in your business that you might want to consider.
1. Economic risk
When the prices fluctuate, the economy continually adjusts. Any positive developments are beneficial for the economy, leading to a booming shopping climate, while profits can be diminished by negative incidents. To theoretically detect and brace for an economic slowdown, it is important to track shifts and patterns.
Save as much capital as possible to sustain a stable cash balance to counteract economic risk. Often, as part of a strategic strategy, work on a lean budget with reduced overhead across all economic cycles.
2. Chance for Compliance
Business owners face an abundance of rules and legislation to deal with. For instance, recent compliance with data security and payment processing may change how you approach some facets of your operation. Staying well versed in existing legislation will help mitigate enforcement risks from federal agencies such as the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as well as state and local agencies.
If you depend on all of your profits from one or two customers, if one or both no longer use your services, your financial risk may be important. To diversify your foundation, start selling your offerings so that the lack of one won't devastate your bottom line.
If you rely on all of your income from one or two clients, your financial burden can be substantial if one or more of them no longer use your services. To diversify your base, begin selling your offerings so that your bottom line will not be destroyed by the loss of one.
3. Chance to Security and Fraud
There are now greater opportunities for hacking as more clients use online and smartphone platforms to exchange personal data. News reports on data hacks, identity theft and payment fraud show how companies are raising this kind of harm.
This vulnerability not only affects trust and credibility, but a corporation is also financially responsible for any data breaches or fraud. Focus on protection solutions, intrusion prevention software and employee and consumer education on how to spot any possible vulnerabilities in order to implement successful business risk management.
4. Danger to Finance
This business risk could include credit extended to clients or the debt burden of your own business. Fluctuations of interest rates may also be a hazard.
It will help you prevent destroying cash flow or causing an unnecessary loss by making changes to your business strategy. Hold debt to a minimum and build a strategy that as soon as possible can help to lower that debt burden. If you depend on all of your profits from one or two customers, if one or both no longer use your services, your financial risk may be important. To diversify your foundation, start selling your offerings so that the lack of one won't devastate your bottom line.
5. Damage to Credibility
There has always been the possibility that an angry client, product loss, bad press or litigation will negatively affect a company's brand image. However, the pace and reach of credibility harm has been exacerbated by social media. Just one adverse tweet or negative review will minimise the follow-up of your client and cause sales to plunge.
Leverage identity management tactics to constantly track what people are thinking about the business online and offline to plan for this possibility. Be able to respond to such comments and quickly help resolve any questions. To deter litigation and product defects that can also harm the credibility of your company, keep quality top of mind.
6. Damage of operations
This market risk may arise internally, externally, or a mixture of factors could be involved. Anything that causes you to lose business continuity can happen suddenly.
A natural catastrophe or fire that affects or kills your physical company may be that unforeseen occurrence. Or, a server crash triggered by technological difficulties, entities, or power cuts may be involved. Often, certain organizational threats are people-related. An employee may make errors that cost money and time.
If it's a person or process malfunction, in terms of resources, time and credibility, these operating risks will adversely affect the business. Via preparation and a corporate continuity strategy, resolve each of these future operating threats. Both methods offer a way to learn about what could go wrong and build a contingency mechanism or preventive steps to ensure that events are not disrupted.
For starters, more organizations use cloud storage to safeguard business information and focus on remote team members to manage operations. It also tends to reduce human errors by automating further operations.
7. Damage to Competition (or Comfort)
While a company may be conscious that their market still has some competition, it's easy to lose out on what competitors deliver that may cater to your clients.
In this scenario, the market danger requires a business leader being so satisfied with their results and the status quo that they do not look at opportunities to pivot or make continuous adjustments. Increasing rivalry mixed with a lack of commitment to adapt will lead to consumer losses.
Enterprise risk management suggests that an enterprise must constantly reassess its performance, optimise its methodology, and establish good, engaging partnerships with its clients and audience. In addition, by constantly studying how they use web and social media platforms, it is important to keep an eye on the market.

While you will never be able to eradicate market risk entirely, it does help to prepare for it proactively. Knowledge is important to help you save money and time while maintaining the trust, credibility, and client base that you have worked so hard to attain.

Why Fintech startups challenge the payments market ?
Nov 13 2020 |
Occams Marketing
139

In the past, value exchanges took place between royalties, traders and commoners, all of whom used gold, silver, livestock and other physical goods to flourish and survive. That ended when the U.S. arrived in 1971. Completely separated from the gold standard, the dollar and other world monetary regimes accepted floating exchange rates.
For the past 50 years, in the face of fintech disruptions such as virtual currencies, electronic ledgers and decentralised protocols, financial institutions have developed payment networks that are partly obsolescent. Fintech founders are more attuned to the high demands of a youthful, digital crowd who with a touch of a phone button, buys products from across the world and can be shipped by Amazon in a few hours.
By being almost automatic, inexpensive and stable, frictionless networks such as distributed ledgers remove barriers to cross-border payments, remittances and data transfers. Such successful sales unlock greater economic growth and foster prosperity. In this way, new buyers can shift value with effectiveness and circumvent needless red tape.
In the payments industry, developers are developing new technologies and producing creative innovations that enable banks and customers to transact at any time, anywhere.
Settlements in Real-time
Global payment firms, unlike most businesses, must operate at the pace of now: receivers want their money immediately, and senders want to rapidly resolve matters. It's all about being frictionless, which means transferring digital money (or data) at low cost, in real time and without hassles at home or across borders.
Millennials have a mentality distinct from past generations. Instant satisfaction and immediacy was welcomed by mainstream society. Most assume that transmitting digits from a sender's electronic screen to a receiver may not be that difficult.
A next-generation payment network that makes real-time payments online and via smartphones was introduced by Japan-based Soramitsu last year. The blockchain technology of the venture is quicker, cheaper and solves development challenges such as when individuals are "unbanked." For example, in Cambodia, 78 percent of the population above 15 years of age do not have access to banking services. The app registered thousands of actual users in six months.
Project Bakong by Soramitsu helps participating banks and consumers to transact directly and more effectively through a network supervised by the central bank of Cambodia. It's the ultimate acceptance stamp. The organisation is also carrying out mobility solutions that give the unbanked population of Cambodia access to smartphone payment services.
Inoperativeness for other structures
In order to create legacy payment systems, banks have spent large amounts. Financial companies, however must now not only design structures and structures that integrate cutting-edge technologies, but also fulfil greater demands of customers. Legacy is incompatible with the networks of other banks or payment processors. When submitting and collecting orders, this leads to high rates, lengthy waits and annoyance with clients.
Tokenization
solves the interoperability problem by leveraging a common token that participants use to easily and securely pass value (or data). In the case of Soramitsu's Bakong Initiative, the network enables participants (i.e. banks) to use token transactions to transact directly. By avoiding conventional business procedures such as transition orders, liquidation and payment confirmations at a later date, this approach dramatically speeds up settlements.
In order to boost
remittances
between those nations, Cambodia, Malaysia and Thailand are also experimenting with QR scan codes. The QR codes are compliant with EMVCo and can be used to send and receive local currency denominated payments.
There are several businesses, banks, payment processors and remittance firms in the financial ecosystem. But having so influential members produces protocols, terminology and procedures that are divergent and incompatible. There is misunderstanding and red tape. And the net expense to the customer can be debilitating as each establishment charges a premium.
Fintech entrepreneurs are lowering payment obstacles, contributing to higher economic growth and new income. Innovations such as Bitcoin, cryptocurrency, tokenization and peer-to-peer networks are being looked into by digital-savvy customers. These are revolutionary innovations that demand the adaptation of a massive, entrenched ecosystem.

Introduction:
Engaging an investment banker is a critical decision for businesses involved in financial transactions. Asking the right questions ensures that you choose a trusted advisor who understands your goals and can navigate complex deals successfully. In this article, we will discuss seven key questions to ask your investment banker, covering their experience, track record, approach to valuation, and more. 7 Key Questions to Ask Your Investment Banker
Choosing the right investment banker is crucial for successful financial transactions. Whether you’re considering mergers and acquisitions, raising capital, or seeking financial advisory services, asking the right questions will help you make an informed decision and maximize your investment opportunities. In this article, we will discuss the seven key questions you should ask your investment banker.
Why Choosing the Right Investment Banker is Crucial
An investment banker plays a pivotal role in executing complex financial transactions. They provide expertise, market insights, and a network of connections that can help you achieve your financial objectives. By selecting an investment banker who aligns with your goals and understands your industry, you increase the likelihood of a successful partnership.
Key Questions to Ask Your Investment Banker
Question 1: What is Your Experience in this Industry?
Understanding your investment banker’s experience in your specific industry is essential. Ask about their track record, relevant transactions they’ve handled, and their familiarity with the challenges and opportunities in your industry.
Question 2: Can You Provide Examples of Successful Deals You’ve Closed?
Requesting examples of successful deals allows you to assess the investment banker’s capabilities and their ability to achieve favorable outcomes. Look for deals similar in scope and complexity to your own to gauge their expertise.
Question 3: How Will You Tailor the Transaction to Fit Our Objectives?
A successful investment banker will demonstrate the ability to customize their approach to meet your specific goals. Ask how they plan to align the transaction with your objectives and how they will address potential challenges or roadblocks.
Question 4: What is Your Approach to Valuation?
Valuation is a critical aspect of any financial transaction. Inquire about your investment banker’s valuation methodology, their understanding of market trends, and their ability to negotiate favorable terms that align with your financial goals.
Question 5: How Will You Assist in Due Diligence?
Due diligence is a comprehensive assessment of a target company’s financial, legal, and operational aspects. Ask how your investment banker will support you in conducting due diligence, including their ability to identify potential risks and opportunities, coordinate with other professionals, and provide valuable insights to inform your investment decisions.
Question 6: What is Your Fee Structure?
Understanding the investment banker’s fee structure is crucial to manage your financial expectations. Inquire about their fees, including any upfront costs, success-based fees, or retainer fees. Clarify the scope of services covered by the fees and ensure transparency regarding the overall cost of the engagement.
Question 7: How Will You Ensure Confidentiality and Security?
Maintaining confidentiality throughout the transaction process is of utmost importance. Ask about the investment banker’s protocols and measures to safeguard sensitive information and ensure data security. Inquire about their experience handling confidential transactions and their commitment to maintaining client privacy.
Real-Life Scenarios: Businesses Benefit from Asking the Right Questions
1. XYZ Corporation: XYZ Corporation, a technology company looking to acquire a competitor, engaged an investment banker and asked detailed questions about their experience in the tech industry, successful deals closed, and their approach to valuation. This thorough evaluation led XYZ Corporation to select an investment banker with expertise in their sector, resulting in a successful acquisition and improved market position.
2. ABC Healthcare Group: ABC Healthcare Group, a healthcare organization seeking to raise capital for expansion, interviewed multiple investment bankers and asked specific questions about their due diligence capabilities and how they would tailor the transaction to their growth objectives. By selecting an investment banker with a robust due diligence process and a customized approach, ABC Healthcare Group successfully secured the funding needed to support their expansion plans.

FAQs
Should I engage an investment banker for every financial transaction?
Engaging an investment banker depends on the complexity and significance of the transaction. While smaller transactions may not require their involvement, complex deals like mergers and acquisitions often benefit from the expertise and network that investment bankers bring.
How do I evaluate an investment banker's experience?
Evaluate an investment banker’s experience by reviewing their track record, industry-specific expertise, and the size and complexity of deals they have successfully closed. Request references from previous clients and conduct thorough due diligence before making a decision.
Can I negotiate the fee structure with an investment banker?
The fee structure is typically negotiable, and it’s important to have open and transparent discussions about fees. Discuss your expectations, the scope of services required, and consider the value and expertise that the investment banker brings to the table.
What confidentiality measures should an investment banker have in place?
An investment banker should have strict protocols to ensure confidentiality, including non-disclosure agreements, restricted access to sensitive information, and secure data storage. Inquire about their confidentiality policies and assess their reputation for maintaining client privacy.
Conclusion
In conclusion, asking the right questions when engaging an investment banker is crucial for successful financial transactions. By understanding their experience, track record, approach to valuation, and ability to tailor the transaction to your objectives, you can make informed decisions and maximize the benefits of the partnership. Remember to clarify fee structures, ensure confidentiality measures, and conduct thorough due diligence before finalizing your engagement. Consulting with an experienced investment banker can help navigate complex financial transactions and increase the likelihood of achieving your desired outcomes.

Software companies aren’t just in the business of technology; they’re in the business of creating technical solutions that help people overcome challenges in their lives, professional or personal. So logically, the technology firms that understand how to best help other people are the ones who are ultimately going to win the entrepreneurial game. For those of you looking to be the next Facebook or HubSpot, here’s five tips for leveraging your professional network.
1. Be at the Pulse of Innovation
Technology firms are by nature innovators. They are interested in new things. They are not traditionalists. The ability to interact with other companies is priceless when it comes to keeping the mill fresh with new ideas. According to Anupam Satyasheel, Chief Enterprise Officer of
Occams Advisory
, being located in an
NYC coworking space
was great for a growing firm. The ability to walk down the hall and get off on another floor and meet people was a tremendous benefit to his startup enterprise. It was educational to listen to them talk about what their companies were doing. And sometimes, he adds, “We found opportunities to tell them about what we do and how it would be relevant to their business.” In addition, Anupam benefited from the flexible approach to business and the realm of office locations that coworking spaces provide. For technology firms whose personnel needs fluctuate with the lifecycle of the product, it’s useful to have the ability to scale up or down, as human capital needs change. The best thing about flexible space is that it is available on-demand and a technology company who has immediate needs won’t have to wait a few weeks or months or go through a lease negotiation.
2. Get the Best People
Software firms live and die by the strength of their people. Getting the right lineup isn’t an easy task when your human capital needs can fluctuate so drastically from one month to the next depending on where you are in the lifecycle. In the increasingly social media-driven world of today, access to personal information is more public than ever. Add to that the convenience of working in an open-plan office center, and recruiting technology talent is easier. Anupam recalls,”If I think back to 15 or 20 years ago, I had to call a head hunter. It was a long process. These days you can go on LinkedIn or ask somebody in your coworking center and get a qualified referral within a matter of minutes or hours.” A killer strategy would be to combine your networking in a serviced
office space in NYC
with online recruiting efforts through Facebook or LinkedIn. Do this on an ongoing basis, even when you’re not in hiring mode. Continually being on the prowl for good talent, even when you’re not in the market for anyone, will provide ready access when you’re in a pinch.
3. Get feedback
What makes software bad or good is the user experience. If people don’t find that the software solves their problems then it will be of no utility to them. However, software that is intuitive, easy to navigate, and contains relevant features will be software that users gobble up. There’s no better way to gauge the user experience than getting direct feedback from a qualified peer group. Sameer Somal of
Blue Ocean Global Technology
is a proponent of being surrounded by like-minded people who are growing and investing in their businesses. “In the knowledge worker economy, that nourishes your ability to make better decisions. Instead of climbing the wrong ladder you can ask your peers.” Knowing how your product will be received by a group of potential users is at the core of whether you are going to be successful or not and a huge growth opportunity.
4. Give
Software companies are built upon relationships, and relationships are ultimately based upon what you are willing to give to other people. According to Sameer, “Like Einstein said, never strive for success; strive to be a person of value. People are smart and they remember when you’ve done more for them than they have done for you.” In any coworking situation, as yourself if you are listening to what other people are saying, and then translating that into an opportunity to give. The best networkers are givers. Reciprocity can be very strong for people who are thought of as kind and nurturing. Always listen with an ear towards how you can help someone as you will foster strong ties with your peers.
5. Use the Right Jargon
If you’re at a standstill in your networking, the words you’re using may be the culprit. For example, the question, “So, what do you do?” seems like an inevitable one in the world of business networking. And it’s ugly. According to Sameer, at the core of the question is a masked demand to explain your value. Awkward, huh? Instead, try questions such as “tell me about the role you have at your firm” or “what are you involved with?” In the same spirit, coming to an event armed with intriguing stories and useful information is a great way to prepare for the awkward silence that inevitably happens at some point when meeting someone new. Study for your networking events beforehand. The time invested will pay dividends in helping to make an uncertain process go smoother. For example, let’s say that you are going to a networking event that focuses on sustainable investing. Read an article or two on the subject, and come up with some insightful questions that potentially could relate back to your software, such as:
Did you realize that there is over 8 trillion dollars invested in sustainable strategies? I wonder how the accounting software for those investments is structured.
So what did you think of the recent Investment News series on
ESG investments
?
What do you think the next technology innovation in this space will be?
Tell me about your investment fund and what types of sustainable investments options you provide. (Research the individual participants in advance for this one)

Introduction
In the digital-first world that defines today’s marketplace, companies vie for attention, loyalty, and growth amid an environment saturated with choices. Traditional marketing and sales strategies are essential but no longer sufficient on their own. What increasingly separates the successful from the merely operational is a profound, often underestimated force: User Experience (UX).
Far from just enhancing visual appeal, UX embodies the art of creating experiences that resonate on a human level—experiences that are intuitive, seamless, and profoundly engaging. It’s about understanding and predicting the needs of the user before they are even fully articulated. This is where UX transcends its conventional boundaries and ventures into the strategic, influencing everything from customer loyalty to operational efficiency and competitive differentiation.
In this narrative, we explore not just the business value of UX, but its role as a transformative agent in the digital age, illustrated by compelling case studies from brands that have turned UX commitment into substantial profitability.
The Essential Role of UX in Shaping Business Success
Today’s consumers are equipped with more knowledge and higher expectations than ever before. They seek not just service but serendipity—not just function but delight. Their tolerance for inefficiency and poor design is minimal, and their willingness to abandon ship for a better option is high. This shift in consumer behavior makes UX not just important but indispensable.
Consider UX the silent ambassador of your brand. It communicates your values through interaction rather than proclamation. It builds trust not through promises but through every click, swipe, and tap. Where traditional marketing reaches the mind of the consumer, good UX touches their emotions, builds habits, and fosters loyalty.
Rethinking UX: Beyond Aesthetics to Core Business Strategy
To appreciate the profound impact of UX, let’s shift our focus from general benefits to specific, transformative outcomes enabled by strategic UX investments:
1.
UX as a Revenue Accelerator:
Take the case of a financial services firm that reimagined its customer onboarding journey. By simplifying the application process and reducing redundancies, the firm didn’t just enhance user satisfaction—it significantly lifted its conversion rates, demonstrating how UX improvements directly translate to the bottom line.
2.
UX as a Brand Differentiator:
Consider Amazon’s “One-Click” shopping. This feature didn’t just simplify the buying process; it redefined it, setting a new industry standard that others rushed to emulate. Amazon’s UX became its competitive moat, showcasing how innovative UX can carve out market leadership.
In-depth Case Studies: The Power of UX Done Right
Airbnb’s Turnaround with UX:
When Airbnb enhanced its platform’s UX by improving photo quality and streamlining the booking process, it didn’t just improve usability—it transformed user perception and trust, which increased booking rates and helped propel Airbnb to a market leader position.
Apple’s UX Philosophy:
Apple’s consistent focus on clean, intuitive design across its product lines isn’t just about aesthetics; it’s about creating a seamless ecosystem that users find indispensable. Apple’s UX practices have not only cultivated an intensely loyal customer base but also allowed it to command premium pricing.
To harness the full potential of UX, it must be embedded in the fabric of your business strategy
Initiate with a UX Audit:
Start by understanding where your digital touchpoints stand against user expectations and industry benchmarks.
Prioritize User-Centered Design:
Shift your design philosophy to fully empathize with and anticipate user needs.
Optimize Continuously:
UX is not a one-time project but a continuous endeavor that adapts to evolving user behaviors and technological advancements.
Measure Impact Rigorously:
Apply metrics to assess how UX enhancements influence user satisfaction, retention, and conversion.
Conclusion
UX is no longer just a part of the product development process; it is a critical business strategy that demands chief consideration. The future of your business depends on how well you can integrate and elevate the UX of your products and services. As we look ahead, UX will not just support business strategies—it will define them.

Introduction
In the world of financial and professional services, where PowerPoints reign supreme and data-heavy charts dominate, how do you stand out? How do you break through the noise of complex jargon and endless reports to truly captivate your audience?
The answer lies in
motion graphics.
These aren’t just flashy animations or decorative elements. Motion graphics are a storytelling powerhouse—a blend of design, movement, and strategy that can turn the most mundane business concepts into unforgettable visual narratives. In a world of short attention spans and endless scrolling, motion graphics aren’t just helpful—they’re
essential.
What Are Motion Graphics, really?
At their core, motion graphics are “graphics with movement.” Think of them as the digital age’s answer to breathing life into static designs.
Unlike full-blown animations with elaborate characters and story arcs, motion graphics focus on making
information move
—bringing text, illustrations, and data to life with seamless animation. Think about the sleek opening credits of a Netflix documentary or the polished explainer videos that break down abstract concepts in seconds. That’s motion graphics in action.
For B2B industries, especially financial and professional services, this dynamic medium offers a unique way to:
Simplify complexity.
Enhance engagement.
Build trust through professional design.
It’s not just design—its
communication elevated.
Why Motion Graphics Are Revolutionizing B2B Content
Gone are the days when pie charts and spreadsheets were enough to keep your audience engaged. Decision-makers today demand content that is not only
informative
but also
inspiring
. Motion graphics hit that sweet spot.
Here is why they have become indispensable for B2B industries:
1. Turning Data into Visual Stories
Financial services live and breathe data—but data alone does not tell a story. Motion graphics transform numbers, charts, and statistics into compelling narratives. Picture a bar graph gracefully growing into a skyscraper to represent revenue growth or a timeline unfolding like a road map. Suddenly, your data is not just seen—it is felt.
2. Grabbing Attention in a World of Noise
In the relentless scroll of LinkedIn and Twitter feeds, static visuals often fade into the background. Motion graphics demand attention. They use movement, bold typography, and seamless transitions to pull viewers in and hold their gaze long enough to deliver the message.
3. Simplifying Complexity
B2B industries are filled with complexity—regulations, financial models, technical jargon. Motion graphics distill these into digestible, bite-sized visuals. Instead of overwhelming your audience, you engage them with clarity.
4. Elevating Brand Presence
A polished motion graphic communicates more than just information—it signals competence and professionalism. By integrating brand colors, typography, and visual elements, motion graphics ensure every piece of content reflects your identity, leaving an impression.
5. Evoking Emotion Without Faces
Emotions drive decisions, even in B2B settings. Motion graphics evoke emotions through thoughtful design choices—color psychology, smooth animations, and strategic pacing—allowing you to connect with your audience without relying on human faces.
The AI Revolution in Motion Graphics: What’s Trending in 2025
2025 is ushering in a new era for motion graphics, driven by generative AI tools. These tools are not replacing designers but empowering them to push creative boundaries faster and smarter.

1. Faster Asset Creation
Generative AI tools produce custom assets—icons, shapes, and text boxes—tailored to your project. This eliminates repetitive tasks and frees up designers to focus on storytelling.
2. Seamless Workflow Integration
AI does not overshadow creativity; it supercharges it. Tools like Firefly integrate directly into industry staples like Photoshop, blending innovation with familiarity.
3. Inspiring Creativity
AI-generated assets can spark fresh ideas, encouraging designers to experiment with styles and concepts they might not have explored otherwise.
Even global powerhouses like Disney are leveraging AI to craft dynamic visuals. If it’s good enough for the world’s biggest storytellers, why not for your business?

Motion graphics have always had a home in creative industries, but their value in B2B—particularly in financial and professional services—is now undeniable.
Why? Because they tackle the sector’s unique challenges head-on:
Data Overload:
From financial forecasts to compliance reports, the volume of information can be overwhelming. Motion graphics simplify this, turning complexity into clarity.
Audience Fatigue:
Whether it is a client pitch or a training module, traditional formats often bore audiences. Motion graphics inject energy, keeping viewers engaged from start to finish.
Precision and Professionalism:
For industries where trust and accuracy are non-negotiable, motion graphics strike the perfect balance between creativity and professionalism.

Showcase Real-World Impact:

Educate Your Audience:

Collaborate Across Disciplines:

Closing Thoughts: Redefining the Future of B2B Communication
In an industry where precision and clarity are paramount, motion graphics offer a rare opportunity to connect with audiences in a way that’s as impactful as it is memorable.
Whether you’re explaining the intricacies of a financial forecast or pitching a bold new idea, motion graphics are your secret weapon to stand out, inspire, and lead.

Over the last 12 months IRS has released several notices and memos advising ERC aspirants to be careful about the unscrupulous practitioners in the marketplace who might be bringing unwarranted risks to their targets through aggressive marketing and incomplete disclosure. These reminders are timely cautions for uninitiated prospects walking into a trap that is likely going to cost them money, time and even reputation. Here is the link to some of these memos and notices.
https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-issues-renewed-warning-on-employee-retention-credit-claims-false-claims-generate-compliance-risk-for-people-and-businesses-claiming-credit-improperly
https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-commissioner-signals-new-phase-of-employee-retention-credit-work-with-backlog-eliminated-additional-procedures-will-be-put-in-place-to-deal-with-growing-fraud-risk
https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/employers-watch-out-for-employee-retention-credit-schemes
Occams Advisory has provided the highest level of compliant
ERC services
to more than 1,000 clients and has committed to standing behind our work. The quality of work has been appreciated and
applauded by clients, affiliates and unrelated third parties.
The continued and repeated feedback from our clients and affiliates alike is a testimony to the high standards we set and maintain all through the ERC process.
The table below helps you quantify and qualify the differences in our practices and the ones that are typically followed by providers and promoters that IRS calls ERC mills. Please understand these differences well and use them in your communication with prospects. Leveraging these you should be able to clearly distinguish Occams Advisory and its market-leading ERC services from other practitioners who might not be as compliant or transparent in their ERC services.
Warning signs to avoid include
How Occams is Different
A. Unsolicited calls or advertisements mentioning an “easy application process.”
We approach you only through your trusted partners (advisors, agents, CPA et al).
Our application process is clear and extensive, involving dozens of documents and multiple interactions.
B. Statements that the promoter or company can determine ERC eligibility within minutes.
It takes Occams team and its client’s multiple conversations and reviews to identify impacts from government mandates.
We also involve independent tax experts and attorneys to ascertain eligibility.
C. Large upfront fees to claim the credit.
Our retainers, if applicable, are small and do not even cover our out-of-pocket costs for the process.
D. Fees based on a percentage of the refund amount of Employee Retention Credit claimed. This is a similar warning sign for average taxpayers, who should always avoid a tax preparer basing their fee on the size of the refund.
Occams accepts flat fees upon completion of work.
We have accepted and are open to accepting alternate methods to estimate our fees.
E. Preparers seeking anonymity by refusing to sign the ERC return being filed by the business as well as supplying their identifying information and a tax identification number. Similar to “ghost preparers,” this limits the risk to just the taxpayer claiming the credit.
We share our names, corporate email, and telephone numbers with all our clients.
Our website has the names of all the employees who work on various client matters.
Occams employees connect with prospects and clients on social media.
F. Aggressive claims from the promoter that the business receiving the solicitation qualifies before any discussion of the group’s tax situation. In reality, the Employee Retention Credit is a complex credit that requires careful review before applying.
Occams states the eligibility rules clearly to its prospects.
We have specific guidance available on our website and through our chatbot available 24×7.
We have a high level of expertise on this complex credit and serve our clients with transparency.
How the promoters lure victims
Our Outreach and Sales Process
A. Aggressive marketing. This can be seen in countless places, including radio, television, social media, online as well as phone calls and text messages.
Although we have a social media and online presence, we connect with prospects primarily through their trusted advisors (CPA’s, wealth managers, trade associations etc.)
B. Direct mailing. Some ERC mills are sending out fake letters to taxpayers from the non-existent groups like the “Department of Employee Retention Credit.” These letters can be made to look like official IRS correspondence or an official government mailing with language urging immediate action. Some solicitations even make it look like it’s coming from the bank the business uses.
Occams does not send direct mailers.
We always identify ourselves as who we are.
There are no misleading emails / letters from us.
C. Leaving out key details. Third-party promoters of the ERC often don’t accurately explain eligibility requirements or how the credit is computed, and they do not share their workpapers with the businesses claiming the credit. They may make broad arguments suggesting that all employers are eligible without evaluating an employer’s individual circumstances.
Occams states the eligibility rules clearly to its prospects.
Occams clearly states that there are specific eligibility criteria that must be met.
We deploy market– leading expertise on this complex credit and serve our clients with transparency.
We share our work product with clients.
D. For example, only recovery startup businesses are eligible for the ERC in the fourth quarter of 2021, but promoters fail to explain this limit.
We clearly advise clients of the rules regarding which quarters an employer can be eligible for, including the recovery start-up rule.
E. Also, the promoters may not inform taxpayers that they need to reduce wage deductions claimed on their business’ federal income tax return by the amount of the Employee Retention Credit. This causes a domino effect of tax problems for the business.
We advise clients about the tax implication of ERC claims.
Our agreement states that the ERC claims will lead to the requirement of the client’s amendment of its income tax returns in the years in which ERC is claimed.
F. Paycheck Protection Program participation. In addition, many of these promoters don’t tell employers that they can’t claim the ERC on wages that were reported as payroll costs to obtain Paycheck Protection Program loan forgiveness.
We advise clients of the PPP funded wages being ineligible for ERC credits.
We do not “double dip” in our calculations when we are aware of the client taking PPP.
G. Mistaken supply chain arguments. Contrary to advice given by unscrupulous preparers, IRS legal guidance in July makes clear that supply chain disruptions do not qualify an employer for the credit unless they are due to a government order. Employers that experienced supply chain disruptions qualify for ERC only if they had to suspend their business operations because their suppliers were unable to provide critical goods or materials due to a government order that caused the supplier to suspend its operations.
We have advised clients that supply chain disruptions must be due to governmental orders.
An independent attorney will review and opine on any claims of supply chain disruption.
In the ever-evolving landscape of the
Employee Retention Credit (ERC)
program,
Occams Advisory
stands as a beacon of trust, guiding clients with transparency, diligence, and unmatched expertise. As the
IRS warns against fraudulent practitioners
, Occams Advisory fortifies its commitment to ethical and meticulous service, championing open communication and accurate guidance. Choose a partner dedicated to safeguarding your interests through informed and compliant practices. Choose wisdom, choose integrity, choose Occams Advisory for your ERC journey.

Introduction
In the high-stakes world of finance, navigating major transactions like mergers, acquisitions, or divestitures can feel like traversing a minefield. But fear not intrepid investors! Two crucial yet interconnected phases offer a sturdy bridge across this rocky terrain: financial advisory and transaction integration.
Real Life Scenarios:
Imagine this: You, a visionary entrepreneur, have identified a strategic
acquisition
that promises to propel your company to new heights. But the path to success is riddled with uncertainties. How do you ensure you’re not overpaying? Can the two entities smoothly
merge
, their cultures and systems harmonizing like a well-oiled machine? This is where Occams steps in, a seasoned guide illuminating the way.
Think of it as a comprehensive roadmap:
Strategic Pathfinders: Occams charts the course, identifying and evaluating potential deals, assessing market trends, and crafting a winning acquisition or divestiture strategy.
Financial Foresight: Occams wields the power of
financial modeling
and valuation, meticulously analyzing data to assess the target’s true worth, project potential synergies, and predict post-transaction performance.
Unveiling Hidden Gems: Through thorough due diligence – financial, legal, operational, you name it – Occams uncovers potential risks and opportunities, ensuring you make informed decisions based on a clear understanding of the landscape.
Negotiation Ninja: Occams becomes your skilled negotiator, crafting deal terms that optimize tax and financial benefits and drafting watertight transaction documents.
But the journey doesn’t end at the closing bell. Transaction integration takes the baton, ensuring a seamless post-merger life:
Integration Architects: We will craft a detailed blueprint for merging operations, systems, cultures, and people, laying the groundwork for a unified entity.
Change Champions: We navigate the delicate dance of change management, minimizing disruption and fostering employee buy-in, crucial for a smooth transition.
Operational Harmony: We orchestrate the alignment of financial reporting, systems, and processes, creating a unified entity that sings in perfect harmony.
Synergy Symphony: We identify and implement strategies to unlock the value created by the transaction, ensuring the sweet music of success resonates loud and clear.
FAQs
What sets Occams Advisory apart?
We boast a team of seasoned professionals with a proven track record of success, a holistic approach encompassing both financial advisory and transaction integration, and a deep commitment to client-centricity. We leverage cutting-edge technology and industry expertise to ensure your journey is smooth and successful.
Is financial advisory a one-size-fits-all solution?
Absolutely not! We tailor our services to your specific needs, industry, and transaction type.
How much does it cost?
The cost varies depending on the scope and complexity of your transaction. However, we believe our expertise is an investment that yields significant returns on your success.
Conclusions
In conclusion, financial advisory and transaction integration are not just buzzwords; they are the cornerstones of successful deals. With Occams Advisory by your side, you can navigate the complexities of major transactions with confidence, maximizing value and achieving your financial goals.

New Year Compatibility Mode: Aligning Your Business for Success
As the new year approaches, it’s crucial to ensure your business is aligned for success. By embracing “New Year Compatibility Mode,” you can navigate the transition seamlessly and position your business for growth. This article explores the importance of compatibility mode and provides strategies to maximize your business’s potential in the new year.
Understanding the Importance of New Year Compatibility Mode
New Year Compatibility Mode refers to the process of aligning your business with the changing dynamics and goals of the upcoming year. Here’s why it’s important:
1. Adaptation to Change: The new year brings new opportunities and challenges. Compatibility mode enables your business to adapt to market trends, evolving customer needs, and industry advancements, ensuring you stay competitive.
2. Goal Setting and Evaluation: Compatibility mode prompts a comprehensive evaluation of your business goals and strategies. It allows you to set realistic and ambitious targets for the new year and identify areas that require improvement or realignment.
Strategies for a Smooth Transition to the New Year
To maximize your business’s potential in the new year, consider implementing the following strategies as part of your compatibility mode approach:
1. Reflect and Learn: Review the performance of the previous year, analyze successes and failures, and identify valuable lessons learned. Use this reflection to inform your strategies and decision-making for the upcoming year.
2. Goal Alignment: Set clear, measurable, and time-bound goals that align with your business’s vision and mission. Break down these goals into actionable steps and assign responsibilities to ensure progress and accountability.
Real-Life Scenarios: Businesses Embracing Compatibility Mode
1. ABC Tech Solutions conducted a thorough evaluation of their products and services, identifying areas for improvement and aligning their goals with emerging technology trends. By embracing compatibility mode, they positioned themselves as a leader in the industry and experienced significant growth.
2. XYZ Retail Store analyzed customer feedback and market research to identify new product lines and refine their marketing strategies. Their compatibility mode approach helped them meet customer demands, increase sales, and enhance customer satisfaction.

FAQs
When should I start preparing for the new year in compatibility mode?
It’s recommended to start preparing for the new year in compatibility mode a few months in advance. This allows sufficient time for goal-setting, strategy development, and resource allocation.
How can I ensure a smooth transition to compatibility mode?
To ensure a smooth transition, involve key stakeholders, communicate the goals and vision for the new year, and create a detailed action plan. Assign clear responsibilities and provide resources and support to facilitate the transition process.
Is compatibility mode only relevant for large businesses?
No, compatibility mode is relevant for businesses of all sizes. Whether you’re a small startup or a well-established enterprise, aligning your business for success in the new year is essential. The principles of compatibility mode, such as adapting to change, goal-setting, and strategic planning, are applicable to businesses of any scale. It’s important to tailor the strategies and goals to your specific business needs and resources.
How can I measure the success of my compatibility mode strategies?
Success can be measured by monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) related to your business goals. These may include metrics such as revenue growth, customer acquisition, customer satisfaction, and market share. Regularly tracking and analyzing these KPIs will help evaluate the effectiveness of your compatibility mode strategies.
Conclusion
In conclusion, embracing New Year Compatibility Mode is essential for aligning your business for success in the upcoming year. By adapting to change, setting clear goals, and implementing effective strategies, you can position your business for growth and navigate the evolving market dynamics.
