Understanding R&D Tax Credit Program for Small Businesses
If you own a small business that invests in research and development, you may be eligible for tax credits through the R&D Tax Credit Program. This program is designed to encourage small businesses to innovate and grow by providing tax incentives for research and development activities. Here’s what you need to know about the R&D Tax Credit Program and how small businesses can qualify for tax credits.
What is the R&D Tax Credit Program?
The R&D Tax Credit Program is a federal tax incentive program that rewards businesses for investing in research and development activities. This credit is available to businesses of all sizes, but it’s particularly beneficial for small businesses that may not have as many resources to invest in R&D. The R&D Tax Credit Program can provide significant tax savings to businesses that qualify.
Who Qualifies for the R&D Tax Credit Program?
To qualify for the R&D Tax Credit Program, your business must engage in activities that meet certain criteria. These criteria include:
The activity must be related to developing or improving a product or process.
The activity must involve a significant amount of technical or scientific uncertainty.
The activity must involve a process of experimentation to eliminate or resolve technical uncertainty.
Eligible Activities for the R&D Tax Credit Program
There are many activities that may qualify for the R&D Tax Credit Program. Some examples include:
Developing new or improved products or processes
Creating new software or technology
Improving manufacturing processes
Developing prototypes or models
Conducting environmental testing or analysis
How to Claim the R&D Tax Credit Program
To claim the R&D Tax Credit Program, you’ll need to file Form 6765 with your tax return. You’ll need to provide documentation of your eligible activities and expenses, so it’s important to keep detailed records throughout the year. It’s also a good idea to work with a tax professional who can help you navigate the complexities of the R&D Tax Credit Program and maximize your tax savings.
Real-Life Scenarios of Small Businesses Maximizing Tax Savings
1. A small manufacturing business invested in developing a new product line. By documenting their eligible R&D activities and expenses, they were able to claim the R&D Tax Credit Program and receive a significant tax credit that helped offset their R&D costs.
2. A software development startup engaged in significant research to create a new software platform. By working with a tax professional to navigate the R&D Tax Credit Program, they were able to claim a tax credit that helped them reinvest in their business and continue to innovate.

FAQs
What expenses qualify for the R&D Tax Credit Program?
Eligible expenses may include wages paid to employees engaged in R&D activities, cost of supplies and materials used for R&D, and costs for conducting research with outside contractors.
Can businesses claim the R&D Tax Credit Program for past expenses?
Yes, businesses can claim the R&D Tax Credit Program for expenses incurred in the past. You can amend prior tax returns to claim missed tax credits.
How much can small businesses save through the R&D Tax Credit Program?
The amount of tax savings will depend on the amount of eligible R&D activities and expenses. Small businesses may be eligible to save up to 14% of their qualified R&D expenses.
Are there any limits to the amount of tax credits businesses can claim through the R&D Tax Credit Program?
There is no limit to the amount of tax credits businesses can claim through the R&D Tax Credit Program. However, the tax credit cannot be used to offset more than 50% of a business’s tax liability in a given year.

Introduction
AI is everywhere—and as Product Leads, we’re all scrambling to figure out how to make it work for our users. From drafting emails to summarizing calls and powering virtual agents, large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4o are redefining what’s possible in user experiences.
But amidst the excitement, a nagging question keeps me up at night:
Are we solving real problems—or just replacing our users?
As a Product Lead working on AI-powered experiences, I’ve seen firsthand how tempting it is to automate aggressively. Yet true product success lies not in replacing human effort, but in augmenting it—amplifying intelligence without sacrificing trust, control, or usability.
This post explores what that balance looks like—and how product managers can lead the charge in building AI that truly serves people.
The AI Boom and the LLM Temptation
LLMs like GPT-4o are incredibly capable: they can reason, translate, summarize, answer questions, and even code. With APIs readily available, PMs are under pressure to ship “AI features” fast.
But here’s the catch:
– Users often don’t trust opaque AI decisions.
– Blind automation introduces usability friction and ethical risks.
– Hallucinations and unpredictable outputs can tank user confidence.
Just because the model can do something doesn’t mean it should. And that’s where product thinking becomes critical.
The PM’s Role: Capability vs. Experience
As PMs, our job isn’t to be AI experts—it’s to make AI useful, usable, and aligned with user intent.
That means asking:
– Is this automation saving effort or creating confusion?
– Does the user understand what the AI is doing—and why?
– Can they override it, edit it, or say no?
The answers to these questions define whether your AI feature builds trust—or breaks it.
Human-Centered AI: Augment, Don’t Replace
The most impactful AI products don’t replace humans, they elevate them. They act as intelligent copilots, not autonomous drivers. Here are a few practical principles I’ve adopted:
Transparency
Explain what the AI is doing. A suggestion is more trustworthy when users know it’s a suggestion—not a command.
Example: Showing “Generated by AI” labels with “Edit” options gives users control.
Control
Let users opt in, revise, or disable automation. Avoid auto submitting or irreversible actions.
Example: Auto-drafted emails that can be reviewed, rated, or rewritten.
Context
Give users a reason to trust the AI’s output—display sources, rationale, or confidence scores.
Example: “I summarized this based on your last three meeting notes.”
Failure Modes
Design for imperfections. LLMs will hallucinate or produce irrelevant results. Build fallbacks—not just features.
Example: If a chatbot can’t answer, offer a human handoff or resource links.
LLMs Aren’t Just a Feature—They’re a Design Paradigm
Many teams treat LLMs like a plugin: “Add GPT here.” But LLMs aren’t magic—they require intentional design, tuning, and evaluation.
Here’s what I’ve learned:
Use Cases Matter
Don’t add AI for the sake of it. Focus on workflows where:
– Users hit friction (e.g., content generation, summarization)
– Knowledge is fragmented (e.g., search, support)
– Repetition can be automated (e.g., FAQs, forms)
UX Patterns That Work Well with LLMs
– “Suggest + Edit” instead of “Auto-complete everything”
– Confidence indicators or disclaimers (“AI may be incorrect”)
– Contextual memory and revisable outputs
Best Practices for PMs Working with LLMs
LLMs require a slightly different product development mindset. Here’s a playbook I follow:
– Always start with the user journey, not the model’s shiny new trick.
– Prototype relentlessly. Expect weirdness and actively seek out edge cases.
– Collaborate closely with ML/AI teams, especially around evaluation metrics.
– Design for fallback states—users should never feel abandoned.
– Collect feedback at scale—user corrections, downvotes, or skips are gold.
Closing Thought: Make the User Superhuman
Ultimately, the true promise of AI isn’t about removing the user—it’s about making them superhuman.
Whether you’re building smart assistants, AI copilots, or intelligent automations, the product goal remains the same: empower people.
Because the best AI doesn’t just work—it works with the user.
Let’s Collaborate
What principles guide your team in building human-centered AI? Share your insights in the comments or reach out directly—I’d love to learn from your experiences!
By understanding and strategically applying these trends, I aim to consistently deliver designs that are not only visually compelling but also deeply impactful, driving growth and success for the brands I work with.

Background
The U.S. national debt surpassed $36 trillion for the first time in the nation’s history on Friday, according to new data released by the Treasury Department. The United States holds the most debt out of any other country, and it continues to grow rapidly. The debt has risen a staggering 122% since 2014 alone. Writer for the Plain Bagel Richard Coffin remarks that “it doesn’t take an economist to recognize that this is a pretty alarming trend.” In perspective, if the national debt were converted to a stack of $1 bills, it would reach the moon and back five times! These alarming statistics have naturally raised concerns that the U.S. could one day default on its debt, which would send shockwaves across the global market and devastate the U.S economy. This whitepaper provides a background and overview of rising concerns over the national debt, repercussions on global markets in the case of the U.S. defaults, and proposed solutions that have been brought up to get the U.S. back on a path of sustainability from a current “fiscal train wreck.”
Rising Concerns Over Debt
While the U.S. has historically never defaulted on its debt, it has come dangerously close to hitting its debt ceiling on several occasions. The debt ceiling is a limit on the total amount of allowable outstanding federal debt and was implemented during World War I to keep the U.S. government fiscally responsible. Since then, however, it’s been raised over 100 times, most recently this January. The Treasury Department has since been taking drastic measures to keep borrowing within its limit to avert the X-date–the day on which the U.S. government is unable to meet all its obligations in full and on time.
Since the 1980’s, the national debt has risen parabolically. The last surpluses for the U.S government came during fiscal years 1998-2001, at a time when President Bill Clinton worked with a Republican-controlled Congress on a bipartisan budget deal to cut the deficit. Both Democrat and Republican administrations have added significantly to the federal deficit and debt to achieve their respective policy visions. Obama’s Affordable Care and U.S Recovery and Reinvestment Act cost hundreds of billions of dollars each. Trump’s Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, defense spending, and costly COVID relief also soared the federal debt. The average national debt every U.S. citizen owes is $100,000, showing that the debt is not just an elusive figure on a screen but a scary reality to reckon with.
Domestic/Global Impacts of a U.S Default
The domestic effects of the U.S. defaulting on debt would be catastrophic. The U.S. bond market, used as the primary form of collateral in the global financial system, would become instantly unstable as interest rates would spike on U.S. bonds, which in turn would spike general interest rates for mortgages, credit cards, loans, government bonds, etc. This would trigger a recession as businesses, particularly those with contracts with the government, would have a hard time operating. The unemployment rate would sharply increase from 3.4% to 7%. This time, unlike during the Great Depression and COVID-19, the U.S. government with inadequate cash would be unable to aid consumers and businesses. Moody projects that a U.S. default would wipe out 6 million jobs and $15 trillion in wealth. Additionally, The U.S government’s credit rating would expectedly downgrade, making it harder to borrow money from abroad. As a result, the U.S. government would be left with no choice but to heavily reduce spending through cutting key programs in military, healthcare, Social Security, etc.
A default would also send shockwaves to global markets. As the famous saying goes, “When the U.S. sneezes, the rest of the world catches a cold.” Demand for volatile U.S. treasuries would sink as panicked investors would sell off their holdings. In turn, the U.S. dollar would crash and likely be abandoned as the world reserve currency, which would hurt global financial markets reliant on the dollar. According to the researchers at The Federal Reserve, between 1999 to 2019, U.S. dollars accounted for 96% percent of trade in the U. S, 74% in Asia, and 79% in Europe. A U.S. dollar crash would trigger a global recession as prices of global stocks go down, inflationary pressures rise, and foreign countries’ export revenues fall precipitously as U.S consumers’ purchasing power erodes and they buy fewer international products.
Inception of DOGE
President-elect Donald Trump has formally announced the creation of the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, to be headed by billionaire Elon Musk and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy. DOGE’s function is to balance the budget by eliminating wasteful government spending and eliminating $2 trillion from the national debt. While it is not exactly clear how Musk and Ramaswamy plan to do this, the general idea is to improve the efficiency of the U.Sn government by removing agencies that overlap with others in function. This is intended to reduce the running cost of the government and “slash and burn bureaucracy” according to Ramaswamy. While the effectiveness of Trump’s DOGE in achieving fiscal responsibility remains to be seen, the creation of such a program marks an unprecedented step of the executive branch taking sweeping measures to address the national debt problem.
Conclusion
The critical issue that the U.S. faces is not just the current debt it has but the unsustainable path at which it is heading. The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates that it would take nearly $8 trillion of budget cuts to keep the debt from growing faster than the economy over the long term. While ideas like inflating away the debt, implementing a national sales tax, and increasing legal immigration could theoretically work, the U.S.’s most realistic option would be to reduce its deficit by balancing the budget in the long term. At least for the next two years, it is up to a Republican-controlled Congress and White House to choose how much attention to heed to this crisis. It will be interesting to see how much debt on top of $36 trillion will be added in the next 4 years and if the country will be able to keep up any longer.

Raising capital: Each investor needs to know three things
Nov 30 2020 |

110

You want a lot of information on how the investment can be spent when you are an investor being approached to provide a growing corporation with millions of dollars in cash.
There's a fairly strong understanding about how much funds they want and a sense of where they're trying to invest the dollars and provide the business with the biggest effect," says Michael Paparella, managing director at Signet Capital Advisors. "I'd guarantee 90% of the capital-raising transactions we're going to implement. But with some precision, they have not nailed it down. That is the aspect that builds confidence in the investor's eyes.
Paparella has more than 20 years of expertise in investment management, development of strategies and M&A, as well as middle-market and big cap enterprise capital raising.
"Investors want to know the purpose and use of those funds with a fair amount of precision," Paparella says. "That will help determine whether it is the type of investment that will provide an acceptable return or not."
Smart Market Dealmakers speak to Paparella in this Dealmaker Q&A about the three things any investor needs to hear before offering funding and what to think if you're leery about giving up your company's equity.
Before trying to collect money, what do businesses understand ?
When thinking about making an investment, there are three characteristics that any investor can look for. If it's a capital raising or someone seeking to sell the business, this is real.
They will evaluate the consistency, scope and breadth of the leadership team. They will analyse the company's previous financial results or the potential whether there is a fund raising for a start-up to see the company's expected financial output. The third element is the potential for growth that the business provides.
These are not only the three most important points to remember, but they are also potentially the most important ones in that order.
Investors will almost often aim to analyse the management team so they invest in the team rather than an idea or a company. Many businesses do not have a well-defined three-year growth plan, whether it is a start-up or an organisation that has been in business for decades, where they can articulate how the corporation, the markets, geographies, goods and services and consumer categories can continue to expand. It is very important to be able to nail the plan on a capital raise for a startup. It is something that brings value to the company while you are selling the company. At the end of the tunnel, it encourages investors to see the light of how the business can get from where they are now and where the investor needs to move them in the future.
How do you know the amount of money that you need ?
The quantity you need is contingent on the target. The issue with spending more than you need is that you're going to give away more resources than you need. Usually, if you don't lift enough and still require some, it's not a question. When you can make improvements, the business gets more profitable as you make progress. Therefore you're giving up less equity for the same dollar sum. If the organisation has not done as it said it will on the initial capital raising round the possible risk of not raising enough capital may become more difficult to eventually raise the capital you need. That's undoubtedly a juggling act.
It's both science and art. The science part is that you start with a three-year plan and then layer in a
financial model
that reflects the strategy to classify all the expense components and scale it for development to decide what you think the need is going to be. The art aspect of it is where you take a step back and just look at it from a gut instinct and see if it makes sense. You will decide at that point that you do not need as much as you thought, so you see in your financial model that you can probably hit a cash flow generating point in month 18 that will self-fund for the remaining 18 months everything you need. So you do not need 36 months of money.
What if it scares you for selling equity ?
You can also be profitable if you don't raise the money and may be able to accumulate the amount of financing you need steadily, making strides before you get to the point that the business will self-fund. You don't give up much equity in that situation and you remain in charge of the company. That's presumably the way to go if that's important to you. The bad part is you're not going to evolve as easily. You face potential competition that could be avoided by business speed.
You're in the market easier if you collect a lot of money upfront and you offer up any of a lot of equity for that capital. You have a greater chance of growth and a greater likelihood of being a bigger organisation than you will achieve on your own. You have more money and you have outside experience that comes from institutional investors for that capital. Personal choice and
risk aversion
really boils down to it.

Introduction
In the dynamic and often intricate world of business, taxation stands as a critical factor influencing financial performance and long-term success. For businesses operating in the United States, navigating the complexities of the tax code can be a daunting task. However, by adopting a proactive approach to tax efficiency planning, businesses can effectively manage their tax obligations, minimize their tax burden, and maximize their after-tax returns.
Tax efficiency planning involves a comprehensive assessment of a company’s financial situation, business structure, and projected growth trajectory. By carefully analyzing income, expenses, deductions, and credits, businesses can identify opportunities to reduce their tax liability and enhance their bottom line.
At Occams Advisory, we understand the complexities of tax efficiency planning and are committed to helping businesses navigate the tax maze and achieve their financial goals. Our team of experienced tax professionals provides tailored advice, helps businesses stay abreast of tax law changes, and ensures that businesses are maximizing their tax savings opportunities.
Real-Life Case Studies: Tax Efficiency in Action
To illustrate the impact of effective tax efficiency planning, let’s consider two real-life case studies:
Case Study 1: Strategic Timing of Income and Expenses
A manufacturing company historically recognized income in the fourth quarter of the year, leading to a significant tax liability. By implementing a strategy to defer income recognition to the first quarter of the following year, the company effectively reduced its tax liability for the current year. Occams’ team of experts guided the company through this strategic transition, ensuring compliance and maximizing tax savings.
Case Study 2: Maximizing Tax Deductions and Credits
A technology company was unaware of the research and development credit, which directly offset its tax liability. Occams’ tax professionals conducted a thorough analysis of the company’s research and development activities, meticulously documenting them to claim substantial tax savings. By leveraging Occams’ expertise, the company was able to significantly reduce its tax burden and increase its after-tax returns.
FAQs
How can my business structure impact my tax liability?
The legal structure of a business, such as a sole proprietorship, partnership, or corporation, can have significant tax implications. Businesses should carefully evaluate their options and choose the structure that best aligns with their financial goals and tax profile. Occams’ tax professionals can provide comprehensive guidance on selecting the optimal business structure for your specific needs.
What are some common tax deductions and credits that businesses can utilize?
Common deductions include expenses for business operations, depreciation of assets, and employee benefits. Credits, such as the research and development credit, can directly offset tax liability. Occams’ tax experts stay up to date on the latest tax laws and regulations, ensuring that you are aware of all available deductions and credits.
How can I stay informed about tax law changes?
Regularly reviewing tax updates and consulting with tax professionals can help ensure compliance and identify potential planning opportunities. Occams Advisory provides ongoing tax updates and consultations to help you stay informed and make informed decisions about your business’s tax strategies.
Conclusions: The Enduring Value of Tax Efficiency Planning
Tax efficiency planning is an ongoing process that requires continuous evaluation and adaptation to changing tax laws and business circumstances. By proactively managing their tax obligations with Occams’ expert guidance, businesses can gain a competitive advantage, enhance their financial performance, and achieve their long-term goals.

The Future Is Quiet
Introduction
In a world where everyone is shouting for attention, silence is quietly becoming the most compelling voice. This isn’t just a passing trend—it’s a profound shift in how we communicate, design, and connect. Especially in B2B industries like financial and professional services, where trust and clarity are the currency of success, the Quiet Revolution is transforming the way we engage with clients and stakeholders.
So, what makes silence such a powerful creative tool? And how can we, as leaders in design, use it to shape the future of B2B communication? Let’s explore.
Drowning in Noise: The Modern Content Problem
Picture this:
A LinkedIn feed overflowing with thought leadership posts, inboxes bombarded with sales emails, client presentations crammed with charts, graphs, and jargon. The average decision-maker sees up to
10,000 ads daily
and spends just a few seconds skimming each one before moving on.
This relentless deluge creates not only fatigue but a dangerous kind of desensitization. When everything is loud, flashy, and busy, nothing truly stands out.
Enter silence: not the absence of communication, but the deliberate act of simplifying it. Silence cuts through the chaos, offering a moment of stillness that commands attention. It’s a breath of fresh air in a room that’s been suffocating for far too long.
Silence Is More Than Absence
Silence isn’t simply about muting noise; it’s about designing moments that pause, resonate, and linger. It’s an active, deliberate choice—a commitment to prioritize clarity and connection over clutter. Here’s how silence shows up in B2B design and communication:
1. Negative Space: The Power of What’s Not There
In design, what you leave out is often as important as what you put in. Negative space (or whitespace) isn’t just “empty”—it’s the stage where your message takes the spotlight.
Think of a financial dashboard or a corporate presentation. Overcrowding it with data, charts, and explanations can overwhelm the audience. Strategic use of negative space, however, directs attention, highlights key insights, and makes complex information digestible.
2. Muted Colors: A Palette That Speaks Confidence
In industries where decisions carry weight and risks are high, loud visuals can feel jarring. A muted, intentional color palette—a mix of soft greys, earthy tones, or neutral hues—projects calm authority. It says, “We’re here to guide, not overwhelm.”
3. Auditory Stillness: The Sound of Focus
In video content, webinars, or presentations, silence can amplify what’s important. IKEA’s “Silence of Sleep” campaign, for example, used tranquil, wordless scenes to create a sense of calm. In a B2B context, imagine a product video that lets visuals and moments of quiet speak louder than words or music. Silence can give the audience space to think, reflect, and absorb your message.
Why Does Silence Work So Well?
Silence isn’t a gimmick; it’s rooted in psychology and human behavior. Here’s why it’s so powerful in the B2B space:
1. It Encourages Reflection
In B2B, you’re not selling a soda or a pair of sneakers—you’re offering solutions that impact businesses, livelihoods, and futures. These are decisions that require thought, deliberation, and trust. Silence gives your audience the breathing room to engage deeply with your message instead of skimming past it.
2. It Captures Attention
Imagine a crowded room where everyone is shouting. Then, one person speaks in a calm, measured voice—or doesn’t speak at all. Who do you notice? Silence has the paradoxical effect of cutting through the noise. It draws attention precisely because it’s unexpected and rare.
3. It Simplifies Complexity
B2B often involves explaining complex ideas—financial strategies, legal services, technological solutions. By stripping away distractions and allowing the core message to breathe, silence sharpens clarity and builds understanding. It lets your audience focus on what truly matters.
Real-World Examples of Silence in Action
1. Netflix’s Screensavers
On idle screens, Netflix displays serene, moving visuals without sound or commentary. These aren’t just placeholders—they invite curiosity and exploration. Imagine applying this principle to a B2B dashboard or report interface: data presented elegantly, with simplicity, inspiring the user to explore further.
2. Muji’s Minimalism
Muji’s no-logo, no-clutter philosophy is a masterclass in using less to say more. For B2B brands, this could mean creating presentations, reports, and marketing materials that focus on clarity and substance, rather than overwhelming design.
3. The Rise of ASMR
ASMR (Autonomous Sensory Meridian Response) ads are designed to engage the senses quietly and intimately. This trend teaches us the power of subtlety. In B2B, think of videos or presentations that use ambient sounds or moments of pause to create a sensory, memorable experience.
How to Bring Silence into Your B2B Creative Strategy
1. Design for Focus
Declutter.
Use negative space to guide the eye to what’s important—whether it’s a key insight in a financial report or a call-to-action in a marketing campaign.
2. Pause with Purpose
In storytelling, pauses are as important as words. In a webinar or video, allow moments of stillness to build anticipation or emphasize a key message. Silence can be suspenseful and thought-provoking.
3. Be Intentional with Sound
Sound doesn’t have to fill every second. The absence of sound can create contrast, focus attention, and highlight transitions. Consider using silence as a punctuation mark in your next client presentation.
The Future Is Quiet
In B2B, trust is built through clarity, authenticity, and respect for your audience’s time and attention. Silence isn’t just a creative tool; it’s a philosophy. It’s about stripping away the unnecessary to reveal what’s essential.
As leaders in design, we have a choice: we can join the noise, or we can create work that resonates. By embracing the principles of the Quiet Revolution, we not only stand out in crowded spaces but forge deeper, more meaningful connections with our clients and stakeholders.
So, the next time you’re crafting a pitch, designing a campaign, or delivering a message, ask yourself:
Where can I let silence speak?
In a world that never stops shouting, the boldest thing you can do is whisper.

Background
This July 4th, President Trump signed the “One Big Beautiful Bill Act” into law. This sweeping legislation made several tax provisions of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act permanent and included significant changes that directly benefit Qualified Small Businesses (QSBs). While it may seem like SMEs have much to gain from the legislation, they must remain vigilant about certain provisions, such as cuts to Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act, as well as rising borrowing costs driven by a $3 trillion surge in the federal deficit that could harm their bottom lines. This whitepaper provides a comprehensive overview of the benefits and challenges the OBBBA presents to SMEs, offering the insights you need to guide your business forward strategically. While the OBBBA provides momentary tax relief, SMEs must anchor their planning not in political cycles, but in long-term economic resilience. At Occams, we guide businesses to think beyond election-year economics through output-focused solutions.
"The One Big Beautiful Bill Act presents both opportunities and headwinds for small and medium enterprises. While the immediate tax benefits are welcome, our clients need to look beyond the short-term relief and build strategies that can weather policy changes and economic cycles. At Occams, we help businesses focus on what they can control, operational efficiency, cash flow
management, and sustainable growth, rather than betting their future on any single piece of legislation."
Benefits
OBBBA includes several tax relief provisions designed to ease financial and operational challenges faced by small business owners. Key benefits include:
Qualified Business Income (QBI) Deduction
A key feature of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the QBI deduction is now permanent. This allows eligible owners of pass-through businesses, such as sole proprietorships, partnerships, S corporations, and certain trusts, to deduct up to 20% of their qualified business income from taxable earnings. Making this deduction permanent provides small business owners with greater certainty in their tax planning and protection against future tax increases.
Full Deduction for R&D Expenses
Starting in 2025, businesses can deduct the full cost of domestic research and development (R&D) expenses in the year they are incurred, replacing the previous requirement to spread these deductions over five years. Small businesses with average annual gross receipts under $31 million may also apply this provision retroactively to R&D expenses incurred after December 31, 2021, allowing them to amend prior tax returns for potential refunds.
Permanent 100% Bonus Depreciation
The bill makes permanent the ability to deduct 100% of the cost of qualified property, such as machinery, equipment, vehicles, furniture, and certain interior improvements, in the year of purchase. This supports faster reinvestment and improves cash flow by reducing upfront tax liabilities.
Temporary Full Expensing for Qualified Production Property
A temporary provision permits full expensing of certain nonresidential real estate used directly in production-related activities like manufacturing. Specific rules apply regarding property acquisition and use, and leased properties or spaces not directly tied to production are excluded. Should the use of the property change within 10 years, a recapture rule will apply.
Section 179 Expensing Expansion
For tax years beginning after December 31, 2024, the bill increases both the maximum deduction limit and the phase-out threshold for Section 179 expensing. This allows businesses to immediately deduct the entire cost of eligible tangible personal property, including computers, tools, and certain vehicles, instead of depreciating those assets over several years.
Challenges
While OBBBA provides certain tax relief benefits, the bill includes several provisions small business owners cannot afford to ignore:
Increased Borrowing Costs
The bill is projected to add more than $3 trillion to the federal deficit over the next decade. As a result, inflationary pressure and interest rates are likely to rise, making it harder for small businesses to obtain affordable capital. For those already facing tight margins or relying on credit to grow, these rising borrowing costs will pose a significant obstacle.
Reductions to Healthcare Access
The legislation significantly cuts Medicaid funding and tightens eligibility criteria, which could result in many small-business owners and their workers losing healthcare coverage. In addition, the Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidies that help reduce premium costs for marketplace plans are scheduled to expire at the end of the year. These changes may lead to higher healthcare expenses, adding financial strain and complicating efforts to recruit and retain employees in a competitive labor market.
“These cuts put pressure on already strained budgets and make it harder for small businesses to recruit and retain talent in a tight labor market,” said Carolyn Rodz, co-founder and CEO of Hello Alice, an online small-business resource platform.
Reduced Funding for the CFPB
The bill also cuts the annual budget of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) by nearly half. Although often associated with consumer advocacy, the CFPB also supports small businesses by promoting transparency in financial services and combating unfair lending practices. The reduction in funding will constrain the agency’s ability to carry out its full regulatory responsibilities, leaving small-business owners more exposed to deceptive or predatory financial products. “Weakening the CFPB leaves small-business owners vulnerable to predatory lenders and scams,” said Heidi Pickman, vice president of engagement and external relations at CAMEO Network.
Conclusion
On the surface, the OBBBA includes many provisions that appear beneficial to SMEs. However, its broader effects, such as rising borrowing costs and increased healthcare expenses, could disproportionately harm small business owners who rely on affordable capital and relief from crushing healthcare costs. Although many of these changes won’t take effect immediately, it’s essential to start planning ahead.
Through services like tax strategy sessions and legislative impact analysis, Occams Advisory is committed to fortifying the foundation of your business. We don’t just respond to legislation; we anticipate and strategize around it, ensuring your business stays ahead, not just afloat. This proactive approach guarantees that, regardless of the impact of consequential legislation like OBBBA, your business remains positioned to thrive.

12 Tiny Tweaks for a Big 2025: A Leader’s Guide to Sustainable Success
By David King, Deputy CEO of Occams Advisory
As a leader in the financial advisory space, I’ve learned that big results often come from the smallest changes. In an industry where precision and strategy drive everything we do, the habits we cultivate in our personal lives directly influence our professional success. It’s not just about delivering for clients – it’s about showing up as the best version of ourselves every day.
These 12 small but powerful tweaks have shaped how I lead and perform. They’re not tied to a calendar or a checklist; they’re habits that, when implemented consistently, can transform how you work, think, and live.
Start with Energy
The foundation of a productive day is how you begin it. A healthy breakfast may seem simple, but it’s a game-changer. Fueling your body with something like Greek yogurt and berries or eggs on whole-grain toast provides the energy and clarity needed for strategic decision-making. In our industry, where mental sharpness is paramount, this is non-negotiable.
Ref:
https://www.ahealthiermichigan.org/stories/food-and-recipes/the-morning-meals-impact-on-productivity
Integrate Movement
Leadership often demands back-to-back meetings, but who says they all have to be in a boardroom? Walking meetings are an excellent way to break the monotony, boost creativity, and foster deeper connections. Some of my best ideas have come while walking with a colleague or client. It’s a reminder that movement isn’t just physical – it stimulates new ways of thinking.
Ref:
https://news.stanford.edu/stories/2014/04/walking-vs-sitting-042414
Reframe with Gratitude
The financial advisory world can be stressful, with constant demands and high-stakes decisions. Practicing daily gratitude helps keep things in perspective. Taking five minutes at the end of each day to note what went well – big or small – creates a mindset that focuses on progress over problems. Gratitude doesn’t just make you feel better; it sharpens your ability to recognize opportunities.
Ref:
https://www.happify.com/hd/the-science-behind-gratitude/
Master Focus
We live in a world of constant interruptions, and in our line of work, those distractions can derail critical thinking. Dedicate specific blocks of time each day to “deep work” by silencing notifications and prioritizing tasks that demand your best thinking. This simple practice improves efficiency and ensures you’re operating at your peak when it matters most.
Ref: Cal Newport “Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World”
Prioritize Physical Well-being
Leadership is as much physical as it is mental. Starting the day with a short stretching routine enhances circulation, reduces stress, and sets the tone for mindful movement throughout the day. In a role that often requires long hours at a desk, this small habit creates balance and clarity.
Stay Hydrated for Sharp Thinking
The demands of advisory work can lead to long hours without proper hydration. Yet, something as simple as drinking enough water significantly impacts energy levels and cognitive performance. Keeping a water bottle within reach ensures that you’re always operating with clarity, even during the most intense days.
Ref:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2908954/
Invest in Knowledge
Continuous learning is essential for leaders in a fast-evolving field like financial services. Dedicating just 10 minutes a day to reading – whether it’s a leadership book or industry analysis keeps your mind sharp and your strategies innovative. This habit not only fuels professional growth but also provides a mental pause to recharge.
Optimize Midday Fuel
In the rush of meetings and deadlines, lunch often becomes an afterthought. Preparing healthy, balanced lunches ahead of time ensures you’re not just grabbing something convenient but fueling your body and mind for sustained performance. This simple tweak also reinforces discipline and structure in a chaotic schedule.
Ref:
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.4278/0890-1171-3.2.12
Listen with Intention
Financial advisory isn’t just about offering solutions; it’s about understanding what clients and colleagues truly need. Active listening – being fully present, reflecting back what you hear, and asking thoughtful questions – builds trust and uncovers opportunities that others might miss. It’s one of the most overlooked yet transformative leadership habits.
Pause for Reflection
In a field driven by constant progress, it’s easy to move from one task to the next without pausing. Regularly taking 15 minutes to reflect on recent successes and areas for improvement enhances self-awareness and adaptability. Reflection isn’t just about looking back – it’s about refining how you move forward.
Disconnect to Reconnect
Leadership requires clarity, and sometimes that means stepping away. Setting aside one evening a week for a digital detox – no emails, no screens – allows you to reconnect with yourself, your loved ones, or even a good book. This intentional pause improves focus and fosters the mental clarity needed to make better decisions.
Celebrate Your Progress
In our industry, we often focus on the next target, the next milestone. But recognizing your achievements – both big and small – reinforces motivation and sets a positive tone for future goals. Whether it’s sharing progress with a mentor, treating yourself, or simply reflecting on your growth, celebrating wins creates a sense of fulfillment that fuels long-term success.
Why These Tweaks Matter
As the Deputy CEO of Occams Advisory, I’ve seen firsthand how small, intentional changes can elevate leadership and drive better results. These habits aren’t just about personal improvement; they’re about showing up more effectively for your clients, your team, and yourself.
Transformation doesn’t have to be overwhelming. Start with one tweak, make it part of your routine, and build from there. The compounding effect of these habits will lead to a 2025 where you’re not just thriving professionally but living with purpose and balance.
Your next step is simple: choose one habit and start today.

Brand Promotion during the Covid Outbreak
Oct 01 2020 |
Occams Marketing
141
0
In periods of crisis, advertisers can find it difficult to know where to start. People have gone into security mode in just a few short weeks, concentrating on themselves, their friends, their workers, their clients, and their neighbourhoods. This is mirrored by social media, with calls for fellow people to follow protocols for government protection. To build bridges within their neighbourhoods and cultures and unify against an unseen power, people have crossed political lines.
With social distance holding many individuals at home, we are already witnessing substantial improvements in behavioural patterns. For reliable information, customers have returned to broadcast and cable television and other premium media outlets. They also aim to download gaming software, spend still more time on social media, and watch more movies and scripted content in the way of escapism and entertainment. And we are testing the bandwidth of our homes in a predominantly pre-5 G environment between immersive working arrangements and live-streamed exercise courses, college seminars, and social engagements.
The need for physical products, meanwhile, is putting pressure on new outlets, with e-commerce growth rising to new standards. Grocery and convenience stores are the centre of basics for those who do go out, but availability is sporadic. Health and safety issues are pushing more consumers, such as using cell phones to pay at check-out without touching a screen or stylus, towards frictionless payment systems.
Any of these changes in behaviour can be intermittent, but many may be more lasting. If people step past the existing paradigm of survival, it is impossible that the impetus behind the acceptance of digital interactions will change if people are compelled to do new stuff through circumstances. During this tough moment, with so much changing very rapidly, what steps should brands take to represent and expand their client ele, minimise harm, and take care of their people?
Present with honesty and empathy
People right now feel insecure. Empathy is pivotal. For starters, many banks have moved to forgive overdraft fees, acknowledging their customers' struggles. SAP has made the Qualtrics Remote Job Pulse platform open to firms who could be moving quickly to new ways of working. In the presence of a power greater than any of us, those instances display modesty.
The complexities of the voice of the company are more responsive than ever. It would not do well with brands that use this period to be financially exploitative. Best to do as Guinness did in the St. Patrick's Day timeframe, as the brand moved its attention away from parties and pub events and leaning towards a sustainability and well-being campaign instead. We may not have all the solutions at these times, and we need to accept that. You have to be able to deliver on what you say if you make pledges, even during unpredictable periods.
Using media in areas that are more responsive
Marketers would try to create more
rapid-response operational models
internally and through organisations to pivot innovative communications rapidly as conditions shift. As the crisis progresses, access to remote output and innovative resources will become increasingly necessary. For starters, Nike quickly moved to embrace a new message: "Play inside, play for the world." And Chiquita Brands stripped Miss Chiquita from their emblem in order to facilitate social distancing and demonstrate a commitment to public safety. "I'm home now. Please do the same to defend yourself, "the caption on Instagram reads."
Beyond innovation, as the mixture of different media channels used by customers evolves increasingly, advertisers should consider changing their advertising mix. Marketers may choose to amplify their use of ad-supported premium video content and smartphone games, for example, with interactive content spiking. Similarly, considering the degree of interaction and importance, when news consumption increases as buyers jostle to keep updated, companies need not fear the adjacency. News may clearly be an area that needs more careful control of how much content tends to eliminate over-exposure to innovation, which can damage brand value.
Associate with nice the brand
In a time of crisis, people would recall brands for their acts of good, particularly if done with true heart and goodness. This might take the form of contributing to food banks, giving emergency staff free items, or continuing to pay workers while the doors of the organisation are closed. For starters, Adobe made Creative Cloud open to K-12 organisations automatically, recognising that this was a moment to offer rather than being strictly commercial. Consumers are likely to know how Ford, GE, and 3 M collaborated to repurpose production ability and bring people back to work to combat coronavirus by producing respirators and ventilators. And people admire that many alcoholic beverage firms have repurposed their alcohol processing capacities from Diageo to AB InBev to produce hand sanitizer, softening short stocks with their slogan "It's in our hands to make a difference."
To boost the brand, feel-good content that alleviates fear and encourages constructive advertising can go a long way. Companies ought to illustrate, however, that their donations are material and not for financial gain alone. Authenticity and real intent are known by customers.
Track patterns and build scenarios
In real time , regular examination of
human behavioural patterns
can assist advertisers to obtain deeper insights. To help adapt content, advertisers may want to measure opinion and usage patterns on a daily basis, carefully track the dialogue through social media channels, online forums, and e-commerce product pages to scan out openings and more rapidly recognise imminent emergencies. To power the right decisions, businesses should consider rapidly developing dashboards for this sort of data.
In order to offer insights to executives who are progressively concerned with marketing decisions, marketers may also want to explore developing deeper relations with their C-suite colleagues. Based for how long the situation lasts, the communications director can work closely with finance and management to predict multiple situations and future effects.
Adjust to new ways of operating in order to continue producing
How rapidly many firms have been able to move to remote working practises is promising. The integration of collaborative technology will include chat, file sharing, meeting and call capabilities effortlessly, allowing teams to stay linked and stay efficient. Digital happy hours are now emerging as the latest trend for the development of team morale. Partners are "pitching" remotely, recognising that for weeks to come, an in-face sales call is unlikely to occur. Leaders have to do their utmost to change every aspect of the operating model to this new paradigm, from promotion, to distribution, to operation. Out of our present frustration, new forms of creativity and even margin enhancement will arise.
How do we prepare for the future and beyond?
We are in the admit-and-adapt process of the pandemic of Covid-19. But after the disaster, we have to prepare for life as well. Marketing executives must strive strategically to make their products and consumer experiences as complete as possible, while working internally to do three things while we manage what we know:
Understand the influence of organisation instability and prepare to assess the unforeseen.
Lean into digital ways of communicating with clients and interacting with them, recognising that this is going to have enduring consequences.
Mitigate risks to the consumer experience by working through the outside-in in a practical manner.
There is, undeniably, a forced acceleration of the policy of digital change as we realise how rapidly clients and workers have adopted technologically connected journeys and experiences.
During these unpredictable and unparalleled conditions, companies must all think, work, and lead in new ways, and we will all have to learn in both faith and modesty.

Mobile Marketing: Your smartphone creates a reputation
Nov 02 2020 |
Occams Marketing
102
0
Consumers spend an average of 5 hours a day viewing videos, playing sports, browsing social media, or shopping on their mobile or tablet? That data is more important than just having a little bit of trivia. That means that for brands and companies, it's enough time every day for you to grab your audience via smartphone.
The bottom line is, if you want to raise the bottom line of your brand or boost customer loyalty, then mobile marketing MUST be included in your
online marketing plan
. If not, you're missing out on a simple chance for your audience to join.
In this post, I'm going to show you how mobile marketing is used by some of the most popular brands to draw clients and develop their business, and how you can use these same tactics to create your own brand.
What is advertisement from smartphone devices and why does it matter?
Quite simply, through apps, social media channels, and websites , mobile marketing is the promotion of a brand or business in a way that is tailored for smartphones and other mobile devices.
Although we understand that many customers spend many hours on their laptops, 59% report they spend their spare time on mobile devices, advertisers have been reluctant to respond to this technology. On average, advertisers spend just 15% of their budgets on handheld applications and the remaining 85% on desktop devices. Since smartphone ads have better penetration rates than desktops, which are around 64 percent higher than typical desktop conversions, this makes little sense.
Search engines have not, although advertisers have dropped the ball on implementing more mobile-friendly content tactics. That means mobile marketing is becoming more and more relevant for SEO as well. In 2016 , Google revealed that, based on how optimised they are for smartphones, they will begin indexing business and brand websites.
If you want to score high on Google for your brand blogs, then pages need to be posted easily, buttons (calls-to-action) need to function on touch screens, and photos need to be scaled appropriately on smaller screens, all to fit smartphone users.
Basically, if the website of your brand is not mobile optimised first to look good and perform well on a mobile device, then it will be useless for any marketing strategy you implement. If a prospective buyer clicks on a connexion on their mobile device in a social media ad, email, or text message and they are led to a mobile page that does not function well, so they will automatically click away from it and you will miss that potential transaction.
Not only does your website have to be mobile-ready, but with the mobile user interface in mind, the material for your ads still has to be developed. Content needs to be simple, easy to interpret, easy to absorb, and needs to draw the interest of someone on their phone who scrolls away easily. Your commercials have a relatively small window of time to attract and hold the customer interested.
6 Smartphone Brand Awareness Building Tactics
If the aim of your campaign is to create brand awareness, mobile marketing would be a major part of every marketing plan. Mobile-friendly outlets such as social media applications make it easier for users, whether they want, comment or share, to engage with brands, making them perfect ways to start brand awareness campaigns.
Here are a few methods you can use to create brand recognition using mobile devices.
Mobile Announcements
A perfect way to communicate with the intended audience of your company and improve retention rates is to give smartphone users text updates about coupons, deals, offers, etc. Give a text subscription on your website to your followers / customers, something along the lines of, "Enter your phone number to receive text announcements of exclusive sales, deals, or activities."
Code of QR
By manufacturing smartphone barcodes (QR codes) or electronic coupons that can be physically checked at the point of purchase while consumers visit the company in-store, many brands have achieved success. To allow them access to a sale or promotional deal, these QR codes may be emailed to the customer. Similarly, in-store QR codes that allow clients to register for a contest or special giveaway when scanned may be made available.
Mobile Marketing for Friendly Email
Email marketing
is an extremely powerful way to keep your clients or fans in touch. Make sure all links found in the email are clickable and engaging to make the email marketing more mobile-friendly. Email marketing connexions are a perfect way to transfer clients from the email to the website of your brand to better turn a client contact into a deal.
Marketing SMS
SMS Marketing is a perfect way for the brand to connect with your client directly. However, before sending messages, you must always have the customer's permission, and you must always give them the right to opt-out of receiving texts at any time.
Many big brands are already using SMS marketing, such as Amazon. Here are just a few examples of the kinds of messages that are sent with this marketing strategy by some brands:
Confirmation notices that are delivered to users with a purchase confirmation or order number (Amazon)
Package distribution status (Amazon / UPS / FedEX)
'Thank you' message for picking your brand
For certain larger brands, surveys and polling have been popular, as they give the business a deeper view of the consumer.
Appointment management and electronic alerts (car dealerships/doctors' offices)
Mobile Ads In the Game
It's possible that you or someone you meet would have a computer game on their computer. Gaming applications are so common that it is expected that by 2020 there will be 213 mobile gamers. Right today, 78% of mobile owners say they use gaming software on a regular basis and spend six and a half hours a week playing games on average.
This makes smartphone advertising an extremely powerful platform for marketing. Ads may act as pop-ups for banners, full-page image advertising, or even video advertisements that appear between loading screens. Mobile advertising in games are a perfect means of capturing a consistent viewer.
Marketing Based On Location
Location-based ads will help ensure that your mobile marketing investment is not spent on consumers who are beyond your service's regional boundaries. For example , if the company just services consumers in New York City, users in Los Angeles do not use ads.
Businesses and brands can deliver customised messages to consumers in a particular geographic region using the mobile GPS functionality. You may also set a virtual perimeter around a shop or company, and a warning is activated on their mobile device whenever a customer (who has installed your brand app) enters the area.
Many social media sites such as Facebook and Instagram offer location targeting, but not smartphone-specific (though many social media users search the applications on their mobile devices). For starters, the Facebook Pixel makes it extremely simple to target your audience with a variety of parameters.
Another useful instrument in location-based ads is
Bluetooth Beacons
. Such systems can be installed by retailers in their shops and can target the position of customers within the store and deliver advertising marketing items that are close to the location of customers within the store.
We live in an environment where users are looking, shopping, and playing on a handheld device for hours of their lives. If they wish to keep rising their brands and increasing their profits, advertisers can no longer disregard smartphone ads. If you're aiming to expand the scope of your company or are seeking to keep your social media marketing firm competitive, then it's time to start implementing mobile ads in a big way into your marketing strategy.

Introduction
Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) can be a complex and challenging process, and post-merger integration (PMI) is no exception. PMI is the process of combining two companies into a single, unified organization. It can be a daunting task, and even the most successful M&A deals can fail if PMI is not done effectively.
In the USA, PMI is particularly challenging due to the country’s diverse workforce and corporate culture. When two companies merge, their employees may have different values, work styles, and communication methods. This can lead to conflict, confusion, and a decrease in productivity.
Case Studies
Here are some case studies of PMI challenges in the USA:
The merger of AOL and Time Warner in 2001 was one of the largest M&A deals in history. However, the PMI was a disaster, and the combined company lost billions of dollars. One of the main challenges was the clash of cultures between the two companies. AOL was a fast-paced, entrepreneurial tech company, while Time Warner was a traditional media conglomerate. The two companies had different values and ways of doing business, and this led to conflict and confusion among employees. (Source: PwC, 2023 M&A Integration Survey)
The merger of Kraft Foods and Heinz in 2015 was another high-profile M&A deal. However, the PMI was also challenging. One of the main challenges was the integration of the two companies’ supply chains. Kraft and Heinz had different suppliers and distribution networks, and it took time and effort to integrate the two systems. (Source: Deloitte, Post-Merger Integration: Challenges and Opportunities)
Real Life Scenarios
Here are some real-life scenarios of PMI challenges in the USA:
A US-based tech company acquires a smaller European tech company. The two companies have different product cultures, and it is challenging to integrate the two product teams.
A US-based manufacturing company acquires a smaller Mexican manufacturing company. The two companies have different labor laws and regulations, and it is challenging to integrate the two HR departments.
A US-based healthcare company acquires a smaller US-based healthcare company. The two companies have different IT systems, and it is challenging to integrate the two systems.

FAQs
Here are some frequently asked questions about PMI challenges in the USA:
What are the most common PMI challenges in the USA?
The most common PMI challenges in the USA include:
Cultural clash
Integration of systems and processes
Communication challenges
Employee resistance
Loss of key talent
How can PMI challenges be overcome?
There are several things that companies can do to overcome PMI challenges, including:
Develop a clear and concise integration plan
Communicate the integration plan to all employees
Get buy-in from key stakeholders
Establish a cross-functional integration team
Provide training and support to employees
Monitor and measure the integration process
What are some best practices for PMI in the USA?
Some best practices for PMI in the USA include:
Start planning for integration early on
Communicate regularly with employees
Be transparent about the integration process
Respect the cultures of both companies
Be flexible and adaptable
Conclusion
PMI is a complex and challenging process, but it is essential for the success of any M&A deal. By understanding the common challenges and best practices for PMI, companies can increase their chances of success.

Introduction
In the tapestry of economic growth and innovation, small- and medium- sized businesses (SMBs) stand as pioneers, shaping the future with their creativity and economic contributions. They are fueled by innovation, but, ironically, SMBs often overlook the
Research and Development (R&D) tax credit.
Alternatively and flexibly known as the Research and Experimentation (R&E) tax credit, these financial incentives transform the way businesses grow and play a pivotal role in the evolution of processes and technologies. The history of the R&D tax credit unveils a narrative of resilience, adaptability, and empowerment for SMBs. In this blog, I walk-through a chronological exploration of this evolution and discuss why the R&D’s impact on business should not be overlooked. There is a concluding FAQ section, and, should you have any further questions or wish to explore how your SMB qualifies, please
schedule some time with me
!
Seeds of Innovation (1950s – 1970s)
The roots of the R&D tax credit are traced back to the mid-20th century when industrialized nations sought ways to foster mechanical and scientific advancement. In the post-World War II era, governments recognized the pivotal role of research and development in driving economic progress. In a worldwide sense, the United States led the way with the introduction of investment tax credits in the 1960s, laying the foundation for future incentives aimed at stimulating R&D activities among businesses. It was a prescient moment for the US government- understanding that fiscal motivators in the form of tax credits would engage forward-thinking businesses and foster a culture of creativity.
Legislation Takes Root (1980s – 1990s)
The 1980s witnessed a significant milestone with the enactment of R&D Tax Credits in the United States under the
Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 (ERTA)
. Sponsored by
Senator William Roth
and
Representative Jack Kemp,
and signed by President Reagan, the ERTA provided businesses with a clear, written financial incentive to invest in their innovation. The credit allowed companies to offset a portion of their research expenses against their tax liabilities, which encouraged inventiveness across various industries. It also included the “Discovery Rule” which delineated qualified activities. This was the dawn of the internet era: a time of risk-taking that would bear enormous fruit and would steam the United States economic engine forward on its course of ingenuity. The concept of R&D tax credits gained traction and other nations, including Canada and the United Kingdom, introduced similar tax incentives. A wave of research-driven policy swept the globe. There was one caveat about this early-version of R&D: the credit was written as a temporary measure in the ERTA. It had an expiration date of December 31, 1985. Seeing its popularity and effectiveness, R&D was temporarily extended in the
Tax Reform Act of 1986,
and again fifteen (!) more times in the years to come leaving the R&D credit in a state of fluctuation during the 1990s.
Maturation and Expansion (2000s – 2010s)
The dawn of the new millennium expedited an era of technological revolution and unprecedented inventiveness. The R&D tax credit evolved in tandem with these advancements, adapting to the definition of what research and development meant to businesses. In 2001, a major change to the R&D credit was made to definition of the “Discovery Rule.” Instead of qualified activities defined as “new to the world,” the new definition simply stated they be “new to the taxpayer.” Further flexibility was reflected when
Alternative Simplified Credit (ASC)
was enacted, allowing businesses to both alter and be more flexible in credit calculations. Governments recognized the diverse nature of innovation and expanded the scope of eligible activities beyond traditional scientific research to include areas such as software development, engineering, and experimental design. This broadened category definition enabled a wider array of businesses, especially SMBs, to benefit from these incentives and nurtured a culture of entrepreneurship.
R&D is Enshrined (2010s – Present)
As the world economy grew more and more competitive, the importance of R&D tax credit policies became evident. It was time to stop kicking the can and enshrine the R&D tax credit as a permanent part of US growth. The
Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act (PATH ACT) of 2015
did exactly that, making the R&D tax credit a permanent fixture in US tax code. It also turned off what is known as Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT), which allowed businesses with $50 million or less in gross receipts to claim. The 2010s also saw the
Tax Cuts and Jobs Act
(2018) make R&D credits more achievable by further reducing AMT guidelines for S-corps and C-corps. By this time, the definition of innovation had grown from simply “manufacturing advances” to a mature version that covered hours of labor, both in-house and outsourced (within US borders), spent engaging with complex modern problems such as climate change, alternative energies, and artificial intelligence. The foundation of the R&D credit remained the same but modern economic houses were built very differently.
The journey of the Research and Development Tax Credit from its humble beginnings in the ERTA of 1981 to its current permanent status is a testament to the resilience of businesses and the adaptability of United States economic policies. For today’s SMBs, these incentives are a beacon of support that empower leaders to dream, explore, and engage without the burden of excessive financial constraints. It is now evident that R&D tax credits do not simply shape industries- they nurture the very essence of progress and creativity. These incentives will continue to pave the way for a future where small- and medium-sized businesses play a leading role in shaping the world of tomorrow. FAQs
Is the Research and Experimentation (R&D) tax credit permanent?
Yes, though it began as a temporary measure in the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, it was first extended by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, extended 15 more times thereafter, and officially made permanent at the end of 2015 in the Protecting Americans from Tax Hikes Act (PATH Act)
What are the benefits of the R&D tax credit?
The R&D tax credit is critical for businesses to maintain an edge on their competition by optimizing efficiency and maximizing the amount of buckets where funds are available.
Why was the R&D tax credit created?
To foster innovation amongst United States businesses and to keep up with the rapidly evolving economic landscape of the 1980s-on.
Does my business qualify for the R&D tax credit?
Potentially, depending on a litany of different criteria.

Streamlining Tasks to Increase Productivity
Every day, you probably use thousands of business processes.
When you produce a report, settle a consumer query, contact a new client, or manufacture a new product, for example, you can repeat the same steps.
You've also seen the effects of dysfunctional systems as well. Customers who are dissatisfied, stressed colleagues, missing deadlines, and higher costs are just a few of the issues that ineffective systems can cause.
That is why, while systems aren't running well, it's important to change them. We'll look at how you can do that in this post.
Concerning Business Processes
Formal and informal processes are also possible. Formal methods, also called protocols, are well-documented and follow a set of steps.
You may have processes in place for collecting and filing invoices, or for forming new client partnerships, for example. When there are safety, legal, or financial reasons to take such steps, formal processes are especially necessary.
Informal systems are most likely to be those that you've devised on your own and haven't recorded. You might have your own collection of procedures for noting meeting actions, doing market analysis, or sharing new leads, for example.
Efficient Processes are Critical
Both of these processes share one thing in common: they're all built to make it easier for you and your colleagues to work together.
There are less mistakes and delays as everybody takes a well-tested sequence of steps, there is less duplication of work, and employees and consumers are happier.
Processes that don't perform will cause a slew of issues. Get the same scenario:
Customers may express dissatisfaction with product quality or service.
Colleagues became irritated.
Work may be duplicated or not completed at all.
Costs are rising.
Resources are being squandered.
You can experience bottlenecks, causing you to miss deadlines.
Improving the Processes of The Team
It might be time to check and amend the appropriate procedure if you run into any of the issues mentioned above. To do so, follow these steps:
Step 1: Build a Process Map
If you've determined which method you want to change, use a Flowchart or a Swim Lane Diagram to log each move. These techniques physically depict the phases in the procedure. (Swim lane diagrams are more complicated than flowcharts, but they're ideal for systems involving several individuals or groups.)
It's crucial to go through each phase thoroughly and certain systems can have sub-steps that you're not aware of. To guarantee that you don't miss something important, talk to people who use the process on a daily basis.
Step 2: Examine the Procedure
Investigate the process's issues using the flow map or swim lane diagram. Think of the following issues:
Where do members of the staff or clients get irritated?
Any of the following steps results in a bottleneck?
Where do prices rise and/or quality falls?
Which of these steps takes the longest or results in the most delays?
To map the issue back to its source, use Root Cause Analysis, Cause and Effect Analysis, or The 5 Whys. Over all, if only the signs are addressed, the issues will persist.
Speak with others that will be impacted by the operation. What do they think the problem is? What ideas do they have for making things better?
Then take a look at the other teams in your business. What strategies have they devised to deal with problems like this?
Step 3: Redesign the Methodology
You'll now redesign the procedure to remove the issues you've discovered.
It is preferable to collaborate with others who are personally engaged in the process. Their insights can expose novel ways, and if they're interested early in the process, they're more likely to embrace reform.
To begin, ensure that everyone knows what the process is supposed to accomplish. Then think about how you should deal with the issues you found in Step 2. (Brainstorming can help here). Make a list of everyone's suggestions for reform, regardless of the cost.
Then, imagine how the team's proposals can apply and a real-world situation to limit your range of alternative alternatives.
To fully comprehend the full results of your team's thoughts, begin by doing an Impact Analysis. Then, inside the revamped method, conduct a Risk Analysis and a Failure Mode and Effects Analysis to identify potential threats and failure points. You may also want to include Customer Experience Mapping at this time, depending on your organization's emphasis.
These assessments will assist you in fully comprehending the implications of each proposed proposal, allowing you to make the best choice for all.
Create new diagrams to chart each move until you and your team have agreed on a process.
Step 4: Obtain Resources
You must now procure the funding necessary to enforce the new procedure. Have a list of all you'll need to complete this task.
Senior management or colleagues from other agencies, such as IT or HR, may be able to help. Communicate with each of both organizations to ensure that they are aware of how the new method will help the company as a whole. To explain this, you will need to plan a business case.
Step 5: Put Change in Place and Communicate It
Changing internal structures, staff, or procedures is likely to be part of optimizing the business operation. You may need to purchase new software, add a new staff member, or arrange training for coworkers, for example.
It's possible that implementing the new method would be a project in and of itself, so schedule and handle it carefully. Set aside time to deal with teething issues, and consider doing a pilot first to rule out any future issues.
Remember that transition isn't always easy. People may be resistant to change, particularly if it requires a procedure they've been doing for a long time. To conquer aversion to change, you can use methods like the Change Curve and
Kotter's 8-Step Change Model
.
Step 6: Evaluate the Procedure
Only a few aspects perform flawlessly right out of the gate. So, once you've launched the new method, keep a close eye on how things are going in the weeks and months ahead to make sure it's working as planned. This tracking will also allow you to address issues when they arise.
Make it a point and ask everyone interested with the latest phase how it's going and what frustrations they're having, if any.
Adopt
Kaizen-style performance management methods
. Small tweaks made on a daily basis would keep the process relevant and effective.
