What is corporate risk?
Business risk is a business or organization's vulnerability to factor(s) that can decrease its profitability or cause it to collapse. Anything that undermines the ability of a company to fulfil its financial targets is called a business risk. To build market risk, there are several variables that can collide. It is often the top leadership or management of an organisation that causes circumstances where a company might be subject to a higher degree of risk.
The source of risk, however, is often external to a business. Because of this, it is difficult for a business to defend itself fully from harm. There are, however, ways of minimising the overall risks involved with running a business; most organisations achieve this by implementing a risk management approach.
Main Takeaways
Any exposure a corporation or company has to factor(s) that can lower its earnings or cause it to go bankrupt is a business risk.
Business risk sources are diverse, but they can vary from changes in consumer taste and demand, the state of the economy as a whole, and the rules and regulations of the government.
While businesses will not be able to eliminate business risk entirely, they may take measures to minimise its effects, including designing a strategic risk strategy.
Business Risk Understanding
When a company faces a high degree of business risk, it can compromise its ability to offer sufficient returns to investors and stakeholders. For example, a company's CEO may make certain choices that impact its earnings, or in the future, the CEO may not correctly predict certain events, allowing the company to suffer losses or collapse.
A variety of different factors impact market risk, including:
Consumer expectations, consumption, and quantities of sales
Price per-unit and cost of input
The Rivalry
The general climate of the economy
Regulations of the Government
A company with a higher amount of business risk may decide to follow a
lower leverage ratio
capital structure to ensure that it can satisfy its financial obligations at all times. With a low leverage ratio, the company will not be able to pay its debt as sales decline (and this may lead to bankruptcy). On the other hand, a corporation with a low leverage ratio enjoys larger earnings as sales grow and is able to keep up with its commitments.
Analysts use four basic equations to quantify risk: commitment margin, leverage effect of activities, financial leverage effect, and overall leverage effect. Analysts should integrate mathematical techniques for more complicated calculations. Usually, market risk arises in one of four ways: competitive risk,
risk of compliance
, organisational risk, and risk of credibility.
Company Risk Forms
The Strategic Risk
Strategic risk happens when an organisation does not work according to its business model or strategy. If an organisation does not perform according to its business model, its plan becomes less effective over time and it will fail to meet its established goals. For instance, if Walmart strategically places itself as a low-cost supplier and Aim tries to undercut the costs of Walmart, Walmart becomes a competitive danger.
Chance for Compliance
Compliance risk is referred to as the second category of market risk. Compliance risk exists mainly in heavily regulated markets and sectors. In the wine industry, for example, there is a three-tier delivery structure that allows wholesalers to distribute wine to a store in the U.S. (who then sells it to consumers). This scheme prevents wineries in some states from exporting their goods directly to retail stores.
There are, however, many U.S. states that do not have this sort of logistics system; there is a chance of compliance where a brand fails to recognise the particular specifications of the state in which it resides. A brand avoids being non-compliant with state-specific delivery regulations in this case.
Chance of service
Operational risk is the third kind of market risk. This danger emerges from inside the organisation, especially when a company's day-to-day practises do not function. In 2012, for example, the international bank HSBC faced a high degree of operating risk and received a substantial fine from the U.S. as a result. Department of Justice because it was unable to adequately combat money smuggling in Mexico through the own anti-money laundering operations unit.
Damage to credibility
Any time the credibility of a company is destroyed, either by an incident that was the product of a prior market risk or by a new event, it runs the risk of losing clients and suffering from its brand loyalty. In the wake of the fine it was imposed for weak anti-money laundering activities, HSBC's image faltered.
Unique Reflections
It is not possible to eliminate market risk entirely because it is volatile. There are, however, many techniques employed by firms to reduce the effect of all forms of organisation risk, including financial, compliance, organisational, and reputational risk.
The first move that brands usually take is to define in their business strategy all sources of risk. These are not only global threats, but can also come from within the enterprise itself. It is important to take steps to reduce the threats as soon as they show themselves. In order to cope with any identifiable threats before they become too big, management can come up with a strategy.
When a company's management has formulated a strategy to deal with the risk, it is important that they take the additional step of recording everything in case the same scenario happens again. Business risk, after all, is not static; over the business cycle, it continues to repeat itself.
Finally, a risk control approach is implemented by most firms. This can be done either before or after the organisation launches operations and suffers a failure. Ideally, a risk control plan would allow the business to be more positioned when they present themselves to cope with risks. In the event that danger poses itself, the proposal may have checked concepts and processes in place.

In the competitive world of business, tax and operational efficiency play pivotal roles in ensuring success. By strategically structuring their business and streamlining operational processes, companies can significantly reduce their tax liabilities and enhance profitability. The U.S. offers a plethora of business structures, each with distinct tax implications. It’s imperative to select the right one tailored to your unique needs and objectives.
Real-Life Scenarios
Scenario 1: Market Expansion
John, a budding entrepreneur, has been running his business as a sole proprietorship. This has led him to pay taxes at his highest individual rate, and he’s also personally accountable for business debts.

Occams, with its expertise in capital markets and investment banking, can guide John in selecting an apt business structure, ensuring tax efficiency.

A tech startup, with multiple founders, is contemplating forming an LLC. They’re aware that LLCs can provide tax benefits and protect personal assets from business liabilities.

Occams can assist this startup in not only forming their LLC but also in aligning their tax structure optimally. Additionally, with insights into capital markets and investment banking, they can offer strategies to boost operational efficiency.
Importance of Business Structure
Every business, based on its size, nature, and goals, requires a suitable structure. Whether it’s a sole proprietorship, partnership, LLC, or corporation, each has its tax nuances.
Enhancing Operational Efficiency
Operational efficiency can be the difference between success and stagnation. Automation, streamlined workflows, outsourcing, and technological investments are some strategies businesses can adopt.
Tax-Efficient Exit Strategies

What are the primary business structures in the U.S.?
The U.S. primarily has sole proprietorships, partnerships, LLCs, and corporations.

Automation, workflow streamlining, outsourcing non-core tasks, and technology investments can significantly boost efficiency.

One such incentive is the R&D Tax Credit, a powerful tool designed to support companies engaged in the development of new or improved products, processes, or software.
At Occams Advisory, we understand the critical role financial planning and resource optimization play in the success of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs). Here is a comprehensive look at how software development firms can maximize their benefits from the R&D Tax Credit.
Understanding the R&D Tax Credit
The R&D Tax Credit, established under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §41, provides a significant tax incentive for companies that engage in qualifying research activities. These activities must meet the following criteria:
1.
Permitted Purpose:
The research must be intended to develop new or improved functionality, performance, reliability, or quality.
2.
Elimination of Uncertainty:
The company must demonstrate that it faced uncertainty at the outset of the project and sought to eliminate it through the research.
3.
Process of Experimentation:
The research must involve a process of experimentation to resolve the technical uncertainties.
4.
Technological in Nature:
The research must rely on principles of physical or biological sciences, engineering, or computer science.
Qualifying Activities for Software Development Firms
For software development firms, a wide range of activities can qualify for the R&D Tax Credit. These include, but are not limited to:
Developing new software applications
Enhancing existing software products
Creating software prototypes
Testing and debugging software
Integrating innovative technologies into existing software
Conducting performance and scalability testing
Financial Impact and Benefits
The financial benefits of the R&D Tax Credit can be substantial. Companies can claim up to 20% of their qualified research expenses (QREs) as a credit against their federal tax liability. QREs typically include wages for employees directly involved in R&D, costs of supplies used in the research, and a portion of contract research expenses.
Additionally, the credit can often be carried forward for up to 20 years, allowing companies to utilize it in future profitable years if they cannot fully use it in the year the expenses are incurred.
Best Practices for Maximizing the Credit
To fully leverage the R&D Tax Credit, software development firms should adopt the following best practices:
1.
Maintain Detailed Documentation:
Keep comprehensive records of all R&D activities, including project plans, time tracking, and detailed descriptions of the technical challenges and solutions.
2.
Allocate Costs Accurately:
Ensure that all QREs are correctly identified and allocated to qualifying projects. This may involve working closely with your financial and technical teams to capture all relevant costs.
3.
Engage Experts:
Consider working with tax professionals who specialize in R&D credits. They can help identify qualifying activities, maximize your credit, and ensure compliance with IRS requirements.
Conclusion
The R&D Tax Credit offers software development firms a valuable opportunity to offset the costs of innovation and drive growth. By understanding the qualifying activities, maintaining detailed documentation, and seeking expert advice, companies can maximize their benefits and continue to push the boundaries of technology.

How to Improve Your Digital Media Efforts | Digital Marketing Trends 2022
Digital media has become a powerful tool for businesses to reach their target audience and drive growth. Staying updated with the latest digital marketing trends is crucial for maximizing the effectiveness of your digital media efforts. In this article, we will explore the importance of digital media in marketing and provide valuable strategies to enhance your digital marketing initiatives in 2022.
The Importance of Digital Media in Marketing
Digital media plays a significant role in modern marketing. It allows businesses to connect with their audience, build brand awareness, and drive customer engagement. Here are some key reasons why digital media is essential in today’s marketing landscape:
1. Wide Audience Reach: Digital media provides access to a vast audience globally. With online platforms, businesses can reach potential customers regardless of their location, increasing their brand’s visibility and potential customer base.
2. Targeted Marketing: Digital media enables precise targeting, allowing businesses to deliver personalized messages and offers to specific segments of their audience. This targeted approach increases the likelihood of conversions and improves overall marketing ROI.
3. Measurable Results: Unlike traditional marketing methods, digital media offers detailed analytics and tracking capabilities. Businesses can measure the performance of their campaigns, monitor engagement metrics, and make data-driven decisions to optimize their marketing strategies.
Key Strategies to Enhance Your Digital Media Efforts
To improve your digital media efforts and capitalize on the latest digital marketing trends in 2022, consider implementing the following strategies:
1. Utilize Social Media Platforms: Social media continues to be a dominant force in digital marketing. Identify the platforms most relevant to your target audience and create engaging content tailored to each platform. Leverage social media ads, influencer collaborations, and user-generated content to amplify your reach and foster brand loyalty.
2. Embrace Video Marketing: Video content is increasingly popular and effective in capturing audience attention. Invest in creating high-quality videos that communicate your brand’s message creatively. Utilize live streaming, storytelling, and interactive videos to engage and connect with your audience.

The advancements in artificial intelligence and machine learning have changed the way businesses operate and make decisions. One of the most remarkable AI-powered tools in the market today is
OpenAI’s
ChatGPT. This language model has the ability to generate human-like text and has a wide range of applications in various industries. In this blog, we’ll explore how
ChatGPT

Improved Data Processing and Analysis
Accounting involves a lot of data processing and analysis, which can be time-consuming and prone to errors if done manually. ChatGPT can help accountants automate these tasks and improve the accuracy and efficiency of the process. For example, ChatGPT can extract data from financial statements, invoices, and receipts, and convert it into a structured format that can be easily analyzed. This will allow accountants to focus on more strategic tasks and make informed decisions faster.
Enhanced Bookkeeping and Record Keeping
Bookkeeping and record keeping are crucial activities in accounting, and they can be tedious and repetitive. ChatGPT can help automate these tasks and reduce the risk of errors. For instance, ChatGPT can generate financial reports and update ledger entries based on incoming transactions. This will not only save time but also ensure that the data is up-to-date and accurate.
Improved Auditing Process
Auditing is an important part of the accounting process and helps to detect errors, fraud, and other irregularities. With ChatGPT, auditors can automate the process of reviewing financial records, analyzing data, and identifying potential issues. This will not only speed up the process but also help ensure that auditors do not miss any critical issues.
Better Customer Service
In accounting, customer service is key, and accountants need to respond promptly and accurately to customer inquiries. ChatGPT can assist accountants in providing better customer service by handling routine inquiries, such as account balances, transactions, and payment history. This will allow accountants to focus on more complex inquiries and provide better service to their customers.
In conclusion, ChatGPT will have a significant impact on the field of accounting by improving data processing and analysis, enhancing bookkeeping and record keeping, improving the auditing process, and providing better customer service. This technology has the potential to revolutionize the accounting industry and make the process more efficient, accurate, and reliable.
Overall, the impact of AI on the accounting profession is likely to be positive, as it can help accountants work more efficiently and accurately, freeing up time to focus on more complex tasks. However, it is important to note that AI is not a replacement for human judgment and expertise, and accountants will still need to use their critical thinking and problem-solving skills to make informed decisions.

Introduction
At Occams Advisory, we understand the critical role that innovation plays in driving business growth and maintaining a competitive edge. One of the most effective ways to support your company’s innovative efforts is through the Research and Development (R&D) Tax Credit, commonly referred to as the Research and Development Tax Credit under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §41. This Tax Credit is designed to encourage businesses of all sizes to invest in Research and Development activities by providing significant tax savings.
What is the Research and Development Tax Credit?
The (R&D) Tax Credit is a federal tax incentive aimed at encouraging companies to invest in innovation and technological advancements. This Tax Credit can reduce your taxable income and increase cash flow, which can be reinvested into further R&D activities. The Tax Credit applies to a wide range of Research and Development activities, making it accessible to many industries beyond just the high-tech sector.
Determining Eligibility
To qualify for the Research and Development Tax Credit, your company’s activities must meet the following criteria:
1.
Qualified Research and Development Activities (QRAs):
The activities must aim to develop new or improved business components, such as products, processes, software, techniques, formulas, or inventions.
2.
Technological in Nature:
The Research and Development must rely on principles of physical or biological sciences, engineering, or computer science.
3.
Elimination of Uncertainty:
The activities should involve a process of experimentation intended to eliminate technical uncertainty.
4.
Process of Experimentation:
This process should include modeling, simulation, systematic trial and error, or other methods aimed at resolving uncertainty.
Qualifying Expenses
Expenses that typically qualify for the Research and Development Tax Credit include:
Wages:
Compensation paid to employees directly involved in qualified Research and Development activities.
Supplies:
Costs of materials used in the R&D process.
Contract Research and Development:
Payments to third parties for conducting qualified Research and Development activities on behalf of your company.
Computer Leasing:
Expenses related to leasing computers for Research and Development purposes.
Calculating the Tax Credit
The Research and Development Tax Credit is calculated based on a percentage of qualified Research and Development expenses (QREs) over a base amount. The base amount is generally a fixed percentage of your company’s average annual gross receipts over the previous four years. There are two main methods for calculating the Tax Credit:
1.
Regular Tax Credit:
This is 20% of the QREs over the base amount.
2.
Alternative Simplified Tax Credit (ASC):
This method is 14% of the QREs that exceed 50% of the average QREs for the three preceding tax years.
Staying Updated with Recent Changes
It’s essential to stay updated with recent changes in tax laws that impact the Research and Development Tax Credit. For instance, under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) of 2017, businesses are required to amortize R&D expenses over five years, beginning after December 31, 2021. Additionally, businesses that expense R&D costs under ASC 730 can still qualify for the Research and Development Tax Credit, ensuring that financial reporting practices align with tax benefits.
Maximizing Your Benefit
At Occams Advisory, we specialize in helping businesses maximize their R&D tax Tax Credits. Our team of experts can assist you in identifying qualified Research and Development activities, ensuring proper documentation, and optimizing your Tax Credit calculations. By leveraging our deep understanding of tax regulations and industry-specific insights, we help you unlock substantial tax savings and reinvest in your company’s innovation journey.
Conclusion
Investing in Research and Development and development is crucial for staying ahead in today’s competitive market. The Research and Development Tax Credit provides a valuable opportunity to offset the costs associated with innovation. By understanding the eligibility criteria, qualifying expenses, and calculation methods, your business can effectively leverage this Tax Credit to fuel growth and enhance profitability.

Conclusion: A Defining Moment for Financial Services
Introduction
The financial services industry is undergoing a profound transformation. Automation, once a tool for efficiency, is now a strategic driver of innovation and competitive advantage. Robotic Process Automation (RPA) has evolved beyond rule-based task execution to become an intelligent, adaptive force capable of making decisions, predicting outcomes, and optimizing financial processes in real time.
“AI is the new electricity.” —Andrew Ng, Founder of deeplearning.ai
This succinct observation from Dr. Ng highlights just how foundational AI-driven automation can be for modern financial operations, akin to the revolutionary impact electricity once had on traditional industries.
Recent market insights suggest that the global RPA market continues to grow at a remarkable pace, driven by increasing adoption in banking, financial services, and insurance (BFSI).
From Automation to Intelligence: The Shift in RPA’s Role
For years, financial institutions have relied on RPA to streamline back-office tasks such as data entry, transaction processing, and compliance checks. While this has led to measurable efficiency gains, the real transformation is happening as automation becomes predictive, adaptive, and increasingly “agentic.”
An AI-powered RPA system no longer just follows predefined rules; it analyzes past trends, identifies anomalies, and even suggests corrective actions. Fraud detection, for example, is no longer reactive. Modern autonomous agents can monitor real-time transaction patterns, flag suspicious activity, and initiate preventive measures before a critical financial risk materializes.
“We invest heavily in AI, big data, and machine learning to reduce risk, fight fraud, and streamline operations.” —Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase
This statement underscores how leading banks view AI-driven automation as key to risk mitigation and operational efficiency. New AI-driven chatbots and virtual assistants—fueled by recent breakthroughs in natural language processing—can interpret complex user requests, extract relevant data from unstructured text, and even provide nuanced customer support. Industry leaders have been piloting large language model (LLM) solutions to streamline processes such as compliance checks and customer inquiry resolution.
Case in Point: Loan Processing
Traditionally a multi-step, time-intensive procedure, loan processing can now leverage agentic AI. Advanced RPA bots integrated with LLMs can verify documents, assess risk profiles, and offer predictive analytics on a borrower’s financial health. Some organizations have reported significant reductions in loan approval times through AI-driven workflows.
The Hyper-Automation Movement: What Comes Next?
The next frontier in automation is hyper-automation—an ecosystem where RPA integrates seamlessly with AI, machine learning, and advanced analytics to create fully autonomous financial processes. Recognized as a major strategic technology trend, hyper-automation is expected to greatly influence how businesses operate and compete.
A significant development in recent years has been the rise of “autonomous agents,” AI systems capable of learning from real-time data, self-correcting workflow bottlenecks, and dynamically coordinating tasks across multiple software platforms. In wealth management, for example, hyper-automation can analyze live market data, customer behavior, and risk factors to offer dynamic, real-time portfolio rebalancing—an approach that has reportedly increased client returns for leading asset management firms.
Entrepreneurs and Startups
Beyond financial services, this level of automation is revolutionizing industries worldwide. AI-enabled decision-making tools are becoming essential for new market entrants, particularly in heavily regulated sectors like finance. Entrepreneurs and startups entering the U.S. market are leveraging AI-powered decision-making to launch businesses faster, navigate regulatory frameworks, and optimize capital allocation—giving them a powerful, near-immediate advantage.
Redefining Work: Humans and AI as Collaborative Partners
One of the most thought-provoking aspects of this transformation is the evolving relationship between humans and automation. While some fear that AI might replace jobs, many research insights predict that AI will, on balance, create more positions than it displaces, especially in industries requiring complex problem-solving and high-value customer interactions.
In financial services, automation takes over repetitive, rule-based tasks, allowing professionals to focus on critical thinking, strategic decision-making, and customer relationships. Rather than handling routine inquiries, human agents can now provide high-value financial advice, while AI-powered chatbots manage transactional queries. Many financial institutions have observed higher customer satisfaction scores when AI and human expertise are combined.
Similarly, compliance teams are moving from manual regulatory reporting to AI-assisted risk management, where automation not only identifies risks but also suggests solutions. This shift has been especially impactful given the escalating complexity of global financial regulations.
Security and Compliance in an AI-Driven World
As automation becomes more sophisticated, financial institutions face new challenges in security and regulatory compliance. While RPA enhances data accuracy and auditability, adapting to evolving regulatory landscapes—especially as AI systems become more “agentic” and autonomous—requires robust governance frameworks.
AI-driven automation systems are already being designed to preemptively detect compliance risks, ensuring that financial institutions stay ahead of changing regulations. Pilot programs at major banks have shown significant reductions in compliance-related incidents when AI-powered systems were used for continuous monitoring and real-time auditing.
For businesses setting up operations in the U.S., navigating federal and state regulations has always been complex. AI is now playing a crucial role in simplifying business incorporation, tax compliance, and financial forecasting, enabling startups to establish themselves more efficiently than ever before.
What the Next Five Years Look Like for RPA in Finance
The momentum behind automation is unstoppable. Over the next five years, financial institutions will move from process automation to full-scale digital transformation. Decision-making will shift from historical data analysis to predictive, AI-driven insights, making financial operations more resilient, scalable, and adaptive. Many experts predict that a significant portion of finance functions could be fully automated in leading organizations within this timeframe.
1. Agent-Orchestrated Workflows
AI agents will coordinate multiple RPA bots and software tools, ensuring end-to-end process continuity without human intervention.
2. Deep Integration with Blockchain
Smart contracts and decentralized ledgers will interoperate seamlessly with AI-driven compliance tools, creating trustworthy, automated ecosystems for payments and settlements.
3. Personalized Customer Journeys
Real-time analytics and LLM-powered chatbots will redefine customer experience, enabling hyper-personalized financial services and on-the-spot product recommendations.
4. Regulatory Evolution
Regulators themselves will adopt AI to monitor the financial system more proactively, while institutions integrate compliance modules that automatically interpret new rules and adapt processes in real time.
5. Entrepreneurial Acceleration
Startups will benefit from near-instant setup and data-driven financial insights, allowing them to compete with established players from day one.
“We are at the beginning of a revolution that is fundamentally changing the way we live, work, and relate to one another.” —Klaus Schwab, Founder and Executive Chairman of the World Economic Forum
This broader perspective underscores that advanced automation and AI are part of a larger societal and economic shift, with finance at the forefront of many transformative initiatives. Customers will no longer tolerate delays in loan approvals, payment processing, or investment strategies. Real-time financial services will become the norm, powered by the seamless integration of AI, RPA, and blockchain technologies, with agentic AI systems steering many of the day-to-day operational decisions.
Conclusion: A Defining Moment for Financial Services
The future of RPA in financial services is not just about automation—it’s about intelligence, adaptability, and the seamless integration of technology into every level of decision-making. Breakthroughs in agentic AI—those capable of autonomous learning, workflow orchestration, and advanced analytics—are elevating automation to an entirely new level of sophistication.
Whether it’s preventing fraud, optimizing compliance, or reshaping customer experiences, automation is no longer an optional tool—it’s an imperative. For financial institutions, the question is not whether to adopt intelligent automation but how quickly they can integrate it into their operations. For entrepreneurs and businesses entering the U.S. market, AI-powered automation is a game-changer, enabling faster decision-making, regulatory compliance, and business scalability.
As we move into this next era of financial services, one thing is certain: those who embrace automation as a strategic asset—not just a cost-saving tool—will define the future of the industry. With agentic AI at the forefront, the road ahead promises a faster, more efficient, and more inclusive financial landscape for businesses and consumers alike.

Introduction
The finance world is changing at a rapid pace with new technologies and advanced artificial intelligence (AI). The new AI era has powerful advanced financial tools. Every department in every organization uses AI and finance is no exception.
Benefits of AI in Finance:
1. Efficiency:
AI’s algorithms can boost efficiency by dealing with large and complex datasets in a flash. AI has automated routine work, including data entry, bookkeeping, invoice processing, payment execution, reconciliation, finance closing internal audits, etc.
2. Accuracy:
Human work is prone to errors. AI processes data accurately within a fraction of time. It can also help identify inconsistent and missing data.
3. Compliance:
AI makes it easier to understand and comply with the complex accounting standards and applicable laws. AI can monitor relevant compliance issues and provide regulatory reports. AI uses natural language processing to transform data into meaningful insight.
4. Reporting:
AI has automated and enhanced multiple reports required by the stakeholders on a daily basis. AI assists in generating various financial reports including cashflow and variances reports. AI can be valuable in identifying outliers and detecting potential frauds.
5. Analysis:
AI can process data in real time to provide analysis and help make strategic decisions in real time. Data gets automatically converted into analytical reports and provides trend analysis.
6. Forecasting & Planning:
Predictive analytics tools are now increasingly used for forecast and planning. AI provides commentary to support the forecasts provided and the key drivers for the decision making. AI forecast can easily recalibrate with a new set of data provided.
Challenges to be considered:
1. Data security:
The omnipresent challenge with AI in finance is the threat of confidential data exposure to unauthorized access. All platforms used by the finace should be protected with cybersecurity to protect data breaches and attacks.
2. Verification:
The finance team should be able to verify the AI generated output. The professional should be able to understand the process and methods used by the AI before relying on the provided results.
Conclusion
Can AI replace humans in Finance?
It is extremely unlikely that AI can ever replace the finance professionals entirely. AI helps with quantitative aspects of finance but not qualitative. AI lacks the human element required in finance for judgement, analysis, interpretation, intuition, and empathy. However, people must partner with AI and stay up to date with the latest technologies and capabilities to automate routine work and focus on quality addition to provide greater value. AI should be used as a tool to free up the time on systematic work and focus on creating the system. Finance professionals powered by AI can deal with any complex analysis and make informed decisions.

Transforming the distribution of services to produce differential insight and added value
For the investment banking sector, recent economic shifts have generated major hurdles. This study examines how banks will have to change their operating systems in order to keep up with the changing investment environment and produce the future bank.
Top Takingaways
Investment banks1 face major challenges led by the consequences of COVID-19, changing financial laws, democratization of the industry, increased maturity of consumers, a move to remote working arrangements, and rapid developments in technology. Banks have potential to move towards higher levels of return; however, some business structures and operating platforms are likely to need to be retooled to accomplish this.
A bifurcation of broker archetypes is likely to be faced by the investment banking industry: "flow players" focused on middle and back office functions and "client capturers" specialized on front-office functions. This bifurcation would result in an ecosystem of diverse players that is interconnected.
Banks would likely need to decide which role they want and are able to play within the environment, based on internal and external influences. They will also need to rethink their service delivery around a related flow paradigm, shifting capacities and processes to business provider environments, and maximizing the use of financial technologies, information, and analytics to produce differentiated insight and added value.
Evolving world of investment banking
The global COVID-19 (novel coronavirus) pandemic's unparalleled public health, economic and social impacts have exacerbated the factors causing difficulties and accelerating disruption in the investment banking industry: declining share rates, liquidity tension, shifting financial legislation, consumer democratization, competitive pressure, enhanced consumer maturity, shifts to remote
We expect investment banking to move from a full-scale service model to a bifurcation with two broker archetypes against this difficult backdrop: "consumer capturers" specialized in front-office functions and "flow players" focused mainly on middle-office functions (figure 1). In an integrated, increasingly global, and perhaps automated, environment that involves alliances that have different back-office roles, these archetypes would certainly work.
The realignment of the sector should generate opportunities for investment banks to press for higher levels of return. Organizations should no longer tinker around the margins, however, to deliver on this agenda. In order to prioritize client-centricity, emerging technology, regulatory recalibration, and the transformation of the workforce and workplace, many will likely need to radically retool their existing market models and organizational frameworks. Moreover, inside the new ecosystem, they can decide which archetype they want and are willing to be.
What is a model for linked flows?
Linked flow is a streamlined, flexible, customer-centered operating model that enhances the capabilities of a financial institution with those of a partner ecosystem by standardizing and centralizing the supply of non-differentiated resources across the sector to generate cost efficiencies. Leveraging internal and partner data offers insight into maximizing efficiency for the most valuable operations and consumers through sales and cost factors and targets the usage of financial capital.
Adopting the related flow model would allow investment banks to reimagine their industry on four large topics: modernization of technology, future workforce, consumer centricity and recalibration of regulations. Ultimately, through expanded automation and better tooling, the model can maximize performance, overcome cost issues and produce outcomes with decreased inventory and sales leakage.
Model of Linked Flow
In the future, investment banks would possibly entail shedding non-core assets and redesigning their service delivery around a related flow model, shifting capacity and processes between various geographies and ecosystem partners, and maximizing the use of financial technologies, data and analytics to produce differentiated insight and added value. The investment bank is a data-centered enterprise that focuses on the consumer experience, transferring middle and back office functionality to sell utilities or financial technologies (fintech). In order to forecast their consumer trading practices and risk appetite, a rich data set would allow the bank to model customer behaviour and use artificial intelligence, machine learning and natural language processing.
The investment bank is also an agile player in a diverse environment that tackles current industry dynamics and relies on identifying aspects such as risk models and consumer service.
Ultimately, in an investment bank's internal processes, only a few value-add functions will need to be implemented: risk control, payments, internal and external data collection (such as customer data and regulatory reporting data) and general ledger.
To deliver this vision, technology exists today:
The foundation for a public ledger that minimizes reconciliations is distributed ledger technology.
Open-source platforms allow data lakes to store the large amounts of data produced by the enterprise.
From this knowledge, advanced analytics and cognitive technologies will extract value.
Considerations of the Archetype
Investment banks should consider how their current structure, technological infrastructure, resource supply, product portfolio, and talent pool map to the expected core competencies of each archetype (Figure 2) and, if possible, how to bridge any capacity holes while determining if it will be more beneficial to become a consumer capturer or a flow player:
How the investment bank of the future will be established
Are investment banks able to reconsider, reconstruct and focus on others to boost their sustainability in the future? For certain companies, untangling their current systems, designing and acquiring emerging technology to effectively connect with clients, healthy ecosystem partners (service providers), and harnessing and commercializing the combined potential of internal and partner data can be challenging, expensive, and time-consuming. The possible solution, though, is likely to be decreased competition and/or disintermediation of the market.
In order to identify where to concentrate and accelerate progress, banks should consider "zooming out" to imagine the future beyond immediate constraints and "zooming in" to convert this vision into prioritized programs within a system of concepts that can help lead their journeys.
The following are examples of steps to continue the journey:
Identify the utilities for either outsourcing or creating mutual internal, bank-wide services functions (for example, for data management and Know Your Customer compliance).
To be efficient, consider the governance structures needed for a
utility-based model
.
Decide on standardization driven by industry and consider how the environment will be impacted.
Consolidate the procedures and functions of operations across asset groups (such as single
post-trade processing
).
To improve flexibility and build smooth integration, centralize data storage and invest in application programming interfaces.
To increase overall performance, achieve quicker time to market, and reduce ownership costs, consider using a flexible, cloud-based architecture.
Explore the art of digital technologies such as AI, blockchain and sophisticated data processing with the art of the conceivable.
Via a post-pandemic perspective and the transition from conventional, office-oriented jobs to more mobile workspaces enabled by technological advances, analyze employee and organizational behaviors.
What's in advance?
As long as major market penetration hurdles (capital requirements, regulatory oversight, behavioural risk, and long-standing customer relationships) remain in place, investment banks are unlikely to be threatened by technology disruptors or other non-industry rivals for their market share. Investment banks looking to the future, however, should consider leaving costly internal infrastructures in the midst of evolving market conditions and shift towards a linked flow model where external providers provide services for both essential and non-critical functions. The capacity of the investment bank to produce and harness differentiated perspectives from data is its new strategic edge in this new world.
Bank of 2030: Make a bold transition
From now, the future of banking will look very different. Banks will need to start placing plans in place now to help them plan for banking in 2030, in the face of changing customer preferences, evolving technology and new market models.
In the next 10 years, how can you accelerate a bold transition in your organization?

Ten reasons why a firm should be raising online capital right now
Oct 16 2020 |
Occams Marketing
96
0
One of the most important problems for entrepreneurs at all levels is collecting money and selling stocks.
It is also one of the most daunting, time-consuming and wasteful roles they face. Fortunately, with the passing of the Employment Act and the development of funding websites, as long as prospective buyers are led to the Securities and Exchange Commission-registered financing site where their shares are being sold, entrepreneurs can now use the internet to broadcast their offers.
In the current climate, this is especially important. Here are 10 reasons why entrepreneurs should boost online capital:
Meetings face-to - face are not needed.
The "death by 1000 coffees" process of hopping from meeting to meeting with potentially qualified buyers who can listen to your pitch and determine if they want to buy your stock is the conventional mechanism for raising money. This archaic mechanism has ground to a halt with the latest COVID-19 pandemic, leaving many entrepreneurs emphasising what to do next.
Set up painlessly
You should be able to get live on an online fundraiser website within a couple of weeks if you are a real running company and have your financials and documents reasonably structured. We had a business go live with us at Netcapital just six days after the first phone call.
Make it simpler to get a "YES" decision for investors.
It is impossible to distinguish $25,000 or $100,000 from purchasing shares in a start-up venture. Prior to signing a check in the six figures, even the richest ought to have a talk with their significant other. The small investment sizes are far more achievable via online platforms. Closing for $5,000 is potentially much better for investors than closing for $50,000. Especially in times like these, where wallets are tightening, it is particularly important to make it easy for investors to say "YES."
Investing in the enterprise digitise and simplify.
Speaking of making it easy for investors to say "YES"-online portals spare investors the usual hassle of getting 10 pages of deal papers to print, sign, scan and return and then go to their bank account to wire funds to a designated account and routing number. They simply press one major investment button on a portal, attach their bank account, and buy.
Empower people who care most about you and your industry to take part
.
On an online platform, you can collect money through the new
JOBS Act
and encourage any investor to join in your bid. You are not limited to the richest and most well-connected anymore, but you can now go to those who are most enthusiastic about your business. Five years from now, you don't want to have to justify to your uncle at Thanksgiving dinner why he never had the opportunity to invest in your rocketship business, so give him the chance now!
Create brand loyalty.
Your clients are one of the most influential people who would continue to participate in your company if you give them the chance. There is no better option than enabling certain clients to own equity to develop brand loyalty and create brand ambassadors. It would be more beneficial to customers who are economically incentivized for your accomplishment than you can imagine.
Get your team engaged in a vital part of your market.
Too much, conventional fundraising depends on only one person's contributions. Founders / CEOs bear the burden of raising capital alone in a manner that restricts the success of fundraising to the network of only that person. Your whole team will help raise money by online channels. Have your CTO report to her on LinkedIn that the business is collecting funds. Ask the person in your operations to tell all of her Facebook friends they have the potential to invest. In a time where we are both apart, let the team feel more together.
Integrate the raising of capital into your tasks.
For the CEO, conventional fundraising is a major time investment that requires a great deal of time away from more vital areas of the organisation. Either you get a huge check written and it was a decent use of your time to fly out to Sand Hill Road, or you didn't get the money and you didn't earn anything for your efforts. The efforts, money and resources expended on the road fundraiser is subjective. Utilizing an online network helps you to incorporate your fundraising with other primary programmes. Active ad campaign running? Conduct any commercials leading customers to your investment offering. Sending out your base weekly emails? Notify them of the investing potential. Make a new app? Guide consumers to the prospect of investment as they try it out.
Release stress contract.
It makes the debates more lively when you put the terms up front and give investors just one decision to make (yes or no). You constantly avoid answering the same 20 questions and the answers to the obvious questions can be found on your offering page by any interested investor. The simplicity of decision-making when leaving out redundant talks makes it easy for an investor to say "YES" and makes your life easy as an entrepreneur.
Take power of your fate.
Do not rest on your hands and wait until this worldwide pandemic has ended. Take measures that encourage you to do exactly that to build value-
online fundraising platforms
. It also encourages you to set the criteria that you feel are fair, and tells the world that there is a need to invest in your business.
Now is the time to explore, if you have ever felt that an online forum could be an productive way of fundraising for your company. All is left working from home, investors are disappointed by the public markets' uncertainty and all is glued to the internet waiting for something interesting to entertain their minds. Publish an offering page and excite the world by contacting your network and telling them to read your storey for 10 minutes and give you some suggestions.
To enter the digital era, it's time for capital raising. To make it possible, COVID-19 might only be the trigger.

What are the most commonly asked questions about Employee Retention Credits?
Aug 23 2022 |
Occams Marketing
96
0
▷
Numerous changes in company operations were brought about by the coronavirus epidemic, which also prompted legislation that altered the tax code and the business credit system. The “Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021” (“CAA”) is one of those laws and it provided a way of relief for many businesses, healthcare providers, and other entities affected by the epidemic. The Employee Retention Credit (ERC), which is a chance offered to qualified firms, is one such opportunity. The ERC still has a lot of complexities that can be challenging for employers to understand despite being originally developed as part of the CARES Act and enhanced as part of the CAA. We address some of the most often asked queries about this important credit in our blog.
Who Are the Eligible Employers?
An organisation must be carrying on a trade or operating as a business in the financial years 2020 or 2021, have experienced a full or partial suspension due to the pandemic, supply chain disruptions due to vendors who experienced shutdown orders, or have experienced a significant loss of gross receipts in order to qualify.
What Affects Gross Receipts as a “Significant Decline”?
The IRS uses percentages that are based on an organization’s 2019 Gross Receipts to determine what constitutes a “significant fall” in 2020 as opposed to 2021. The drop must be larger than 50% in 2020 and greater than 20% in 2021. This is evaluated on a quarterly basis in both cases and corresponds to the same quarter in 2019. For the year 2021, there is an exception to this rule: if a preceding quarter was required to be larger than 20%, it might be used in place of a prior year.
Which Workers Are Eligible?
For the 2020 ERC, an employer with 100 or fewer average full-time employees (as measured in 2019) is defined as a small employer.
For the 2021 ERCs, an employer with 500 or fewer full-time employees (as measured in 2019) is defined as a small employer.
The term “full-time employee” means an employee who, with respect to any calendar month in 2019, had an average of at least 30 hours of service per week or 130 hours of service in the month (130 hours of service in a month is treated as the monthly equivalent of at least 30 hours of service per week), as determined in accordance with section 4980H of the Code.
What Quarters Can the ERC Be Reclaimed For?
The eligibility determines how many quarters may be claimed. Wages paid between 3/13/20 and 9/30/21 are eligible for the ERC credit. Wages paid between 7/1/21 and 12/31/21 are eligible for starting firms.
Can I Make an ERC Claim If I Got a PPP Loan?
Yes. You can now claim the ERC credit even if you had a PPP loan thanks to the revisions made by the CAA Act and enacted into law. Simply put, we cannot spend identical funds, dollar for dollar. This factor is taken into consideration while determining your ERC qualification.
How much might be claimed annually? What Wages Are Eligible?
The credit equals 50 percent of the qualified wages (including qualified health plan expenses) that an Eligible Employer pays in a calendar quarter. The maximum amount of qualified wages taken into account with respect to each employee for all calendar quarters is $10,000, so that the maximum credit for qualified wages paid to any employee is $5,000.
Example 1:
Employer M pays $10,000 in qualified wages to Employee A in the second quarter of 2020. The Employee Retention Credit available to Employer M for the qualified wages paid to Employee A is $5,000.
Example 2:
Employer N pays $8,000 in qualified wages to Employee B in the second quarter 2020 and $8,000 in qualified wages in the third quarter 2020. The credit available to Employer N for the qualified wages paid to Employee B is equal to $4,000 in the second quarter and $1,000 in the third quarter due to the overall limit of 50 percent of $10,000 of qualified wages per employee for all calendar quarters.
How is the ERC Said to Work?
The employee wage requirements are used to calculate the ERC credit, which is subsequently claimed by revising the related payroll tax reports.
How soon must I submit an ERC claim?
After submitting Form 941, amended payroll tax returns may be filed three years later. Accordingly, you have till Q1 of 2023 for Q1 of 2020, Q1 of 2021 until Q1 of 2024, and so on.
Are ERC credits tax deductible?
ERC credits are not considered to be taxable income. It does, however, change your payroll costs. The precise amount of your refund must be communicated to your CPA so they can accurately report the changes on your business tax returns after you get it.
What Will Happen Next?
Despite the fact that the procedure can be complicated, the following easy stages will assist you in navigating the ERC:
a) To find out if you qualify, complete our Qualification form.
b) Obtain your 941 forms and payroll data so that we can start computing your credit.
c) Work with our staff to submit all the necessary documentation and information.
You’ll then have a better idea of the types of funding your company is eligible for. We at
Occams

15-min free consultation here

Introduction
401k plans are a type of retirement savings plan that allows employees to contribute pre-tax dollars towards their retirement savings. These plans are a popular way to save for retirement, with millions of Americans relying on 401k plans for their retirement savings.
Current State of 401k Plans
Currently, 401k plans have contribution limits of $19,500 for employees under 50 years of age and $26,000 for employees over 50 years of age. Employers can also contribute to these plans on behalf of their employees, up to a certain limit.
The Changes Coming to 401k Plans in 2023
Starting in 2023, the contribution limits for 401k plans will increase. Employees under 50 years of age will be able to contribute up to $20,000, while employees over 50 years of age will be able to contribute up to $27,000. Additionally, the limit on employer contributions will increase to $44,000.
Real-Life Scenarios
Here are two real-life scenarios that demonstrate how the changes to 401k plans in 2023 may affect retirement planning:
Scenario 1: Tom is 45 years old and currently contributes the maximum amount allowed to his 401k plan. When the new contribution limits go into effect in 2023, Tom will be able to contribute an additional $500 to his retirement savings each year.
Scenario 2: Jane is 55 years old and plans to retire in 10 years. Jane currently contributes the maximum amount allowed to her 401k plan, but with the new contribution limits in 2023, she will be able to contribute an additional $1,000 to her retirement savings each year. This additional savings could make a significant difference in Jane’s retirement income.
Conclusion
The changes coming to 401k plans in 2023 will provide employees with the opportunity to save more for retirement. By taking advantage of these increased contribution limits, employees can maximize their retirement savings and ensure a comfortable retirement.

Why Is Business Process Management Essential for Any Company?
Apr 28 2021 |
Occams Marketing
157
0
Businesses must constantly develop their operations in order to become and stay profitable and efficient.
Businesses must be willing to constantly change their systems in order to stay ahead of the market.
Business process management software
is intended to make management's workloads simpler and more effective, as well as to provide a platform for all staff members to collaborate.
Technology for business process management should be reliable, accurate, and offer quality satisfaction to all team members who use it.
Businesses must constantly develop their operations in order to become and stay profitable and efficient. If you don't, you'll probably end up with increased prices, reduced earnings, less enthusiastic workers, and dissatisfied clients.
Business process management (BPM) is a valuable mechanism that companies can use to ensure that all facets of their processes operate smoothly. Here's why the organization wants enterprise process management if you're thinking about investing in it to boost processes.
What exactly is BPM?
Business process management, according to Gartner, is "a discipline that drives organizational efficiency and business agility to boost organization results." Consider a company to be an engine, and BPM to be a method for fine-tuning each part of that engine to reach peak efficiency.
What is the purpose of BPM?
There are standard business processes in any organization that are structured to achieve goals. Any systems, nevertheless, can be sluggish, costly, ineffective, duplicative, and redundant for a variety of reasons. A BPM examines all of these systems from a new perspective, using models, metrics, and research to assess them and find changes that can increase efficiency. Businesses should use BPM to ensure that new systems integrate seamlessly and perform well as they are implemented.
What are the biggest advantages of BPM applications and what do you aim for?
Simply put, a business process management (BPM) platform allows businesses to process more for better efficiency, reduced waste, and less time. This is especially beneficial for startups and other businesses with limited resources that need to achieve profitability rapidly.
The basic advantages of BPM for businesses can be divided into three categories:
Effectiveness.
Many systems are prone to waste due to a variety of reasons, including manual labour, ineffective interdepartmental handoff, and a general failure to adequately track overall development. Companies will identify and eliminate inefficiencies by shining a new eye on operations, which benefits the bottom line.
The ability to be successful.
BPM can be used to make a procedure more successful until it has become more functional. The ability to treat exceptions quicker and easier, make better, more rational choices, and perform reliably, which is crucial for delivering a better consumer experience, are just a few of the many advantages of increased process effectiveness. Companies become more efficient and competitive as all operations are running smoothly and are consistent with business goals and priorities.
Adaptability
. The need for an organization to be agile is more important than ever before in today's ultra-competitive business environment. Companies of old, inflexible systems, on the other hand, would be left behind. The desire for reform will come from both within and outside an organization. In order to take advantage of new openings, you can need to make some adjustments. Change may be needed to satisfy new business partners or clients who have a particular way of doing business. Remember that state, federal, and foreign regulations can compel a company to alter its procedures.
Commercial process optimization platform that is widely used
When looking for the right enterprise process management tools, there are several choices to consider. The decision you make is influenced by a number of considerations, including the cost of the software, whether you want the software to be available to in-house employees, remote employees, or a mix of both, and the program's ease of use.

Introduction
In today’s fast-paced technological landscape, developing automated solutions has become a cornerstone of innovation. Automation transforms ordinary tasks into streamlined processes, enhances efficiency, and enables organizations to scale operations to unprecedented heights. However, crafting effective automated solutions is an intricate process that demands a delicate equilibrium between two crucial qualities:
persistence
and
patience.
Persistence serves as a driving force, propelling developers forward in their quest to find solutions. It fuels their determination to overcome obstacles and setbacks, ensuring that progress remains unwavering. On the other hand, patience provides a steadfast foundation, maintaining a consistent course even in the face of challenges and setbacks. Together, these qualities form the bedrock of successful automation projects.
In this exploration, we delve into the vital roles of persistence and patience in the development of automated systems. We uncover how striking the right balance between these qualities can lead to sustainable and innovative outcomes.
Understanding Automation in Context
Automation involves using technology to perform tasks with minimal human involvement. Whether it’s streamlining workflows, managing large datasets, or deploying intelligent decision-making algorithms, automation requires a precise understanding of both the task at hand and the tools used to achieve it.
Developers of automated solutions often face various challenges:
– Complexity of Requirements:
Automation involves breaking down complex processes into manageable tasks.
– Integration Issues:
Systems and tools must work harmoniously, requiring robust integration strategies.
– Evolving Expectations:
Stakeholder requirements can change during the development cycle.
– Error Handling:
Ensuring the solution can gracefully handle exceptions is crucial for its reliability.
These challenges require a mindset that balances determination with adaptability—a hallmark of persistence and patience.
Persistence plays a crucial role in automation development
Involving consistent problem-solving, iterative design refinement, and overcoming challenges.
1. Debugging and Troubleshooting:
Inevitable errors arise during development, and a persistent mindset helps developers persevere through frustration. Methodical testing, analyzing logs, and refining code are essential steps in resolving complex issues, such as edge cases or unpredictable API behavior.
2. Learning New Technologies:
The automation landscape is constantly evolving, and persistence is vital for learning and mastering new platforms, frameworks, or languages. Understanding AI tools or software testing frameworks like Selenium often requires extensive experimentation and research.
3. Iterative Improvement:
Automation solutions often start as rough prototypes. Persistence ensures continuous refinement, enhancing efficiency, reducing errors, and expanding functionality. This iterative approach often involves revisiting solutions multiple times to improve performance.
4. Overcoming Roadblocks: Developers encounter various roadblocks,
including limited documentation and incompatible tools. A persistent attitude maintains momentum, ensuring progress even in the face of unexpected challenges.
Patience plays a crucial role in automation development,
complementing persistence by encouraging steady and thoughtful work rather than rushing toward completion. It enables developers to endure delays and setbacks without losing focus or motivation.
Patience is essential for several aspects of automation:
1. Thorough Planning:
Jumping straight into coding without understanding the problem can lead to wasted effort. Patience allows developers to take the time needed to map out workflows, identify edge cases, and determine the best tools for the job. A well-planned solution is often more robust and easier to maintain.
2. Testing and Validation:
Effective automation requires rigorous testing. Patience ensures that developers thoroughly validate their solutions, testing for various scenarios and edge cases. This includes unit testing, integration testing, and user acceptance testing. Skipping these steps can lead to unreliable systems and costly rework.
3. Stakeholder Collaboration:
Stakeholders may not always articulate their requirements clearly, and their needs may evolve. Patience is essential for engaging in constructive dialogue, refining the solution based on feedback, and ensuring the final product aligns with expectations.
4. Long-Term Vision:
Automation projects often have long-term goals, such as reducing operational costs or improving customer satisfaction. Achieving these outcomes requires patience, as the full benefits may not be immediately apparent.
Striking the right balance between
persistence and patience is crucial for developers. Too much persistence without patience can lead to burnout, while excessive patience without persistence can result in stagnation. Here are some strategies to help you achieve this balance:
1. Set Realistic Goals:
Define clear and achievable milestones for your project. Break it down into smaller tasks and celebrate your progress along the way. This will help you stay focused on attainable outcomes and prevent frustration.
2. Adopt Agile Practices:
Agile development methodologies encourage iterative progress, frequent reassessments, and collaboration with stakeholders. These practices inherently balance persistence (through continuous delivery) and patience (by allowing flexibility and time for adaptation).
3. Embrace a Growth Mindset:
Recognize that setbacks are opportunities for learning. A growth mindset fosters resilience and encourages developers to persist through challenges while maintaining patience for long-term development.
4. Leverage Collaboration:
Working in a team environment helps balance individual strengths and weaknesses. Persistent team members can drive momentum, while patient team members ensure a steady and thoughtful approach.
5. Prioritize Self-Care:
Burnout is a real risk for developers. Regular breaks, maintaining a healthy work-life balance, and practicing mindfulness can help sustain both persistence and patience throughout a project.
Case Study 1: Automating E-Check Processing at Equipay
Equipay, a payment solutions provider, automates the acceptance of e-checks for merchants through a multi-stage workflow. This process includes customer verification, bank account validation via third-party APIs, compliance checks, and e-check processing through an ACH provider.
The system offers multiple integration workflows, including web store APIs, Equipay terminals, and bulk CSV uploads. Merchants also receive automated notifications and generate reports based on submission statuses.
Challenges and Solutions:
Complex Bank Verification Processes:
Third-party API downtimes and validation errors were common. However, the team’s
persistence
allowed them to handle various errors and downtime, as well as fallback systems for uninterrupted processing.
Diverse Workflow Integration:
Supporting different merchant workflows, including accepting data through various modes such as online forms, web stores, APIs, CSV files, and virtual terminals, required
persistent efforts
to build scalable and flexible modules that ensured compatibility across different systems.
Notification Accuracy:
Delays and duplicate notifications posed challenges. Through iterative improvements and
persistent debugging, the team
ensured real-time accuracy in notifications.
Dynamic Reporting:
Data inconsistencies made automated reporting difficult. The team’s
persistent focus
on refining data pipelines led to actionable insights for merchants.
The Role of Patience:
Extensive testing for edge cases, such as incomplete submissions or high transaction volumes, required
patience
to ensure system reliability.
Stakeholder Collaboration:
Evolving requirements from merchants necessitated
patient engagement
and iterative refinements.
Outcome:
Equipay successfully launched a robust e-check processing system that reduced processing times, provided flexible integrations, enhanced merchant transparency, and improved scalability for future growth.
Case Study 2: Implementing a BOI Chatbot for FinCEN Filings
In response to mandatory FinCEN filings,
BOIReporting
introduced a chatbot to address a wide range of user queries related to Beneficial Ownership Information (BOI) reporting. The chatbot offered structured responses based on advanced algorithms and was synchronized with the government’s official FinCEN FAQs.
To address the diverse user scenarios,
BOIReporting developed comprehensive workflows to handle various queries. Continuous user feedback guided the
refinement
of algorithms, enabling the chatbot to better interpret and respond to queries.
The result was a simplified compliance process, providing accurate and up-to-date responses that reduced the need for human intervention. The chatbot also enhanced the user experience, making the BOI reporting process more user-friendly.
Occams Advisory
streamlined its Beneficial Ownership Information Reporting (BOIR) process by automating multiple stages, including lead generation, agreement signing, file processing, and payment collection.
Challenges and Solutions:
Lead Generation and Data Collection:
Occams Advisory generated leads through web portals, APIs, and manual uploads. To automate document generation based on user data, the team implemented
persistence
to refine dynamic templates and ensure seamless data flow.
Agreement Signing and Notifications:
Automating e-signature workflows posed challenges, including triggering notifications and advancing to subsequent stages. Through
persistent debugging,
the team optimized real-time status updates and triggered workflows efficiently.
File Processing and Payment Tracking:
Linking payment collection to workflow completion required
persistent monitoring
and integration of centralized dashboards for tracking.
The Role of Patience:
Scenario Testing:
Rigorous testing across workflows ensured that automated forms, e-signatures, and payment tracking worked cohesively.
Iterative Refinements:
Feedback from users guided
improvements
in form-filling mechanisms and status-tracking workflows.
Result:
The automated system significantly reduced manual intervention, streamlined tax credit claims, and provided businesses with a transparent and efficient process for filing Beneficial Ownership Information Report claims.
Conclusion:
Building automated solutions is a complex and rewarding endeavor that combines art and science. Developers must possess the determination to overcome obstacles and the patience to navigate intricate challenges. By striking a balance between these qualities, developers can create innovative and efficient systems that are not only sustainable but also long-lasting.
Persistence drives progress, while patience ensures a steady and thoughtful approach. Together, these qualities form the cornerstone of success in automation development.

Introduction
Section 179D of the Internal Revenue Code provides a significant tax deduction for energy-efficient improvements made to commercial buildings. However, to claim this deduction, building owners and designers must meet specific certification requirements. This white paper outlines the process, key players, and necessary documentation to ensure compliance and maximize benefits.
Overview of Section 179D Deductions
Section 179D, also known as the Energy Efficient Commercial Buildings Deduction, offers tax incentives for the installation of energy-efficient systems in commercial buildings. The deduction applies to property that reduces energy and power costs related to lighting, heating, cooling, ventilation, and hot water systems by at least 25% compared to a reference building.
Key Changes and Updates
Recent changes, particularly from the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, have expanded eligibility and increased potential deduction amounts. Key updates include:
– Increased deduction limits for projects meeting prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements.
– Introduction of alternative deductions for energy-efficient building retrofit property (EEBRP).
– Elimination of partial deductions and interim lighting rules.
Certification Requirements
Certificates Must Be from a Qualified Individual
A certification from a qualified individual is necessary to claim the Section 179D deduction. A qualified individual must: – Be a licensed engineer or contractor in the jurisdiction where the building is located. – Not be related to the person or entity claiming the deduction. – Provide written representation of their qualifications.
Certification Process
1.
Energy Modeling :
The building’s energy performance must be modeled using approved software to demonstrate compliance with the energy reduction requirements.
2.
Inspection and Testing :
A qualified individual must inspect the property and verify that the energy-efficient systems have been installed as per the design specifications.
3.
Certification Document :
The qualified individual must complete a certification document that includes:
– The name and address of the building owner.
– The address of the building.
– The energy-efficient systems installed.
– The calculated energy savings compared to a reference building.
Required Documentation
To substantiate the deduction, the following documents must be maintained:
– The energy savings report generated by the approved software.
– Detailed records of the inspection and testing performed by the qualified individual.
– The completed certification document signed by the qualified individual.
Prevailing Wage and Apprenticeship Requirements
To qualify for the increased deduction amounts, projects must meet prevailing wage and apprenticeship requirements:
–
Prevailing Wage:
Laborers and mechanics involved in the installation must be paid wages at rates not less than those prevailing for similar work in the locality.
–
Apprenticeship:
A certain percentage of total labor hours must be performed by qualified apprentices.
Claiming the Deduction
Form 7205
To claim the Section 179D deduction, Form 7205 must be completed and attached to the taxpayer’s income tax return. The form requires detailed information about the building, the energy-efficient property installed, and the certification details.
Recordkeeping
Taxpayers must retain all relevant documentation, including the certification, energy savings report, and records of prevailing wage and apprenticeship compliance, for audit purposes.
Conclusion
Meeting the certification requirements for Section 179D deductions can significantly benefit commercial building owners and designers by reducing their tax liability. By understanding the certification process, engaging qualified professionals, and maintaining thorough documentation, taxpayers can ensure compliance and maximize their deductions.

The Path Forward
Introduction
As we begin February, the landscape of marketing is undergoing transformative changes, driven primarily by advancements in artificial intelligence (AI). This evolution is not merely an extension of existing tactics but a fundamental inversion of traditional marketing dynamics.
Here’s a deep dive into what this means for marketers, brands, and consumers.
1. From Push to Pull: The New Dynamics of Consumer Engagement
Historically, marketing has been about pushing messages to audiences through mediums like billboards and TV ads. In the AI-driven future, the focus shifts dramatically from pushing messages to making products and services optimally discoverable by AI systems. Intelligent systems will “pull” relevant offerings into their decision space when they meet specific needs, fundamentally changing how visibility in the market is achieved.
2. From Scarcity to Abundance: Managing the Overflow
In traditional marketing, strategies revolve around the scarcity of resources—be it ad space, creative input, or consumer attention. AI overturns this by offering infinite content variations, personalization, and interaction points. However, this abundance creates a new form of scarcity: the lack of trust and authentic human connections. Marketers must now pivot from managing resource scarcity to curating a wealth of content, focusing on quality and relevance.
3. From Static to Fluid: The Evolution of Marketing Campaigns
Forget fixed campaigns and set schedules. In the age of AI, marketing campaigns are living, evolving entities that adapt in real-time based on continuous feedback. This dynamic environment means marketers will set parameters for campaigns to self-evolve rather than adhere to predetermined paths, posing new challenges in flexibility and real-time decision-making.
4. From Human to Hybrid Markets: Navigating Complex Ecosystems
The marketplace is evolving into a complex ecosystem where you’re not just marketing to humans but also AI agents and hybrid systems. Understanding the nuances of these new market “species” is crucial. The strategy will involve deciphering and influencing a mix of human and AI-driven decisions, making the marketer’s role more sophisticated and integrated.
5. From Metrics to Memory: Building Brand Legacy
While AI excels at optimizing for immediate metrics like clicks and conversions, the future of marketing emphasizes creating lasting brand memory and cultural resonance. Legacy brands with rich histories and deep-seated consumer relationships have an edge here. In an AI-dominated landscape, the challenge for new brands will be to build this kind of equity, which cannot be quickly replicated through optimization alone.
Rethinking Marketing Functions
Creation Becomes Curation:
With AI capable of generating endless content variations, the marketer’s role will increasingly focus on curating rather than creating, selecting content that aligns best with brand strategy and audience needs.
Targeting Becomes Teaching:
Traditional targeting is transformed into educating AI systems about your products’ unique attributes to enhance their ability to match these offerings with the right opportunities.
Campaigns Become Ecosystems:
Marketing initiatives will morph into ecosystems that adapt organically to market responses. Marketers will initiate conditions and guide developments but will not control every aspect.
Analytics Becomes Intelligence:
Moving beyond mere data analysis, marketers will need to understand and interact with complex market dynamics that include both human and AI behaviors.
Why Legacy Brands Have an Edge
In a world where AI can optimize anything quickly, the enduring value of a brand built over decades becomes a significant advantage. These brands’ deep roots and authentic connections make them more trusted and preferred, despite the presence of newer, possibly more optimized competitors.
The Path Forward
This isn’t just about adding AI into the marketing mix but rather understanding a completely new marketplace landscape. Success will hinge on:
Embracing a systems and networks mindset over campaigns and funnels.
Developing capabilities to engage both human and AI market participants.
Balancing swift AI-driven optimizations with long-term brand building and authenticity.
As we navigate this new era, the key will be not just to adapt but to lead through understanding and innovating within these inverted dynamics. Welcome to the new age of marketing, where the integration of AI demands a re-evaluation of strategies, and the true power lies in balancing technological advancements with the intrinsic value of genuine brand building.
