Background
“Think, Feel, Act”
is an outcome-based engagement framework built on three interconnected stages: our thoughts, which influence our emotions, which influence our actions. Unlike rigorous analytical tools and frameworks,
“Think, Feel, Act”
offers a simple, intuitive approach to business strategy that owners can use to guide employees through organizational change and as a marketing tool to better understand and influence client behavior. This white paper provides a comprehensive guide on how business owners can implement the
“Think, Feel, Act”
framework as an effective tool for creating a cohesive team of brand ambassadors for the company and influencing client behavior, drawing from Occams Advisory’s successful application of this framework in achieving these outcomes.
“Think, Feel, Act” in Managing Organizational Change
Change is the only constant in life, and the business world is no exception to that. This is especially true for small businesses, who have to grow their concepts to be viable and scalable. In times of organizational change, it’s essential for business owners to effectively communicate to their team to maintain cohesion. Here’s where the
“Think, Feel, Act”
model can come into play to make these transition periods easier for everyone.
Think: Get employees on the same page
Implementing an organizational change–shift in the business model, rebranding, or cultural change–can be difficult for employees to adjust to, especially when operations are already smooth. Clear communication from business leadership— explaining the reason behind changes, expected outcomes, and impact on the organization and individual roles—is essential for employees to get on the same page as the leadership. When Occams Advisory implements a change, such as expanding its service offerings, leadership holds town halls and Q&A sessions to clarify the purpose and impact on each team. Departments receive tailored guidance on role adjustments, and training is provided to prepare employees for new responsibilities. Change champions within teams support peers, and regular check-ins ensure ongoing feedback, making the transition collaborative and aligned with Occams’ vision.
Feel: Tend to emotions
When initially proposing change, you might get a few raised eyebrows, pursed lips, and voices of concern by unsettled employees. Business owners must lend emotional support to their employees by addressing insecurities and inspiring confidence, helping their team embrace change rather than avoid it. Employees who feel valued as key contributors to the company’s success will demonstrate better resilience and adaptability during organizational change. At Occams Advisory, supporting employees through change is essential. During any internal shift—like expanding services or restructuring—leadership holds open discussions to address concerns, reinforcing each team member’s role and value. Regular meetings and peer support networks foster transparency and trust, ensuring that everyone feels heard and appreciated. This approach builds morale, resilience, and a unified, adaptable team ready to embrace new challenges together.
Act: Turn enthusiasm into action
Once employees are familiarized and invested in your vision for change, they need clear calls to action. What exactly do employees have to do to fulfill your organizational vision? Suggest specific actions that are relevant and achievable. Occams Advisory example
(Photo Illustration Concept By NAIOP)

A Team of Brand Ambassadors
A powerful outcome of applying the
“Think, Feel, Act”
model is that employees naturally evolve into brand ambassadors, actively championing the company’s values and goals. This way, owners do not have to feel trapped in an “isolation chamber” where they are running the business all alone. Employees that think, feel, and act with an owner’s mindset can apply the above steps as well, making transition periods during organizational change even smoother and successful. Occams Advisory started exploring the idea very organically to build its brand positioning and ideology. In a world full off grey, Occams decided to use its own employees as their ambassadors. Who better to tell their story than the employees who work within the organisation.
“Think, Feel, Act” in Client Strategy
According to research conducted by Forrester Consulting, how a customer thinks and feels are statistically significant drivers of business outcomes like purchase, loyalty, and advocacy. To influence and increase these outcomes, companies must understand the following client behavior:
Think: Clients’ Cognitive Process
Once clients recognize a need for a product or service, they will weigh different options in the market, assessing which product or service best addresses their pain points.
Feel: Clients’ Emotional Aspect
Customers develop feelings and emotions based on their interactions with the brand and how it resonates with their values and aspirations.
Act: Clients’ Conversion to Purchase
After careful consideration, clients eventually make the decision to purchase the product/service or engage with the brand.
Conclusion
Although having important applications in corporate settings, the
“Think, Feel, Act”
framework is not exclusive to the workplace. At its core, it’s a universal approach to understanding the human mind – helping us recognize why we and others think, feel, and act the way we do, and taking that awareness to facilitate better decision-making in both professional and personal contexts. The increased mindfulness that comes with adopting this framework promotes healthier workplaces, relationships, and mental well-being. Business strategy is often overcrowded with complex jargon and elaborate models that not every business owner can resonate with, so it’s refreshing to see how a framework as simple and intuitive as
“Think, Feel, Act”
can have a profound effect on not just workplace efficiency and performance, but in life.

Introduction
Every business, at some point, grapples with the critical question of how to finance its growth. Two primary options stand out: equity financing and debt financing. Each comes with its own set of advantages and disadvantages, making the choice a delicate one.
Real Life Scenarios:
Let’s consider two contrasting scenarios:
Start-up A: This young, tech-driven company has a revolutionary product with high growth potential. However, it has limited cash flow and needs capital to scale. Equity financing seems ideal, allowing it to attract investors who believe in its vision while avoiding the burden of fixed debt payments.
Company B: This established, brick-and-mortar business has a steady cash flow and needs capital for expansion. Debt financing appears advantageous, as it allows them to maintain control and leverage tax benefits without diluting ownership.
FAQs
What are the key differences between equity and debt financing?
Ownership: Equity holders own a part of the company, while debt holders are creditors.
Repayment: Equity investors expect a return on their investment, which can be realized through dividends or capital appreciation. Debt holders receive fixed interest payments and the repayment of principal at maturity.
Control: Equity holders may have voting rights and influence on the company’s decision-making, while debt holders typically have no such rights.
Which option is better for my company?
It depends. Consider your company’s stage of growth, risk tolerance, credit rating, and growth potential. Consult financial advisors for tailored advice.
What role can Occams Advisory play?
Occams Advisory can assist with:
Financial modeling and forecasting: Assess the impact of different financing options.
Investment banking services: Connect with potential investors and negotiate terms.
Merger and acquisition advisory
: Explore alternative capital raising strategies.
Conclusions
Both equity and debt financing have their merits and drawbacks. By understanding the key differences and carefully considering your company’s specific circumstances, you can make an informed decision that fuels your growth trajectory.

Introduction
The pandemic has had a disproportionate impact on small businesses, particularly those in certain sectors. As lockdowns and restrictions were put in place, many small businesses were forced to close their doors, resulting in significant financial losses.
Small Business Sectors Hit Hardest by COVID-19
Some of the small business sectors that were hit hardest by the pandemic include:
Restaurants and bars: Many restaurants and bars were forced to close or operate at reduced capacity due to social distancing guidelines.
Retail: Small retailers, particularly those selling non-essential goods, experienced a significant decrease in foot traffic.
Tourism and travel: Small businesses in the tourism and travel industry, such as hotels and tour operators, were severely impacted by travel restrictions and a decrease in demand.
Personal services: Small businesses providing personal services, such as hair salons and gyms, were forced to close or operate at reduced capacity.
Real-Life Scenario #1
Let’s say a small business owner operates a hair salon that was forced to close during the pandemic. They struggled to pay rent and other expenses, resulting in significant financial losses.
Real-Life Scenario #2
Now let’s say a small business owner operates a small retail store that was forced to close or operate at reduced capacity due to social distancing guidelines. They experienced a significant decrease in foot traffic and struggled to make ends meet.
How Small Businesses Can Adapt and Recover
To adapt to the challenges posed by the pandemic, small businesses can:
Embrace e-commerce: Small businesses can set up an online store or sell through third-party platforms to reach customers who are unable or unwilling to visit their physical store.
Offer delivery and curbside pickup: Small businesses can offer delivery or curbside pickup options to make it more convenient for customers to shop with them.
Implement safety measures: Small businesses can implement safety measures, such as requiring masks and social distancing, to make customers feel comfortable shopping in-store.
Financial Assistance for Small Businesses
Paycheck Protection Program (PPP): This program provides forgivable loans to small businesses to help cover payroll costs and other expenses. Eligible businesses can apply through participating lenders.
Economic Injury Disaster Loan (EIDL) Program: This program provides low-interest loans to small businesses that have suffered economic injury as a result of the pandemic. Eligible businesses can apply directly through the Small Business Administration (SBA).
State and local grants: Many state and local governments have established grant programs to help small businesses that have been impacted by the pandemic. Check with your local government to see if you are eligible.
A family-owned restaurant in a small town struggled to keep its doors open during the pandemic. The owners had to pivot to takeout and delivery services, which required significant investments in technology and marketing. Despite their efforts, the restaurant was forced to close permanently due to a lack of business.
Conclusion
The COVID-19 pandemic has been a challenging time for small businesses around the world. However, with the right strategies and support, small businesses can adapt and recover. By embracing e-commerce, offering delivery and curbside pickup, implementing safety measures, and accessing financial assistance programs, small businesses can weather the storm and come out stronger on the other side.

Background
On April 2nd, on what the Trump administration proclaimed as “Liberation Day,” President Donald Trump imposed a 10% baseline tariff on all imports into the United States, with higher rates targeting 60 countries running significant trade deficits with the US, including China, the European Union, and Japan. The tariffs, which take effect between April 5th and 9th, have rattled global markets, sparked fears of a trade war, and marked the most significant tax hike since 1942. A combination of declines in the S&P PMI, consumer confidence, ISM PMI, and the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet—alongside rising Core PCE prices and Michigan inflation expectations—signals a shift toward a stagflationary economy marked by high inflation and low output. In Trump’s view, the tariffs will re-shore manufacturing, eliminate massive trade deficits, and usher in a new global order where America is no longer “ripped off” by foreign nations. However, the immediate fallout—surging prices, renewed protectionism, and plummeting markets cast uncertainty over Trump’s long-term vision of a reindustrialized, booming America coming to fruition. This whitepaper will break down the economic impact of the tariff policy, assess the “MAGA masterplan” of a new global order conducive to American interests, and guide SME owners on how they can weather these uncertain times with Occams Advisory’s expertise.
Tariffs Send Wall Street Reeling
Trump’s sweeping tariffs rattled global markets as over $6.6 trillion in stock market value was wiped off Wall Street, all three major stock indices (S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq) tumbled over 5%, Nasdaq and Russel 2000 entered bear markets, commodities like oil and copper plunged, and the US dollar sank. This marks the worst week for the US stocks since the COVID-19 crash. Analysts at major banks like JP Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs warn of a looming recession. In a report headlined “There will be blood,” JP Morgan warns, “these policies, if sustained, would likely push the US and possibly global economy into recession this year. An update of our probability scenario tree makes this point, raising the risk of a recession this year to 60%.” The Federal Reserve, under Powell’s assessment that “significantly larger than expected” tariffs will cause “higher inflation and slower growth,” will not see fit to lower interest rates and move further from the 2% inflation target, despite President Trump’s demands for Powell to “CUT INTEREST RATES AND STOP PLAYING POLITICS!” on a recent Truth social. Rob Citrone, founder of Discovery Capital Management, captured the current chaos in a client’s note, stating, “This environment is one of those times when my investment roadmap feels less like a drive down I-95 and more like navigating NYC rush hour with Waze constantly rerouting every 30 seconds.”
Global Trade War Looms
Fears of a recession have been further compounded by the threat of a global trade war, with world leaders, including key allies, responding to Trump’s tariffs with retaliatory measures and condemnation. Canada’s Prime Minister Carney announced a 25% tariff on all US vehicle imports “that do not comply with our free trade agreement.” China fired back at Trump’s “bullying tariffs” by instituting a 34% reciprocal tariff on US imports to China effective April 10th. However, other countries are taking a different approach by negotiating with Trump to prevent an all-out trade war. UK’s Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he is approaching the tariffs with a “calm and pragmatic approach … opting not to impose retaliatory measures.” The EU is prepared to negotiate to “remove any remaining barriers to Transatlantic trade” but is also “prepared to respond if negotiations fail,” according to European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. The current swing towards protectionism after decades of post-WW2 globalization trade policies will only lead to political destabilization and economic hardship on a global scale. Consumers will have to bear the burden of higher prices, and economic productivity will decline because of discouraging innovation, competition, and specialization. The last time the world faced a similar situation was in the 1930s when America’s Smoot-Hawley Tariff triggered a decline in international trade and deepened the Great Depression, which may have set the conditions for the outbreak of the Second World War. This stands as an ominous historical example of the devastating consequences a full-blown trade war can have.
What Does the Trump Administration Hope to Accomplish?
Trump downplayed the effect of his tariffs, saying, “The markets are going to boom, the stock is going to boom, the country is going to boom, and the rest of the world wants to see if there is any way they can make a deal.” However, one question on everyone’s minds amid the fallout is: What exactly does the Trump administration hope to achieve with these tariffs? To understand this, we need to take a closer look at the administration’s broader economic strategy—a plan to create a new global order, reverse deindustrialization, and eliminate trade deficits.
Reverse Deindustrialization and Trade Deficits.
Since the 1960s, deindustrialization has devastated America’s industrial heartland. In the 1950’s, manufacturing value added (VA) accounted for 28% of output. Today, that number is only 10%. The White House stated that the tariffs would “re-shore manufacturing and drive economic growth for the American people,” the president added that “jobs and factories will come roaring back.” While reindustrializing America is a noble pursuit, the Trump administration’s vehemence on tariffs as a solution is flawed. For decades, US companies have offshored manufacturing to evade higher labor and material costs, lack of operational factories capable of mass production, and an overvalued dollar hurting exports. It is unlikely that a large share of companies will move established supply chains back to the US and run the risk of skilled worker shortages, especially in a tumultuous economic climate where countries are slapping reciprocal tariffs onto each other. Additionally, employers could harm manufacturing jobs by adapting to higher production costs and reducing consumer demand by hiring freezes or layoffs. Trump’s tariffs may end up hurting the people they intend to help.
On trade deficits, Trump recently emphasized aboard Air Force 1 that the US “has massive deficits and we need to straighten that out. It cannot go on any longer.” However, Trump’s belief that the US is getting ripped off with every trade deficit is a zero-sum view of how the economy works. American economist Thomas Sowell notes, “If the goods and services available to the American people are greater as a result of international trade, then Americans are wealthier, not poorer, regardless of whether there is a deficit or a surplus.” The trade deficit does not stem from countries’ ruthless exploitation, rather the US’s own role as a global hegemony.
The Triffin Dilemma
In 1959, economist Robert Triffin exposed a fundamental paradox in the US’s role as the world’s reserve currency. When the dollar was designated as the global reserve currency at the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944, it gained the advantages and responsibility of pulling the levers of international finance by providing liquidity to the rest of the world. However, the US must continually inject large amounts of money into circulation to keep the global economy functioning. This surges its exchange rate and makes domestic exporting industries less competitive, leading to chronic trade deficits and higher inflation within the issuer’s borders. This poses a dilemma between balancing domestic economic interests and international responsibilities. The more the US prints dollars and runs deficits, the more fragile the confidence in the dollar becomes, leading to a scenario where countries lose confidence in the stability of the dollar. Eventually, the US will be forced to choose between continuing to supply global liquidity or protecting domestic economic interests. The tariffs are the first step in a “MAGA masterplan” of a new global order in which America relinquishes itself from international responsibility to protect domestic interests. If no countries are willing to comply with this new global order, then the US will likely be left with two options: give up its role as the global reserve currency or accept deficits as part and parcel of global trade. However, in an interview with Bloomberg News in Chicago, Trump recently vowed to protect the US’s role as the global reserve currency. In this case, Trump’s plan to eliminate trade deficits with soley tariffs is implausible.
How MSME’s Can Navigate Uncertain Times
Increased production costs, consumer prices, and supply-chain disruptions caused by tariffs will likely hurt MSMEs across the United States. Here are some tips for MSME owners to navigate these challenging times and maintain stable financial health for their businesses:
Seek professional assistance:
Occam’s Advisory’s strategic and functional services can help you develop a customized plan to mitigate the impact of tariffs and navigate these changes confidently.
Reevaluate your supply chain:
If your imports come from tariff-affected countries, explore alternative suppliers in non-tariffed regions or renegotiate prices/contracts with current suppliers.
Build up inventory:
To avoid short-term cost increases, consider stocking up on essential materials now before tariffs take effect in impacted countries.

Introduction
The digital realm is in constant flux, and the emergence of generative search engines, spearheaded by innovations like Google’s AI Overviews and Microsoft Copilot, marks a significant turning point for businesses online. This evolution presents both novel challenges and exciting opportunities. To thrive in this new landscape, a proactive strategy is essential. Enter Generative Engine Optimization (GEO), a forward-thinking approach that focuses on crafting content not just for human consumption, but also for optimal processing and understanding by artificial intelligence, all while upholding the principles of top-tier Search Engine Optimization (SEO).
Decoding GEO: Optimizing for the AI Era
At its core, GEO is a strategic evolution of traditional SEO. It recognizes that modern search engines are increasingly leveraging sophisticated AI models to understand user intent and generate direct answers or summaries. Therefore, GEO integrates established SEO best practices with a deep understanding of how these AI models analyze, interpret, and prioritize online content. By strategically applying GEO principles, businesses can ensure their content achieves dual visibility: ranking effectively in conventional search results and being prominently featured in AI-generated overviews and summaries.
Key Strategies for GEO Success: A Holistic Approach
To effectively implement GEO and maintain your SEO prowess, consider these crucial strategies:
Mastering Content Fluency and Structure:
Clarity and Conciseness are Paramount:
Employ straightforward language, avoiding jargon or overly complex sentence structures. This ensures both human readers and AI algorithms can easily grasp the core message.
Strategic Organization with Clear Signposts:
Structure your content logically using descriptive headings (H1, H2, H3, etc.) and subheadings. This hierarchical organization provides a clear roadmap for both readers and AI to navigate and understand the content’s key sections.
Enhancing Readability with Visual Aids:
Utilize bullet points and numbered lists to break down complex information into digestible segments. This improves scannability for humans and facilitates efficient information extraction for AI.
Amplifying Trust and Authority with E-E-A-T:
Demonstrate Comprehensive E-E-A-T:
Emphasize Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, and Trustworthiness throughout your content. This is not just a traditional SEO recommendation but a critical factor for AI to assess the credibility and value of your information.
Showcase Your Credibility:
Integrate personal anecdotes that highlight your direct experience, meticulously cite reliable and authoritative sources to back your claims, and prominently display relevant credentials, certifications, or affiliations. This builds trust with both your audience and AI algorithms.
Harmonizing Optimization for Humans and AI:
Craft Engaging and Understandable Content:
Write in a style that resonates with your target audience, maintaining clarity and interest. Avoid sacrificing human engagement for the sake of AI optimization.
Facilitate AI Extraction with Strategic Formatting:
Employ concise and informative headers and subheadings that accurately reflect the content within each section. This helps AI quickly identify and extract key information for generative summaries.
Strategically Leveraging AI in Content Creation:
Harness AI for Foundational Tasks:
Explore how AI tools can assist in the initial stages of content creation, such as outlining potential topics, brainstorming ideas, and conducting preliminary content analysis to identify gaps and opportunities.
Maintain Human Oversight and Accuracy:
Recognize that AI-generated content is a starting point, not the final product. Always subject AI-generated drafts to rigorous human editing, fact-checking, and brand voice alignment before publishing.
The Indispensable Role of Education and Consistency
In the rapidly evolving landscape of generative search, continuous learning is paramount. Invest in training initiatives to educate your team on the latest GEO trends, best practices, and algorithm updates. Staying informed will enable you to adapt your strategies proactively. Furthermore, consistency is the bedrock of long-term GEO success. Maintain your commitment to traditional SEO fundamentals while seamlessly integrating GEO techniques into your ongoing content strategy. This dual approach ensures sustained visibility and relevance across both traditional and generative search environments.
Generative search is fundamentally reshaping how users discover and interact with online information. By proactively embracing Generative Engine Optimization (GEO) and thoughtfully adapting your content strategy, your business can not only navigate this new era but also thrive within it. Remember that the key to success lies in consistently prioritizing the creation of high-quality, authoritative, and relevant content that captivates human readers while being readily understandable and valuable to AI algorithms. This balanced approach will ensure your continued visibility and competitiveness in the evolving world of search.

Everything You Need to Know About the Payment Protection Program (PPP)
The Payment Protection Program (PPP) is a crucial government initiative designed to provide financial support to businesses during times of economic uncertainty. This article provides comprehensive information about the PPP, including its benefits, eligibility criteria, and application process. By understanding the PPP, businesses can access the assistance they need to navigate challenging circumstances and ensure their financial stability.
What is the Payment Protection Program?
The Payment Protection Program is a loan program established by the Small Business Administration (SBA) in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Its primary objective is to help businesses retain their employees and cover essential expenses during periods of economic disruption.
Benefits and Eligibility of the Payment Protection Program
The Payment Protection Program offers several benefits to eligible businesses:
1. Loan Forgiveness: If businesses use the loan funds for approved expenses, such as payroll costs, rent, utilities, and mortgage interest, they may qualify for loan forgiveness. This means the loan amount can be entirely or partially forgiven, turning it into a grant.
2. Financial Support: The PPP provides businesses with the financial support they need to maintain their workforce and cover essential expenses during challenging times. This helps businesses avoid layoffs, retain talent, and sustain their operations.
Real-Life Scenarios: Businesses Benefiting from the PPP
1. ABC Restaurant, a small family-owned business, faced financial strain due to reduced customer demand during the pandemic. By successfully obtaining a PPP loan, they were able to retain their employees, cover rent and utility costs, and continue serving their community.
2. XYZ Retail Store experienced a significant decline in revenue and faced the possibility of permanent closure. Through the PPP, they secured the necessary funds to pay their employees, pivot their business model, and maintain their operations until the market conditions improved.

FAQs
How do I determine if my business is eligible for the Payment Protection Program?
Eligibility for the PPP is based on various factors, including business size, industry, and payroll costs. Consulting with a financial advisor or referring to the official guidelines from the SBA can help determine your business’s eligibility.
How can I apply for the Payment Protection Program?
To apply for the PPP, you need to submit an application to an approved lender. The SBA website provides a list of participating lenders and the necessary forms and documentation required for the application process.
What expenses can be covered by the PPP loan funds?
The PPP loan funds can be used for approved expenses, including payroll costs, rent, utilities, mortgage interest, and certain operational expenses. However, a portion of the loan must be used for payroll costs to qualify for full loan forgiveness.
How does loan forgiveness work under the Payment Protection Program?
To qualify for loan forgiveness, businesses must use at least 60% of the loan funds for payroll costs and the remaining 40% for eligible non-payroll expenses. They must also maintain employee headcount and salary levels during the specified period. Detailed guidelines and documentation requirements can be found on the SBA website.
Conclusion
In conclusion, the Payment Protection Program (PPP) offers essential financial support to businesses during times of economic uncertainty. By understanding the benefits, eligibility criteria, and application process of the PPP, businesses can access the assistance they need to maintain their operations, retain employees, and ensure financial stability. Strengthen your business and personal financial status
When you face challenges with asset security, concentrate on the task of not only optimising money, but also protecting it:
Buy protection against liability. Don't slip into a mistaken sense of confidence. A single entity's limited liability cover would not preclude the need for liability insurance, both for the corporation and for you directly. In order to defend yourself from lawsuits that allow a "piercing of the corporate veil." you need individual umbrella coverage. Carefully set up sums and forms of liability coverage for your corporation tailored to its unique requirements and asset worth, as well as coverage for your assets outside the company.
Seeking an equilibrium
Balancing the cash needs of the organisation with your longer-term personal financial ambitions is not always straightforward. But choices in this balance will make or break your company—and your personal financial statement. Usually, rising and profitable firms require financing. Indeed to reduce its borrowing or capital needs, you will benefit from holding as much as possible of your available assets in the business. You might even lend capital back when it's required by the company.
Be wary, however,
Remember your personal financial interests and your desire to defend your investments from the creditors of your corporation. This is exactly why in the first place, you formed a different agency for your organisation. You have to determine if the risks and the ability for them dictate that now you are searching for other funding or investing in equity.
Buy insurance for life
It's clear that with sufficient life insurance, you need to cover your company and families. And proper insurance forms and amounts will prevent the family from being compelled to sell the firm to cover future estate taxes. But don't stop there with your preparation. Bear in mind that your family might suffer crippling economic hardship from missed business profits after your death. In several cases, sufficient life insurance will help—for example, through:
Providing funds to other owners or main workers to buy out the interest of your family,
Heading off a cash shortage that might otherwise result in a swift selling of the firm at a deep discount
Giving the firm the requisite time and funding to make improvements and restore it to profitability.
Go For The Gap
Your family and you deserve the same consideration as your company. Don't let the sun shine on your company for too long — even secure your personal assets: think shared tenancy. Try transferring possession to your partner in order to protect your home from the control of your company or personal creditors. Or instead, in states where it is an option, move to tenancy by the entirety. Not the same security is provided by regular joint tenancy.
Keep properties in distinct organisations
You can secure these properties to some degree from future creditors by placing real estate or financial assets into a limited partnership. They will not be able to convert their investment into cash, even though creditors can take partner interests. Or propose setting up an Alaska, Delaware or offshore trust to shield creditors from your investment funds. Assets granted to you by others such as donations or inheritances) can be more conveniently secured by trusts formed locally that maintain the interest transferred to you as a beneficiary.
Safely Save
Registered savings programmes provide substantial advantages, including private retirement accounts and 401(k) plans. Contribute as far as you can afford to the legal limits and your business. You'll earn income tax savings while offering a better place to store some of your investment funds at the same time. Generally, either corporate or entity eligible schemes will not be attained by creditors. Introduction
Investing is a cornerstone of wealth creation and financial security. It goes beyond simply saving money—
it’s about making your money work for you.
Whether you’re a seasoned investor or just starting, understanding the power of investing can help you achieve long-term financial goals and protect your future against economic uncertainties.
Why Investing Matters?
Investing allows you to grow your wealth over time by leveraging compounding, market dynamics, and asset growth. Unlike saving, where your funds are static, investing multiplies your money by tapping into the growth of markets, businesses, or properties.
•
Inflation Protection:
Inflation erodes the purchasing power of money. Investing helps counter this by generating returns that typically outpace inflation.
•
Wealth Creation:
Through consistent investment, even small amounts grow exponentially over time, thanks to compound interest.
For example, investing $200 monthly with an average annual return of 8% could grow to over $120,000 in 20 years—a dramatic increase compared to keeping the same amount in a savings account.
“The individual investor should act consistently as an investor and not as a speculator.”
– Benjamin Graham, The Intelligent Investor
Graham’s insight highlights the importance of a disciplined, long-term approach to investing rather than chasing quick profits.
The Magic of Compounding
Compounding is often referred to as the eighth wonder of the world. It works by reinvesting earnings to generate additional returns. Essentially, your money starts earning money.
Example of Compounding:
•
Monthly Investment Growth:
The longer your investment horizon, the greater the portion of your total balance attributed to growth rather than your initial contributions.
Imagine investing
$200 per month
with an annual return of
8%.
In 10 years:
You’d accumulate approximately
$36,000
, of which about
$12,000
is growth.
In 20 years:
Your investment grows to
$120,000
, with around
$72,000
being growth.
In 30 years:
It balloons to over
$300,000
, where nearly
$228,000
comes from compounding.
• Lump-Sum Investment Growth: Even a single investment can generate significant wealth with enough time.
Let’s say you make a one-time investment of $10,000 at an annual return of 10%:
After 10 years:
Your investment grows to
$25,937.
After 20 years:
It reaches
$67,275.
After 30 years:
It skyrockets to
$174,494.
“Time is your friend; impulse is your enemy. Take advantage of compound interest and don’t be captivated by the siren song of the market.”
– John C. Bogle, The Little Book of Common Sense Investing
Bogle’s words emphasize patience as the key to benefiting from the snowballing effects of compounding.
Types of Investments
The investment world offers a variety of options tailored to different financial goals and risk appetites:
•
Stocks:
Ownership in a company, offering high growth potential but also higher risks.
•
Bonds:
Debt instruments providing steady income with lower risk than stocks.
•
Real Estate:
Tangible assets that offer both income (through rent) and capital appreciation.
•
Mutual Funds & ETFs:
Diversified options for spreading risk across multiple assets.
•
Cryptocurrency:
A volatile but potentially high-reward emerging investment option.
Diversifying across asset classes helps manage risk while maximizing returns.
“The stock market is filled with individuals who know the price of everything, but the value of nothing.”
– Philip Fisher, Common Stocks and Uncommon Profits
This quote encourages investors to focus on the intrinsic value of assets rather than market trends.
Risk and Reward
All investments come with risks, but understanding and managing those risks is crucial to success.
•
Risk Tolerance:
Your financial situation, age, and goals determine how much risk you can take. Younger investors may favor riskier investments like stocks, while older individuals may lean towards safer assets like bonds.
•
Market Volatility:
Markets fluctuate, but historically, they have shown growth over the long term. Patience and staying invested are key to weathering short-term dips.
“The key to growing wealth is to have an investment strategy and stay the course, even during challenging times.”
– Tony Robbins, Unshakeable
Robbins reminds us that consistent action and resilience are crucial in the face of market volatility.
The Importance of Starting Early
All investments come with risks, but understanding and managing those risks is crucial to success.
•
Risk Tolerance:
Your financial situation, age, and goals determine how much risk you can take. Younger investors may favor riskier investments like stocks, while older individuals may lean towards safer assets like bonds.
•
Market Volatility:
Markets fluctuate, but historically, they have shown growth over the long term. Patience and staying invested are key to weathering short-term dips.
“The key to growing wealth is to have an investment strategy and stay the course, even during challenging times.”
– Tony Robbins, Unshakeable
Robbins reminds us that consistent action and resilience are crucial in the face of market volatility.
The earlier you start investing, the more time your money has to grow. Consider this:
•
Investor A:
Starts investing $5,000 annually at age 25 and stops at age 35, investing for 10 years.
•
Investor B:
Starts investing $5,000 annually at age 35 and continues until age 65, investing for 30 years.
Results at age 65
(assuming an 8% annual return):
Investor A:
Despite investing for only 10 years, Alex ends up with
$787,180.
Investor B:
Despite investing for 30 years, Ben ends up with
$611,730.
Despite investing for a shorter time, Investor A ends up with more money at age 65 due to the power of compounding. Time is a crucial ingredient in investment success. Starting early can result in higher wealth, even with fewer contributions, because of the longer compounding period
“It’s not how much money you make, but how much money you keep, how hard it works for you, and how many generations you keep it for.”
– Robert Kiyosaki, Rich Dad Poor Dad
Kiyosaki’s insight underscores the importance of putting money to work through wise investments.
Investing for Goals
Investing helps you align your money with life’s big goals:
•
Retirement:
Building a corpus to ensure a comfortable post-retirement life.

Is Your Business Prepared For These 5 Common Digital Payment Methods?
May 24 2021 |
Occams Marketing
100
0
Pay management, like the rest of our planet, is becoming increasingly automated. Here are five different types of digital payment methods that your company can use to complete purchases.
Businesses and customers alike are looking for quicker, simpler, and more efficient payment options as cash becomes obsolete, and contactless transactions, particularly in light of COVID-19, are in high demand. Consumers would prefer to use five common digital payment methods in the coming years.
What are the different types of digital payment services?
Contactless, cashless, and paperless payment systems are also examples of
digital payment services
. Via services like smartphone applications and AI/machine learning, technology has enabled the world to accept these more accessible payment exchanges. According to Statista, the number of people who use digital payments will increase by 5.4 percent by 2020.
Different types of digital payment systems are available.
Today, a variety of digital payment methods are common. Here are five of the most common payment methods for businesses to use:
1. Biometric identification devices
Customers are making more digital purchases, which raises the need for surveillance. Biometric protection protects against identity theft and fraud by using fingerprint scanners, facial recognition, iris recognition, pulse tracking, and vein visualization.
Many phones with digital wallets, such as Apple Pay and Google Pay, currently use fingerprint or facial recognition, but more options are being created. Instead of inserting a PIN code or signing a receipt, Visa is testing a biometric payment card that allows users to authenticate a transaction by pressing a sensor on the card that can decide whether the fingerprint is a match.
Per year, over 18 billion biometric transactions are projected to take place by 2021. As a company owner, it’s important to safeguard your data as well as that of your clients, and biometric security is a promising way to accomplish those goals.
2. Point of sale on the go (mPOS)
Businesses should prioritise convenient payment processing now, as there will be 27.7 million EmPOS devices by 2021, up from 3.2 million in 2014. Tablets, laptops, and other cellular gadgets that use an interface and a card reader to accept purchases like a cash register are known as mobile POS schemes.
This allows companies to do away with a central check-out area and take purchases from anywhere in their shop, including from off-site. You should, for example, take the payment system to a trade show or other off-site venue without thinking about how purchases will be handled. Customers will use the card reader connected to your computer to swipe their credit or debit cards and make an immediate buy – it’s that easy.
Note from the editor: Are you looking for the best credit card processor for your company? Fill out the form below to have one of our vendor partners ask you about your requirements.
3. Wireless speakers
Voice instructions are no longer a far-fetched notion. Consumers may make an immediate deposit or order by using smart speakers such as Google Home, Apple HomePod, and Amazon Echo. In reality, 35% of consumers use their smart speakers to purchase items such as home care, groceries, and clothes.
Any customers are concerned that this is not the safest way to make transactions. Nonetheless, by 2022, this digital payment pattern is expected to reach 77.9 million people (up from 18.4 million users in 2017). With this kind of development on the horizon, it’ll be critical to customise your web shop for voice search so that your company can be found using smart speakers.
4. Payment through contactless technology
Users can move money, buy goods, pay bills, and complete nearly every other form of financial transaction with the tap of a finger using a variety of mobile payment applications. Purchasing products and services using a cell phone is simple and convenient when you have an account and store your payment information in it.
Venmo (which is also useful for peer-to-peer payments), PayPal, Google Pay (previously known as Google Wallet), Apple Pay, and Samsung Pay are all examples of this technology. Allowing consumers to make electronic payments through their bank app/digital wallet or other mobile payment applications provides an unparalleled level of convenience.
Contactless payment systems come with a price tag. To begin, you’ll need to buy card terminals that support near-field communication technology. Accepting Apple Pay and Google Pay is free, but when customers use a credit card to pay for products or services in your store, premiums and fees apply much as any other credit card purchase. (These are referred to as card-present transactions.) You should inquire about these particular prices for your processor.
Many customers choose these strategies because they believe they are simpler and faster than counting money or swiping a credit card. It’s also much easier to access for the many customers who are always using their phones.
Phone wallets aren’t the only way to make contactless payments. RFID technology, which is used for contactless purchases, is also available on new credit cards. Customers who use a contactless credit card actually keep the card next to the card reader instead of swiping it, inserting it into a card reader, or tapping it against the terminal.
5. Payment options on social media
Payment options, such as exchanging money from one person to the next (P2P payments) or from customers to merchants, are also available directly within social media networks.
When it comes to shopping, the majority of millennials use social media. According to an Animoto survey, a brand’s social networking visibility influences 75 percent of millennials’ buying decisions.
Facebook, Instagram, and Pinterest all have business profiles that allow brands to sell to customers for a small price, with digital payment purchases taking place directly on the web. According to a 2018 Avionos survey, 55% of online shoppers have made a purchase through a social media site.
Consumers have driven changes in payment systems ahead. The use of numerous alternate payment mechanisms, such as those mentioned above, will continue to grow, while the use of cash and credit cards, in particular, will continue to decline, as shown by the Avionos market survey.

Supreme Court Upholds Tax on Foreign Investments in Moore vs. United States
Sep 11 2024 |
Veer Agarwal

▷
Understanding the MRT Provision
▷

▷
Victory For the Status Quo
▷
Good News For the Moore Wealthy
▷
Sources/Citations
Introduction
On June 20th, the Supreme Court was tasked with determining whether or not to blow the U.S. tax code in the case Moore vs. United States. In a 7-2 majority ruling, the court ruled against a Washington couple’s challenge to federal taxation on income generated from their foreign investments. Writing for the majority, Justice Brett Kavanaugh stated, “The MRT [Mandatory Repatriation Act] — which attributes the realized and undistributed income of an American-controlled foreign corporation to the entity’s American shareholders, and then taxes the American shareholders on their portions of that income — “does not exceed Congress’s constitutional authority.”
Justice Brett Kavanaugh Struck Down Couple’s Tax Challenge Photo illustration by Slate. Photo by cei.org/YouTube and Shawn Thew /Pool/AFP via Getty Images.
Understanding the MRT Provision
Before the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) — a comprehensive tax reform package signed into law by former President Donald Trump in 2017 — U.S. taxpayers with ownership stakes in foreign companies were exempt from paying taxes until the company profits were distributed to them. However, the passage of TCJA, particularly the MRT provision, implemented a one-time tax requirement for American shareholders of profitable foreign corporations, regardless of whether those profits were repatriated back to the U.S. The act intended to offset revenue losses projected from the significant tax cuts included as another key component of TCJA and address the trillions of dollars of undistributed income that was being held by mega-corporations such as Apple, Google, and Facebook without tax consequences to American shareholders.
A key component of TCJA was the MRT Provision (Mandatory Repatriation Tax) (Photo illustration by Freed Maxick
https://blog.freedmaxick.com/summing-it-up/mandatory-repatriation-toll-tax-of-income-earned-by-controlled-foreign-entities
)
The Prosecution’s Argument
According to the Moores, the MRT provision went beyond congressional authority by placing taxes on unrealized income and essentially directly taxing their wealth, which according to the Sixteenth Amendment, must be apportioned among the States. Kavanaugh rejected this assertion in a footnote of his opinion, where he drew a distinction between direct taxes “imposed on persons or property” and indirect taxes such as MRT, a consumption tax “imposed on activities and transactions.” Thus, the Court’s decision upheld the Sixteenth Amendment’s provision on indirect taxes as part of income, affirming Congress’s power to “collect taxes on all incomes, from whatever source derived.”
Victory For the Status Quo
Before the case ruling, there appeared to be a nervous stir among corporate America that a decision in favor of the Moore’s would send shock waves through the U.S economy by upending the tax code. A victory for the plaintiffs would have cost Washington trillions of dollars in tax revenue by rendering existing tax provisions that target unrealized income such as the CAMT, GILTI, and subpart F income unconstitutional. Additionally, a proposed global minimum tax deal named “Pillar Two,” which aims to impose a 15% tax on multinational corporations’ foreign income, would be constitutionally cumbersome to implement in the U.S. with an opposite ruling. Moreover, this decision will likely bode well for corporate taxpayers seeking certainty in how their business pays taxes. Had the ruling gone differently and MRT was deemed unconstitutional, taxpayers who filed state corporate or personal income taxes under MRT may have been eligible for protective refund claims subject to limitation periods and state policies. Ultimately, the decision in Moore has preserved the status quo and calmed a storm that threatened to dismantle the tax code.
https://www.crfb.org/blogs/moore-v-us-ruling-could-widen-deficits-upend-tax-law
Good News For the Moore Wealthy
That is not to say the decision does not have immediate implications, however, as progressives committed to enacting an Elizabeth Warren style wealth tax may have been dealt a final nail in the coffin when reading Kavanaugh’s opinion that makes slight suggestions on the unconstitutionality of such legislation. Based on his definition of a direct tax being applied on the wealth or “property” of an individual and an indirect tax on income derived from that wealth, a wealth tax would likely fall under the domain of a direct tax that would fail to abide by the Sixteenth Amendment’s apportionment requirement.

In 2025, Brands That Embrace Art Will Lead the Future

Introduction
▷
A Return to Art as the Core of Branding
▷
Building Brands as Worlds, Not Just Products
▷
From Transactions to Cultural Movements
Introduction
When you close your eyes and picture a tube of toothpaste, it’s likely that something resembling Colgate flashes in your mind. That moment — that instant brand recall — isn’t an accident. It’s the product of decades of deliberate, consistent storytelling. Throughout the 20th century, leading brands didn’t just capture market share; they captured imagination. They shaped the way we think about entire categories. In that era, challengers had little choice but to mimic — to look like the best in the hope of someday standing alongside them.
But the rules have changed.
In 2025, consumers don’t simply buy products. They buy meaning. They don’t see a pair of sneakers or a soda can as just merchandise — they see a reflection of values, personality, and identity. A product’s utility remains important, but it is no longer enough. What matters just as much is the story it tells, the community it signals, and the feeling it evokes. Brands today are not fighting for shelf space; they are fighting for emotional space in people’s lives.
If your business isn’t steering with these five objectives at the core, it’s time to reassess your strategy. Here’s what you need to know:
A Return to Art as the Core of Branding
Ironically, at a time when marketing has become a sophisticated science of algorithms and A/B tests, the answer to deeper brand loyalty lies not in better data but in better art. This is not a return to romanticism for its own sake — it’s a strategic imperative. Historically, commerce and creativity have been intertwined. In Renaissance Europe, patrons like the Medici family commissioned art not merely for beauty, but for influence and legacy. Closer to our times, brands like Chanel, Absolut, and Coca-Cola understood that aligning with culture — through collaboration with artists and the language of visual storytelling — transcended conventional advertising.
Yet somewhere along the path to modern efficiency, branding became divorced from artistry. Scale demanded uniformity. Reach demanded simplicity. Marketing became formulaic, driven more by clicks than by culture. But culture, as ever, remains stubbornly resistant to formulas. The resurgence we are witnessing today — a shift back to brand building as an act of creativity, meaning-making, and world-building — is both inevitable and essential.
Building Brands as Worlds, Not Just Products
At Occams Advisory, as we expanded our digital brand storytelling capabilities, it became clear that the brands poised to thrive in this new environment are those who treat creativity as infrastructure, not garnish. Investing early in thoughtful design, coherent narratives, and emotionally intelligent communication isn’t an indulgence. It’s survival. In our work across diverse industries, we’ve seen that brands who integrate storytelling deeply into their identity from day one build something far more valuable than awareness: they build belief.
This is why branding today demands a different kind of partnership. The era of “influencers” is giving way to an era of “co-creators.” Working with artists — illustrators, musicians, digital creators — is no longer a tactic for buzz; it’s a strategy for authenticity. Great brands aren’t borrowing someone else’s audience for a fleeting campaign; they are inviting new perspectives into their world, allowing their story to be reshaped and reimagined by creative minds. Done right, these collaborations create layers of meaning that marketing departments alone could never manufacture.
But even the most compelling story risks fading if it remains a one-way broadcast. Today’s strongest brands understand that real loyalty stems from community, not just consumption. Audiences can be bought with media budgets; communities are built through trust and shared values. Brands like Glossier, Aime Leon Dore, and others show us that customers don’t just want products — they want membership, participation, and co-ownership in a broader narrative. Community today isn’t a side effect of good marketing; it is the marketing.
Observing these shifts up close — in our internal brand work and through partnerships where storytelling and design drive customer experience — reinforces a larger truth. Building a brand today is not a sprint to attention; it is an invitation to belonging. And that belonging must be earned through consistent creativity, respect for your audience’s intelligence, and an unwavering commitment to meaning over mechanics.
From Transactions to Cultural Movements
Looking ahead, the brands that will matter most won’t necessarily be the ones with the biggest ad spend or the most polished performance campaigns. They will be the ones that act more like cultural institutions than commercial enterprises — ones that use design, language, and digital experiences to spark connection, reflection, and even movement. Brands that feel like art — unpredictable, emotive, courageous — will not only thrive but define their industries.
The tools we have today — from digital storytelling platforms to sophisticated design ecosystems — make it easier than ever to build a brand with depth and artistry. But tools alone are not enough. What is required is intent: the intent to create something enduring, not just attention-grabbing. The intent to matter, not just to sell.
In a world increasingly shaped by algorithms, it’s tempting to believe that branding can be reduced to optimization. But the brands that will lead us into the next decade are those that remember what technology alone cannot replicate: the human need for beauty, meaning, and connection.
In the end, it is art — not marketing — that leaves a mark.

Introduction
The
Corporate Transparency Act (CTA), passed in 2021
, marks a significant change in the way businesses operate in the United States. This act mandates that many companies, including small and medium-sized businesses, disclose information about their beneficial owners, those who ultimately control or own a significant portion of the company, to the
Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
. This article aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the CTA, its purpose, and the steps businesses need to take to comply.
The Purpose of the CTA: Combating Illicit Finance and Promoting Transparency
The CTA’s primary purpose is to combat illicit financial activities, including money laundering, tax fraud, and terrorism financing. These criminal activities often exploit opaque corporate structures to conceal the true identities of individuals behind illegal operations. By requiring disclosure of beneficial ownership information, the CTA aims to make it more difficult for criminals to hide behind shell companies and engage in financial crimes. Increased transparency allows law enforcement agencies to trace illicit funds, identify perpetrators, and dismantle criminal networks.
Who Must File a Beneficial Ownership Information (BOI) Report?
The CTA’s reporting requirements apply to a broad range of companies, categorized as either domestic or foreign reporting companies.
Domestic Reporting Companies
Domestic reporting companies are those formed within the United States, typically by filing documents with the Secretary of State or a similar office. This category includes corporations, limited liability companies (LLCs), and other entities created through state or tribal government filings.
Examples of domestic reporting companies:
A Delaware Limited Liability Company
A California For-Profit Corporation
A Florida Homeowner’s Association
A Texas General Partnership
A Massachusetts Tribal Organization
Foreign Reporting Companies
Foreign reporting companies are formed under the laws of a foreign country and registered to do business in a U.S. state or tribal jurisdiction.
Examples of foreign reporting companies:
A Colombian LTDA registered to do business in Florida
A Cayman Island LP registered to do business in Delaware
A Swiss Cooperative registered to do business in New York
Exemptions from Filing a BOI Report
While the CTA’s reach is extensive, the legislation recognizes that certain types of companies are already subject to significant regulatory scrutiny and disclosure requirements. Therefore, the CTA provides 23 categories of exemptions.
The most notable exemptions include:
Companies in highly regulated environments:
This includes entities such as banks, credit unions, insurance companies, and publicly traded companies. These entities already provide ownership information to regulatory bodies.
Certain registered or “large” investment companies:
Investment companies registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) are generally exempt, as are large investment funds that meet specific asset and investor thresholds.
Tax-exempt entities and their assisting entities:
Non-profit organizations with 501(c) status, charities, and certain trusts are generally exempt, along with entities that support these tax-exempt organizations.
Large operating companies:
Companies with a substantial U.S. presence, defined as having:
More than 20 full-time employees in the U.S.
An operating presence at a physical office in the U.S.
More than $5 million in gross receipts or sales reported on the previous year’s federal tax return.
Subsidiaries of certain exempt entities:
Subsidiaries of companies that are already exempt, such as subsidiaries of publicly traded companies, may also be exempt from filing.
Inactive entities:
Entities that are not actively conducting business operations are typically exempt from filing.
Identifying Beneficial Owners: Who They Are and What They Do
The CTA’s definition of a beneficial owner centers around two key concepts: substantial control and ownership interest.
Substantial Control
A beneficial owner can be an individual who exercises “substantial control” over a company, even without holding a significant ownership stake.
Individuals who might exercise substantial control include:
Senior officers:
This includes positions such as president, CEO, CFO, COO, general counsel, or other senior officers performing similar functions.
Individuals with appointment or removal authority:
Those who can appoint or remove senior officers, including a majority of the board of directors, may exert substantial control.
Important decision makers:
Individuals who can influence significant company decisions, such as those involving mergers, acquisitions, major asset disposals, or changes in the nature of the business, might be deemed to have substantial control.
Ownership Interest
The more straightforward definition of a beneficial owner is an individual who owns or controls at least 25% of a company’s ownership interests.
“Ownership interests” are broadly defined to include:
Equity, stock, or voting rights:
This includes traditional shares of stock, membership interests in an LLC, and other forms of ownership that grant voting rights.
Capital or profit interests:
This category encompasses interests in companies structured as partnerships or LLCs, where ownership is represented by a share of profits or capital.
Convertible instruments:
These are financial instruments that can be converted into equity or ownership interests in the future, such as convertible bonds or warrants.
Options or privileges:
Rights or agreements that give an individual the option to acquire equity or ownership interests, even if they don’t currently own them, are considered ownership interests.
Catch-all provision:
The definition also includes any other contract, instrument, or mechanism established under applicable law that confers substantial control or ownership, ensuring a comprehensive scope.
Understanding Company Applicants
For companies formed or first registered on or after January 1, 2024, the CTA introduces the concept of a “company applicant.” This refers to the individual who files the paperwork to create the company or registers a foreign company to do business in the U.S. If multiple individuals are involved in the filing process, the company applicant is typically the person primarily responsible for directing or controlling the filing.
What Information Must Be Disclosed in a BOI Report?
A BOI report requires information about both the reporting company itself and its beneficial owners and company applicants.
Reporting Company Information
The company section of the report requires:
Full legal name:
The official, registered name of the company.
Any trade or “doing business as” names:
If the company operates under a different name than its legal name.
Complete current street address of the principal U.S. place of business:
This is the primary location where the company conducts business activities.
The state, tribal or foreign jurisdiction of formation:
Where the company was legally established.
The IRS Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN):
For U.S. companies, this is typically an Employer Identification Number (EIN). Foreign companies may need to provide a tax identification number issued by their home jurisdiction.
Beneficial Owners and Company Applicants Information
For each beneficial owner and company applicant, the following information must be provided:
Full legal name:
The individual’s complete legal name as it appears on official documents.
Date of birth:
The individual’s date of birth.
Current residential street address:
The current residential address of the individual. Company applicants acting in the course of their business should provide their business address.
An identifying number from an acceptable document:
This can be a driver’s license number, passport number, or other government-issued identification number.
An image of the identifying document:
A clear copy of the document from which the identifying number was obtained is required.
Filing Deadlines: Meeting the CTA’s Timeframes
Meeting the CTA’s filing deadlines is crucial to avoid penalties. The deadlines vary based on the company’s formation date.
Companies formed or registered before January 1, 2024:
These companies have until
January 13, 2025,
to file their initial BOI report.
Companies formed or first registered in 2024:
These companies must file their initial report within
90 calendar days
of receiving notice that their creation or registration became effective.
Ongoing Reporting Obligations: Keeping Information Current
The CTA’s reporting requirements are not a one-time event. Companies have a continuing obligation to keep their BOI information updated. Any changes to the information previously reported, such as changes in beneficial owners, company addresses, or control structures, must be reported to FinCEN within 30 days of the change.
Penalties for Non-Compliance: The Consequences of Inaction
The CTA imposes significant penalties for failing to comply with its reporting requirements, including both civil and criminal penalties.
Civil Penalties
Companies that do not file a BOI report or fail to update their information timely can face civil penalties of up to $591 for each day the violation continues, potentially resulting in substantial fines.
Criminal Penalties
Willful failure to report complete or updated beneficial ownership information, or providing false or fraudulent information, can lead to criminal fines of up to $10,000, imprisonment for up to two years, or both.
How to File a BOI Report: Options for Submission
Companies have two main options for filing their BOI reports.
FinCEN’s Online Portal
FinCEN provides a secure online portal for companies to file their BOI reports electronically. This portal is accessible through FinCEN’s website (FinCEN.gov).

Factors Contributing to the Rent Payment Crisis
Various factors contribute to the rent payment crisis among small businesses. Some of these factors include:
1. Economic Downturn: The recent economic downturn has led to decreased consumer spending, impacting businesses’ ability to generate revenue.
2. Pandemic Aftermath: The ongoing effects of the COVID-19 pandemic have left many businesses with reduced capacity and increased operating costs.
3. Rising Rent Prices: Rent prices have continued to rise, putting further strain on small business budgets.
Real-Life Scenarios
Scenario 1: A local coffee shop has experienced a significant decline in foot traffic due to remote work and social distancing measures. This, coupled with rising rent prices, has made it increasingly difficult for the owner to cover their monthly expenses.
Scenario 2: A small retail store faced temporary closure during the pandemic. Despite reopening, the store has struggled to regain its pre-pandemic customer base, leading to lower revenue and an inability to pay rent.
Potential Solutions for Small Businesses
4. Government Assistance Programs: Small business owners can explore government-funded programs, such as low-interest loans or grants, to help cover expenses during difficult times.
5. Rent Negotiations: Businesses may be able to negotiate more favorable rent terms with their landlords, such as rent reductions or deferrals.
6. Business Model Adaptation: Small businesses can adapt their business models to fit the changing economic climate, such as pivoting to online sales or offering new services.
FAQs
What percentage of small businesses are struggling to pay rent?
41% of small businesses are currently struggling to pay rent.
What factors contribute to the rent payment crisis among small businesses?
Factors include the economic downturn, pandemic aftermath, and rising rent prices.
What solutions can help small businesses overcome rent payment difficulties?
Solutions include government assistance programs, rent negotiations, and business model adaptation.
How can small businesses access financial assistance programs?
Small businesses can apply for financial assistance programs through participating lenders or directly through the Small Business Administration.
Conclusion
In summary, the rent payment crisis among small businesses is a pressing issue that requires immediate attention. By understanding the contributing factors and exploring potential solutions, business owners can better navigate these challenging times and work towards a brighter future.

Introduction
Starting
January 1st, 2024
, the
Corporate Transparency Act (CTA)
brought significant changes to reporting requirements for registered businesses in the United States. Enacted by Congress to combat illicit activities such as tax fraud, money laundering, and terrorism financing, the CTA requires U.S. small business owners meeting certain criteria to file a Beneficial Ownership Information (BOI) report to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN). As the submission deadline of
January 1st, 2025
looms, this white paper aims to provide key information on the act’s background and offer small business owners clarity on maintaining compliance.
Background
The CTA was passed as part of a larger reform bill called The National Defense Authorization Act of 2021. At the time, CTA was not the main focus: other provisions, such as advancing AI R&D, allocating $740 billion to the Pentagon, and renaming military bases previously named after Confederate leaders garnered most of the attention among Congressmen. Nonetheless, the act was consequential as it meant the creation of a federal database tracking the beneficial ownership of U.S entities, enhancing business transparency and empowering the government to better detect and investigate concealed financial crimes. However, amid global and domestic issues such as the unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic and a post-election America, the act went under the radar of lawmakers and small business owners alike. Since put into effect on January 1, 2024, though, the act has required 30 million businesses to understand and comply with Beneficial Ownership Information (BOI) filing requirements or face harsh penalties, including daily fines of $500, fines of up to $10,000, and up to 2 years in jail.
Understanding Key CTA Terms
Reporting Company
includes corporations, LLCs, or similar entities registered to the business in The United States by filing a document with the Secretary of State. Thus, they are required to file a BOI report. However, 23 types of entities outlined in FinCEN’s Small Entity Compliance Guide are exempt from filing.
Beneficial Owners
are individuals who, directly or indirectly, have substantial control over a reporting company or own at least 25% of its ownership interests. Indirect ownership can take various forms, including convertible instruments, capital or profit interests, and equity or stock holdings.
A company applicant
is either: a) The individual who directly files the document that creates or registers the entity, or b) The individual who is primarily responsible for directing or controlling such filing if more than one individual is involved in the filing of the document.
(Photo Illustration By NAIOP)
https://www.naiopmd.org/news/what-to-know-about-the-corporate-transparency-act/
Reporting Requirements
Reporting companies must provide the following information about its company:
Legal name
Trade names
Current U.S. business address:
Principal place of business for U.S.-based companies
Address of U.S. operations for foreign companies
Jurisdiction information
IRS taxpayer identification number (EIN / TIN).
Reporting companies must provide the following information about beneficial owners and company applicants:
Legal name
Date Of Birth
Current Address
An identification document with a unique identifying number, name of the state or jurisdiction that issued the acceptable identification document, and an image of the acceptable identification document.
Who can access my BOI report?
In its “Access Rule,” FinCEN has outlined the following recipients authority access a company’s BOI reports:
Federal law enforcement agencies
State, local, and tribal law enforcement agencies with court authorization
Financial institutions, with customer consent, for customer due diligence purposes
Federal functional regulators and other appropriate regulatory agencies
Foreign law enforcement agencies, via requests made by U.S. federal agencies
U.S. Treasury Department officials for tax administration

What are the major debt categories?
Dec 15 2020 |
Occams Marketing
113
0
In their lives, most Americans face some sort of debt. Not all loans, though are produced equally and some are deemed better than others. Indeed, although debt comes in different ways, it is possible to categorise all personal debt (not corporate or government debt) into a few large categories, including secured debt, unsecured debt, revolving debt, and mortgages.
Secured Debt
For collateral purposes, secured debt is any debt backed by an asset. For the lender to judge how prudent debt has been treated in the past, a credit check is required, but the asset is promised to the lender in the event that the creditor does not repay the loan. The lender has the option to seize the asset if the debt is not paid back.
Secured debt, unsecured debt, revolving lending, and mortgages are the key forms of personal debt.
Any type of collateral is required for secured debt, whereas unsecured debt is strictly dependent on the creditworthiness of an individual.
A credit card is an example of unsecured revolving debt, and a protected revolving debt is a home equity line of credit.
Mortgages are mortgage loans that usually have periods of 15 to 30 years, with equity acting as the real estate.
An example of secured lending is an auto loan. A loan provides you with the funds required to buy it but also puts a lien, or assertion of possession, on the title of the car. The seller will repossess the vehicle and auction it in order to reclaim the funds in the event that the car buyer fails to make payments. Secured loans like these have a reasonably rational interest rate, which is normally dependent on the value of the collateral and creditworthiness.
The Unsecured Loans
Any collateral lacks unsecured loans. If a loan with no asset held as collateral is made by an investor, it does so only on the confidence in the potential and promise of the borrower to repay the loan. The creditor is entitled by a binding obligation to return the cash, and the lender may go to court to recover any money owed if there is a default. Nevertheless, doing so comes at a considerable cost to the lender, and for this reason, unsecured lending typically comes at a higher rate of interest. Credit cards, signature loans, gym membership arrangements, and hospital bills are other forms of unsecured debt.
Debt Rotating
Revolving debt is an arrangement between a lender and a borrower which requires the consumer, on a recurring basis, to borrow an amount up to the maximum limit. Examples of revolving loans include a line of credit or a credit card. A credit card has a credit cap, and once the limit is met, the user is free to pay any amount below the limit. Revolving mortgage payment rates differ depending on the amount of funds actually on credit. As in the case of a credit card, revolving debt may be unsecured or covered, such as on a home equity line of credit.
Mortgages
The most popular and largest debt many consumers hold is mortgages. Mortgages are loans made for the purchase of properties, with equity acting as the subject house. Usually, a mortgage has the lowest interest rate of any personal loan option, and for those who itemise their returns, the interest is also tax deductible. Mortgage loans are often often given on 15- to 30-year contracts to keep homeowners' mortgage payments manageable.
