Background
It is no rumor that the United States is in a national debt crisis. The debt stands at about $36 trillion, rising a staggering 122% since 2014 and continuing to rise rapidly. The last budget surpluses for the U.S. government came during fiscal years 1998-2001 when President Bill Clinton worked with a Republican-controlled Congress on a bipartisan budget deal to cut the deficit (Clinton White House Archives). In response to the fiscally unsustainable trend, President Trump created the Department of Government Eﬃciency, or DOGE, originally headed by billionaire tycoons Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy. Ramaswamy has now stepped down to pursue a run for elected oﬃce as Ohio governor. The program aims to eliminate wasteful government spending by eliminating $2 trillion from the national debt according to Musk (The Hill). This whitepaper provides an overview of how Musk and his team plan to balance the federal budget through government restructuring and reform, focusing on the spillover eﬀect DOGE could have on SME owners with government contracts.
DOGE’s Authority
How will DOGE function? It is important to note that DOGE is not an oﬃcial government department, so it will not have the authority to enforce federal laws, terminate employees, and revoke regulations. Instead, DOGE will act as an advisory body to Congress and the Trump administration, identifying issues and recommending ways to reform the “slash excess regulations, cut wasteful expenditures, and restructure federal agencies” (Pillsbury Law).
Specifically, DOGE plans to work closely with the Oﬃce of Management and Budget and the
House Oversight and Accountability Committee currently under Republican control (Pillsbury Law).
DOGE’s Plans
DOGE will initiate three major kinds of reform: regulatory rescissions, administrative reductions, and cost savings. They are expected to do this by:
Cutting federal regulations that are considered invalid to “slash and burn bureaucracy” according to Ramaswamy (The Hill).
Shrinking the federal workforce, leading to “mass head-count reductions across the federal bureaucracy.” Federal workers will be “transitioned into the private sector,” being oﬀered “incentives for early retirement and voluntary severance payments to facilitate graceful exits.” Workers will be expected to come to the oﬃce five days a week, resulting in a “wave of voluntary terminations” (Wall Street Journal).
⅔ of the government’s $6.7 trillion budget is mandatory spending, of which Social Security and Medicare are part. The rest is discretionary spending, in which a large part is spent on defense. Musk and Ramaswamy will therefore target “$500 billion-plus in annual federal expenditures that are unauthorized by Congress or being used in ways that Congress never intended” (The Hill).
In an op-ed, Musk and Ramaswamy pinpointed The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, international organizations, Planned Parenthood, and “progressive groups” as places they would like to cut. Additionally, DOGE may dismantle big institutions like the IRS, USDA, FBI, DOE, and ATF.
“Voters did not vote for incremental change, they voted for sweeping change,” Ramaswamy says (Wall Street Journal).
Help Wanted
DOGE is looking for a small number of “super high-IQ small-government revolutionaries willing to work 80+ hours per week on unglamorous cost-cutting.” Those interested can submit their CV or resume to DOGE’s oﬃcial account on X. The following are people across engineering, HR, IT, and finance industries who are reportedly interested in getting involved:
William McGinley, a Republican lawyer who served on the committee of the Republican National Committee
Brad Smith, CEO of healthcare firm Russell Street Ventures who served as a health oﬃcial during Trump’s first term
Marc Andreessen, co-founder of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz (Business Insider).
Impact on Small to Mid-Sized Business Owners
DOGE will likely have significant implications for SMEs with contracts with the federal government. The Cato Institute, a libertarian public policy research organization based in Washington D.C., submitted recommendations to DOGE on areas to cut government. Among them was the recommendation to eliminate the Small Business Administration and contracts set aside for minorities. These changes could potentially threaten existing contracts between SME owners and the government while making the procurement process for new entrepreneurs more diﬃcult than it already is (Cato Institute; Angell). Additionally, Musk could run DOGE with volatility, making it advisable for SMEs to perhaps start exploring alternative contracting options in the private sector as well (Angell).
However, DOGE could present SMEs with fruitful opportunities as well. SMEs could thrive in a scenario where the government outsources the work of these eliminated agencies to the private sector. During Reagan’s administration, work usually done by the government, such as maintaining parks and developing weaponry, was handed over to the private sector, intending for SMEs to compete for contracts and ultimately lower costs for consumers (Angell).
Particularly, SMEs in AI should expect a critical role for them moving forward. Matt Zeiler, CEO and Founder of tech company Clarifai, notes, “If they reduce the federal workforce significantly, I think that’s going to increase the need for AI because there are still a lot of things that need to be done in the Government, that could be a big opportunity for us” (Angell).
Concerns With DOGE
Doubts have emerged about how Musk and his team exactly plan to make such a drastic change to the federal budget without cutting key government programs that many Americans rely on: Social Security and Medicare, which comprise 35% of the federal budget (Center for American Progress). “Two trillion dollars per year is such an absurdly large number, it’s impossible,” Senior Director of Federal Budget Policy at the left-leaning Center for American Progress Bobby Kogan said. “You could only propose $2 trillion a year if you are not interested in living within reality or if you are completely callous to the major harmful eﬀects that doing that would entail.”
Even if DOGE decides to limit these entitlement programs, they will likely receive fierce pushback from the courts. Currently, DOGE is facing legal challenges, namely, their dismantling of USAID (United States Agency for International Development). “USAID was established by an act of Congress, and it can only be disbanded by an act of Congress,” says Virginia Congressman Don Beyer (Connolly). Additionally, many Americans are questioning if Musk and his team are overstepping their power by accessing the Treasury’s payment systems. They are unelected oﬃcials now with access to millions of Americans’ bank accounts, tax data, Social Security numbers, home addresses, and critics say that Congress is being diﬀerential to the power grab of what is meant to be an advisory board to the American Government, not an executor (Center for American Progress).
Conclusion
Whether you argue the creation of DOGE marks a positive step in eradicating government ineﬃciencies or a blatant overreach of executive power, such a program marks an unprecedented step of an administration taking sweeping measures to fundamentally alter the nature of the administrative state. According to the Pew Research Center, 57% of Americans today say that reducing budget deficits should be a top priority, compared to 45% in 2022 (Pew Research Center). The need for the Government to balance its books is growing on the radar of Americans who fear the massive repercussions of a national debt default. While the eﬀectiveness and legality of DOGE in achieving fiscal responsibility remains to be seen, an attempt is finally being made to address what has been a long-forgotten national issue.

Accounting Firm Innovations as a Route to Growth
Jun 15 2021 |
Occams Marketing
126
0
▷
Businesses are continuously seeking to develop in the face of increased market competition. They may be able to achieve this growth through innovation and new technology.
Distinct occupations have different perspectives on innovation. When it comes to accounting businesses, it is thought that technology businesses that provide accounting and associated software are a key source of innovation for the accounting profession.
According to a Robert Half Management Resources poll, 41% of CFOs see technology as a key source of stress in their professions, claiming that accounting advances are moving at such a fast pace that it's impossible to stay up.
However, innovation cannot be described solely in terms of technology. At your company, innovation might be characterised as:
Your company is in the midst of a transition.
Your company's capacity to provide services to its clientele is always improving.
Your company's management methods and operations are always evolving.
How can businesses of any size innovate?
Any company, regardless of its size, may take an innovative strategy. Accounting professionals, for the most part, take a forward-thinking approach to their work and seek to deliver services that their clients will appreciate for years to come. Another challenge is figuring out how to accomplish this without resorting to extremely unsafe or time-consuming approaches.
Any company cannot completely transform itself overnight, nor can it devote all of its resources to improving its services and operations. Your company's approach to innovation will be largely determined by its size and resources, since innovation may be beneficial to every company, but there is no one-size-fits-all solution.
On a lesser scale, innovation
One of the most effective methods to seek innovation is to investigate the services you give and how you give them. There are several software solutions on the market, and you may pick the one that will make your company procedures more efficient.
You may start thinking about other services to give if you start doing what you're presently doing faster and more efficiently. For instance, the less time you spend on data entry activities, the more time you have to provide critical consulting services to your clients. You must consider innovations that can be implemented immediately, as opposed to those that will be implemented in the future.
Examining the software used by your competitors is one of the most effective ways to find the same. Participate in networking organizations with businesses of similar sizes, ask questions in online forums, and attend conferences.
Small teams might be focused on studying the viability of new possibilities for your practice if you operate a medium-sized organization. Hiring third-party advisors that specialize in Machine Learning (ML), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Blockchain technology might also assist you in reaching your goals. Testing new technologies internally with your own transactions and books, regardless of the size of your company, is a terrific way to learn.
The innovative mindset
Firms of all sizes and types may profit greatly by approaching innovation with an open mind and a readiness to adapt. With increased market rivalry, it's becoming increasingly difficult for businesses to grow and thrive by depending on obsolete service offerings and technology, since customers have more alternatives than ever before.
In various sectors of your career, innovation may take on a different meaning, yet every firm must innovate on a regular basis. Adequate steps in this area can set you apart from the competition and pave the way for long-term success.
Innovations in Accounting Technology
Accounting on the Cloud — In the twenty-first century, no other technology has had as big of an influence on accounting as the cloud. The capacity to handle everything from payroll and invoicing to taxes and benefits is provided by cloud apps, with automation being the most significant benefit of cloud-based accounting.
Real-Time Reporting — As AI technology improves, accounting has understood the value of real-time reporting and the impact it has on measuring a company's financial health. The time between when an accounting event occurs and when it is recorded has been greatly reduced.
Accounting on the Go - Accounting on the Go has reduced the need for accountants to be literally bound to their desks in order to do their jobs. Accounting businesses may now use a smartphone, laptop, or tablet to enter receipts, balance finances, generate pricey claims, and submit invoices.
The accounting sector has benefited immensely from
optical character recognition (OCR) technology
. “Advances in technology allow organizations to utilize scanners or even the cameras on mobile devices to record printed financial information like receipts and invoices and convert the text into digital files,” explains accountant Bill Gerber. “Improved accuracy has reduced the rate of mistake throughout this translation, and future upgrades are expected to boost the procedure's efficiency even more.”
Customer Relationship Management Software (CRM) - CRM solutions have become critical for accounting companies to stay competitive and satisfy client expectations. Companies can improve client interaction and automate boring operations by combining these systems with AI and automated solutions.
How can accounting businesses effectively innovate?
As previously said, accounting companies must innovate, and there are a few strategies that these organizations might use to do so successfully.
Determine your buyer group and persona – A buyer group is a broad category that includes things like manufacturers and physicians. Within that group, you must look for a persona, which is a detailed profile of your intended user. 'Members of a medical practice with 5 or fewer physicians' is an example of a persona. The trick is to be explicit.
Recognize the market – Learn everything there is to know about the market and why it wants what you have to offer. Market research must underpin your implementation. Talk to as many people as you can, including prospects, clients, and industry experts, to learn about their needs and problem issues. It's critical to think like a customer and approach the market from the outside in, rather than the inside out.
Use conceptual designs - To aid the customer in transforming an idea into a service or product, conceptual drawings should be employed. It may be described as a plain and plain illustration of the innovation principle. Growth, for example, may be shown as a three-legged stool, with growth as the seat and marketing, product management, and sales as the legs.
Analyze your market position by identifying competing products and market differentiators. One of the most dependable resources is interviewing your rivals. You will only be able to supply something that is completely enticing in the market if you conduct a thorough investigation of the competitors.
Give your invention a name – Give your innovation approach a catchy, distinctive, and memorable name. Select a name that elucidates the purpose and value of your services. Instead of opting for 'accounting outsourcing,' you may go for something more enticing like 'concierge accounting.'
Conclusion
As previously said, innovation does not function on a one-size-fits-all basis, and as a result, it should be tailored to your specific business plans and needs. Implement new technology and allow yourself to be innovative in the marketplace by allowing yourself to be creative with new ideas.

Introduction
At Occams Advisory, we understand the vital role research and development (R&D) plays in driving innovation and competitiveness within engineering firms. Leveraging R&D tax credits can significantly reduce your tax liability and fuel further advancements. Here are five essential steps to help your engineering firm qualify for these valuable credits.
1. Master the Four-Part Test
Qualifying for R&D tax credits under IRC §41 requires passing a four-part test:
Permitted Purpose:
Your activities must aim to create or improve a product, process, software, or technique.
Elimination of Uncertainty:
Efforts should focus on eliminating technical uncertainty regarding the development or improvement of a business component.
Process of Experimentation:
A systematic process of experimentation must be employed to resolve technical uncertainties.
Technological in Nature:
Research should be grounded in principles of physical or biological sciences, engineering, or computer science.
At Occams Advisory, we assist in assessing and documenting your activities to ensure they meet these criteria, maximizing your eligibility for R&D tax credits.
2. Document Your R&D Activities
Thorough documentation is crucial. Maintain records such as project plans, lab notes, and testing results to demonstrate a systematic approach to research. This documentation should clearly show how each project meets the four-part test criteria.
Occams Advisory provides comprehensive support in maintaining accurate and detailed records, ensuring they withstand IRS scrutiny.
3. Identify Qualified Research Expenses (QREs)
Accurately identifying and tracking Qualified Research Expenses (QREs) is essential. These typically include:
Wages:
Salaries and wages of employees directly involved in R&D activities.
Supplies:
Costs of materials used in the R&D process.
Contract Research:
Payments to third-party contractors for R&D services.
Computer Leasing:
Costs of leasing computers for R&D purposes.
Our experts at Occams Advisory guide you in identifying and categorizing your QREs, ensuring all eligible expenses are included.
4. Consult with R&D Tax Credit Experts
Navigating the complexities of R&D tax credits can be challenging. Consulting with experts ensures compliance with IRS guidelines and maximizes your potential credit. Professionals help identify qualifying activities, maintain proper documentation, and prepare accurate tax filings.
Occams Advisory specializes in R&D tax credits, offering tailored services to help engineering firms navigate the process efficiently and effectively. Our team of experts works with you to identify qualifying activities, document your efforts, and prepare your tax filings.
5. Stay Updated on IRS Guidelines
The IRS frequently updates guidelines and regulations regarding R&D tax credits. Staying informed about the latest changes ensures your firm’s practices are compliant, maximizing the benefits and avoiding potential pitfalls.
Occams Advisory keeps you informed about the latest IRS guidelines and regulatory changes, ensuring your firm remains compliant and fully benefits from available R&D tax credits.

How Cognitive Bias Affects Your Business
Cognitive bias can have a significant impact on the decisions that businesses make. In this blog post, we’ll explore what cognitive bias is, how it affects business decisions, and provide strategies for overcoming it.
Introduction
As humans, we are all susceptible to cognitive biases, which are errors in thinking that can affect our decision-making processes. In a business context, these biases can lead to flawed decision-making and negative outcomes.
What is Cognitive Bias?
Cognitive bias refers to the systematic errors in thinking that can occur when people process information. These biases can influence our perception, judgment, and decision-making processes, often in ways that we are not aware of. Some common types of cognitive biases include confirmation bias, availability bias, and overconfidence bias.
Examples of Cognitive Bias in Business
Cognitive biases can manifest in a variety of ways in a business context. For example, a business owner may have an overconfidence bias and believe that their product will be a market success without conducting adequate market research. Or, they may exhibit an availability bias and make decisions based on the information that is readily available to them, rather than seeking out additional information that could provide a more complete picture.
Real-Life Scenario #1
Let’s say a company is considering launching a new product line. The CEO, who has an overconfidence bias, decides to go forward with the launch without conducting market research. As a result, the product fails to gain traction in the market, resulting in financial losses for the company.
Real-Life Scenario #2
Now let’s say a business owner has an availability bias and relies on information from a single source when making decisions. They may make a decision that is not in the best interests of the company because they are not aware of all the relevant information. For example, they may choose to partner with a supplier who is not reliable because they are not aware of other more reliable suppliers in the market.
How Cognitive Bias Affects Business Decisions
Cognitive bias can have a significant impact on business decisions. It can lead to flawed decision-making, which can result in missed opportunities, financial losses, and damage to a company’s reputation. For example, a business owner may have a confirmation bias and only seek out information that supports their existing beliefs, rather than considering alternative perspectives.
Overcoming Cognitive Bias in Business
Overcoming cognitive bias requires a conscious effort to recognize and challenge our biases. Some strategies for overcoming cognitive bias in a business context include:
Seeking out diverse perspectives and information sources
Conducting market research and gathering data from a variety of sources
Encouraging dissent and constructive criticism within the organization
Using decision-making frameworks that incorporate objective data and analysis
Practicing mindfulness and self-reflection to recognize and challenge our own biases
By implementing these strategies, businesses can make more informed and objective decisions that are not influenced by cognitive biases.
Conclusion
Cognitive biases can have a significant impact on business decisions, but they can be overcome with conscious effort and awareness. By recognizing and challenging our biases, seeking out diverse perspectives and information, and using objective decision-making frameworks, businesses can make more informed and objective decisions that lead to positive outcomes.

Mastering the 4 Levels of Strategy: A Guide for Business Leaders
Oct 23 2024 |
Occams Marketing
412

Introduction
▷
1. Corporate Level Strategy: “Big Picture” Thinking
▷
2. Business Level Strategy: Outwit, Outplay, Outlast
▷
3. Functional Level Strategy: The Unsung Heroes
▷
4. Operational Level Strategy: Where the Magic Happens
▷
Why You Can’t Afford to Ignore Any Level of Strategy
▷
Conclusion: It’s All About Balance (And Maybe a Little Luck)
Introduction
In business, strategy is like the layers of a delicious cake — skip one, and the whole thing might crumble. Whether you’re leading a corporate giant or running a scrappy startup, having a well-baked strategy at
all levels
is the key to long-term success (and avoiding some serious heartburn).
Let’s break down the
four distinct levels of strategy
— Corporate, Business, Functional, and Operational — and explore how they can help turn your business into the next great success story. Oh, and to keep things light, I’ll sprinkle in a bit of humor and wisdom from some legendary business minds.
1. Corporate Level Strategy: “Big Picture” Thinking
Think of
Corporate Level Strategy
as the CEO’s crystal ball — it’s all about the
big picture
, the company’s North Star. Here, the top brass (Board of Directors, C-suite folks) define the
vision and mission
, laying out the long-term goals of the business.
It’s also where companies decide if they’re going to expand into new markets or make some bold moves, like buying up a rival (or a few thousand coffee shops, if you’re Starbucks).
Key ingredients:
Vision and Mission:
“Where are we going?” (Hint: hopefully somewhere profitable).
Resource Allocation:
“Who gets the money, and who gets…well, creative?”
Expansion:
“Are we the hunters or the hunted?”
As Jeff Bezos famously said, “We are stubborn on vision. We are flexible on details.” And who can argue with the man who started with selling books and now ships everything from toothbrushes to space rockets?
2. Business Level Strategy: Outwit, Outplay, Outlast
Once the corporate vision is set, the battle begins!
Business Level Strategy
is like that game of chess you’re playing against competitors in your industry. The goal? Achieve a
competitive advantage
—whether it’s through
differentiation
(fancy word for “we’re better”),
cost leadership
(fancy word for “we’re cheaper”), or
focus strategies
(fancy word for “we’re dominating this niche”).
Think of this as the organization’s Game of Thrones moment—hopefully without the backstabbing (unless you count boardroom drama).
Key moves:
Differentiation:
“We’re unique” (aka the Air Jordan approach).
Cost Leadership:
“We’re the most affordable” (aka the Walmart approach).
Focus Strategy:
“We own this market niche” (aka the Apple iPhone approach).
As Michael Porter, the granddaddy of strategy himself, once said: “The essence of strategy is choosing what not to do.” In other words, you can’t dominate everywhere, but you sure can pick your battlegrounds wisely.
3. Functional Level Strategy: The Unsung Heroes
If corporate strategy is the glamorous superstar and business strategy is the genius tactician, then
Functional Level Strategy
is like the team behind the scenes making sure everything runs smoothly. This level focuses on individual departments—marketing, finance, HR—where each group makes sure they’re pulling their weight.
It’s kind of like each team is saying, “Okay, the big boss has their plan, now let’s make sure we don’t screw it up.”
Functional focus:
Efficiency
Coordination:
“Marketing, are we cool with sales? Okay, good.”
Innovation:
How do we stay one step ahead without breaking the budget?”
To put it in Jack Welch’s words (former CEO of General Electric): “An organization’s ability to learn, and translate that learning into action rapidly, is the ultimate competitive advantage.” The faster your teams can adapt, the better you execute!
4. Operational Level Strategy: Where the Magic Happens
Finally, we get to
Operational Level Strategy
— where the actual work gets done. This is the day-to-day grind, the trenches, where grand visions get translated into action. It’s all about
execution
— making sure that every little cog in the machine is working perfectly so the bigger wheels keep turning.
Think of this as the foundation of a house. It might not be the most glamorous part of the project, but without it, the whole thing falls apart (and quickly).
Operational duties:
Short-term objectives:
“We’ve got a deadline, people!”
Resource allocation:
“We’ve got three employees, one printer, and a dream.”
Process management:
“Okay, seriously, who’s running the ship?”
In the words of Steve Jobs: “Great things in business are never done by one person; they’re done by a team of people.” It’s the teamwork at the operational level that turns strategic plans into real results.
Why You Can’t Afford to Ignore Any Level of Strategy
Each of these four levels plays a vital role in the success of a business. Focusing too much on one at the expense of another can spell disaster. You might have the best operational team in the world, but without a corporate vision, you’re like a ship sailing without a compass. On the flip side, even the most inspiring corporate vision won’t save you if your operational teams can’t execute it.
Remember, strategy isn’t just a buzzword you throw around at meetings—it’s a multi-layered approach that covers
every aspect
of your business.
Conclusion: It’s All About Balance (And Maybe a Little Luck)
Creating a successful strategy requires an understanding of
all four levels
. From the
high-level corporate vision
to the
nitty-gritty day-to-day execution
, your business needs a balance of big ideas and fine-tuned processes. Skip a level, and you’ll find yourself running in circles.
And let’s face it, even if you have the perfect strategy, sometimes you just need a little luck—whether that’s being at the right place at the right time or hiring a few genius-level employees to execute your grand vision. As Henry Ford once said: “The only real mistake is the one from which we learn nothing.”
So, before you roll out your next big plan, ask yourself: are you giving enough attention to each level of strategy? Make sure you’re covered from top to bottom, and you might just find your business soaring to new heights (or at least avoiding any Game of Thrones-style disasters)

Introduction
On August 9th, small business owners who filed legitimate claims for Employee Retention Tax Credit (ERC) received encouraging news: The IRS announced that it will accelerate processing of ERC claims after a lengthy pause due to a surge of high-risk, inappropriate filings. Specifically, the IRS has begun processing approximately one million ERC claims submitted prior to the moratorium period effective September 14, 2023. The agency has already started prioritizing the compensation of small business owners who filed legitimate ERC claims while simultaneously intensifying efforts to reject improper claims and investigate cases of fraud and abuse.
Background
ERC was first introduced in March 2020 as part of the CARES Act, a $2 trillion economic relief bill in response to COVID-19. ERC was specifically designed for small business owners affected by the pandemic with employees still on the payroll. Initially, Congress budgeted just $83 billion to hand out in ERC payments but ended up distributing $230 billion, nearly triple the estimate. Driven by “aggressive marketing by nefarious actors,” small business owners uninformed of ERC’s requirements were enticed to file claims by promoters who falsely promised entitlements. When the IRS noticed an influx of ERC claims dubious in validity, they placed a moratorium on further claims in September 2023 to review existing ones. A review of 1 million claims worth over $86 billion revealed that 10-20% were high-risk and improper, 60-70% had an “unacceptable” level of risk—not enough to process or deny the claim–and 10-20% were low risk and safe for payment processing.
Resumption of Claims
10-20% of claims that were categorized as low risk by the IRS have begun being processed starting late summer 2024. Meanwhile, the IRS is currently conducting further review of 60 to 70% of the claims categorized as an unacceptable level of risk and has started outright denying the rest with a high risk. Additionally, they have rolled back their claims-processing moratorium and announced on August 8th that “it will now start judiciously processing claims filed between Sept 14, 2023, and Jan 31,2024,” prioritizing “the highest and lowest risk claims at the top and bottom of the spectrum” where there is a “sound basis to pay or deny a refund claim.” As per the recent update, 28,000 disallowance letters have been issued to claimants of high risk, thousands of audits and hundreds of criminal cases are underway, and 50,000 claimants of low risk are on the fast track for payment processing in the coming weeks.
Launch of Second ERC VDP
More recently, on August 15, 2024, the IRS announced a second Employee Retention Credit Voluntary Disclosure Program (ERC-VDP) to allow businesses with potentially erroneous ERC claims the opportunity to repay 85%, or keep 15%, of the claimed credit without incurring penalties or interest, applications due by November 22, 2024. To be eligible, employers must have already received the ERC refund or credit for 2021, but those under criminal investigation, facing employment tax examinations, or already notified by the IRS about repayment obligations are excluded from participating. The program requires participants to disclose information about their tax preparers, potentially aiding the IRS in identifying abusive practices. Participation in the program does not shield businesses from future criminal investigations related to their ERC claims and prosecution.

Final Thoughts: The Responsibility of Innovation
Introduction
Web development has never been just about writing lines of code—it’s about redefining human interaction, challenging outdated paradigms, and building the foundation of the next digital frontier. Over the years, I’ve witnessed the internet evolve from a mere information repository to an interconnected, AI-infused organism that influences every aspect of our lives. Yet, in the midst of this rapid progress, one question lingers—are we truly innovating, or are we merely iterating?
Web Development: Breaking the Cycle of Incremental Change
For decades, the web has been shaped by incremental improvements—better UI frameworks, faster front-end libraries, more scalable back-end solutions. But at its core, are we genuinely challenging the fundamental principles of how the web operates? The original vision of the internet was decentralized, permissionless, and open. Yet, we’ve drifted into a reality dominated by walled gardens, data monopolies, and corporate-controlled ecosystems.
Front-end frameworks like React, Vue, and Svelte have made development smoother, but do they push the web forward or just make it slightly more efficient? We celebrate real-time interactions powered by WebAssembly and server-side rendering, yet we still rely on the same centralized models for hosting, authentication, and data ownership. What if we could rebuild the web with user autonomy at its core?
Beyond the Page: The Web as an Intelligent Entity
The web is no longer a collection of pages—it’s an ecosystem that learns, adapts, and predicts. Businesses are shifting from building static websites to creating dynamic, AI-driven experiences that blur the lines between digital and reality. The rise of generative AI is pushing this further—soon, websites won’t just respond to users; they will anticipate their needs, generating personalized content in real-time.
And yet, this raises a critical issue—if AI is shaping our web experiences, who controls the narrative? Algorithms dictate search results, content feeds, and even the very information we consume. As developers, we hold immense power to either reinforce these invisible biases or actively fight against them by promoting transparency and ethical AI practices.
Decentralization: Will It Free the Web or Fracture It?
The promise of Web3 and blockchain was to return power to the users, giving them control over their data and digital identities. However, the reality has been far more complex. While decentralized technologies present an alternative to centralized control, they also introduce new challenges—scalability, usability, and environmental impact. Are we trading one set of gatekeepers for another?
We must ask ourselves—how can we leverage decentralization to build a fairer internet without compromising usability? True innovation lies in bridging the gap between decentralized principles and real-world accessibility, making blockchain-powered applications as seamless as traditional web experiences.
AI in Development: A Double-Edged Sword
AI is no longer just a tool—it’s becoming a co-developer. From GitHub Copilot writing boilerplate code to AI-driven testing suites optimizing performance, automation is revolutionizing the development process. But at what cost? If AI can write, debug, and even design applications, will developers become obsolete, or will we evolve into architects of higher-order systems?
The challenge ahead is not just about harnessing AI—it’s about maintaining creativity in an era of automation. We must resist the temptation to let AI replace human ingenuity and instead use it to amplify our ability to think beyond conventions, push boundaries, and create something truly revolutionary.
The Next Era: A Web Without Limits
The web has never been static. It’s constantly reshaping itself, adapting to new demands, and forcing us to rethink our role as developers. The modern era of composable architectures, headless CMS platforms, and microservices-driven infrastructures offers unprecedented flexibility. But should we be content with flexibility alone, or should we be thinking even bigger?
What if the future of web development isn’t about building sites but about crafting entirely new digital realities? Virtual worlds, persistent online spaces, and AI-driven personal assistants that seamlessly integrate into our lives—these aren’t sci-fi fantasies anymore, they’re within reach. The challenge is no longer just about writing efficient code—it’s about reshaping the very concept of what the web is.
Final Thoughts: The Responsibility of Innovation
As developers, we are not just coders. We are architects of the digital age, and with that power comes responsibility. The decisions we make today—about AI, decentralization, ethics, and automation—will shape the internet for generations to come. Are we content with making the web marginally better, or will we dare to reinvent it?
If we are to step into this new era of web development, let’s do it with purpose. Let’s build not just for efficiency, but for impact. Let’s stop iterating and start revolutionizing.

A Step-by-Step Guide on How to Apply for an SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan
Navigating the application process for an SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan (EIDL) can provide essential financial relief for businesses facing economic hardship. This comprehensive guide walks you through the steps to secure an EIDL, ensuring your business can access the support it needs during challenging times.
Understanding the SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan Program
The SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan program provides low-interest loans to businesses affected by disasters, including economic downturns. Here’s what you need to know:
1. The loans are intended to cover working capital needs and help businesses overcome temporary loss of revenue.
2. The loans have long repayment terms and offer favorable interest rates to support business recovery and stability.
Eligibility Criteria for the SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan
To be eligible for an EIDL, your business must meet certain criteria:
1. Business Type: Small businesses, private nonprofits, and agricultural businesses may qualify for the EIDL.
2. Economic Impact: Your business must demonstrate a significant economic injury due to the disaster, such as a decline in revenue or inability to meet financial obligations.
Step-by-Step Application Process for the SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan
Follow these steps to successfully apply for an SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan:
1. Gather Documentation: Prepare financial documents, including tax returns, profit and loss statements, and bank statements. These documents will be required for the application process.
2. Visit the SBA Website: Go to the official SBA website and locate the EIDL application portal. Create an account or log in to begin the application.
3. Complete the Application: Provide accurate and thorough information about your business, financial situation, and economic impact. Be sure to answer all questions and submit the required documentation.
Real-Life Scenarios: Businesses Benefiting from the EIDL
1. ABC Manufacturing Company experienced a significant decline in sales due to the pandemic. By successfully securing an EIDL, they were able to cover operational costs, retain employees, and invest in new technologies to adapt to the changing market.
2. XYZ Restaurant faced financial challenges after a natural disaster forced them to close temporarily. The EIDL funds helped them reopen, repair damages, and retain their staff during the recovery period.

FAQs
What is the maximum loan amount available through the SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan?
The maximum loan amount for an EIDL is $2 million, subject to the actual economic injury suffered by the business.
How long does it take to receive a decision on the EIDL application?
The time to receive a decision can vary. While the SBA strives to process applications expeditiously, the volume of applications and other factors can impact the processing time. It’s advisable to regularly check the status of your application and be prepared for potential delays.
Can the EIDL be used for any business-related expenses?
The EIDL funds can be used for various business-related expenses, including working capital, fixed debts, payroll, accounts payable, and other operating expenses. However, there may be restrictions on certain uses, so it’s important to review the guidelines provided by the SBA.
Is collateral required for an SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan?
For loan amounts over $25,000, the SBA may require collateral. However, for loans up to $25,000, collateral may not be necessary. The SBA will determine the collateral requirements based on the circumstances of each application.
Conclusion
In conclusion, the SBA Economic Injury Disaster Loan provides vital financial assistance to businesses facing economic hardship. By understanding the program, meeting the eligibility criteria, and following the step-by-step application process, you can access the support needed to overcome challenges and ensure the continuity of your business. Investment Banking's FinTech Landscape: Synergy and Disruptive Innovation
Jul 16 2021 |
Occams Marketing
122
0
▷
A look at the latest happenings from across the world as the fintech environment continues to grow.
Fintech, a combination of finance and technology, symbolises the coming together of two worlds—as well as the growth of technology’s usage in financial services. Financial services and technology are inextricably linked, bringing with them both upheaval and synergy.
Fintech start-ups are attracting the attention of financial institutions, who are either investing in them or forming strategic relationships with them. According to McKinsey Panorama, over 80% of financial institutions have formed fintech collaborations. Meanwhile, worldwide venture capital (VC) fintech investment hit $30.8 billion in 2018, up from $1.8 billion in 2011.
While technology advancements appear to be defining a brighter future for certain firms in the post-COVID age, FinTech continues to grow and change the financial services sector environment. It’s all about remaining ahead of the curve in this battle to capture a larger share of the market amid dwindling consumer and company confidence, since improved technology adoption can be the secret sauce for attracting and maintaining consumers in the digital age.
Asset management, insurance, and lending firms are just a few of the important areas of the larger financial sector that have embraced the latest digital technology with vigour. While the COVID-19 epidemic originally drove the investment banking (IB) industry to its knees, recent developments in financial technology adoption appear to be helping them get back on their feet, owing to improved and simplified M&A advising, risk management, and financial asset management solutions.
We’ve all heard of Fintech Version 1.0 and Fintech Version 2.0, but the current philosophy around financial technology investment doesn’t stop there. A variety of elements can push and pull IB thematics while channelling the way technology can slither through and provide a spin to each and every product and service in the Investment Banking market. When it comes to risk profiling, lending, fraud analysis, and payments, tech-based end-to-end models look to take things to the next level. Let’s have a look at how this is accomplished in today’s world:
Penetration of AI Technology – The ‘New Normal’: Fintech adoption in IB models is paving the way for new growth opportunities in the financial services sector, assuring cost-effective due diligence, increasing the value of M&A possibilities, expediting legal checks, and advancing asset-reporting inconsistencies in acquisition agreements. Furthermore, AI-enabled actuarial software is giving a strong push toward providing top-notch, quicker, and more accurate risk advising services.
Furthermore, the seamless use and penetration of AI and ML in
algorithm trading
, stock market prediction, fraud detection and prevention, client acquisition, risk profiling, and network security merits praise. Technology-enabled valuation models play an essential role in carving out future stock forecasts and assisting smart investment judgments in the face of COVID-induced market volatility.
Value-Based Offerings are Powered by Big Data Analytics- Big data models are increasingly being used by IBs to evolve and provide sophisticated solutions, such as creating customer-centric asset portfolio valuation models, trading and investment assistance, risk advising, and M&A help. Meanwhile, big data is being used to improve internal operations like automated customer service, salary optimization, attrition modelling, fraud analysis, and credit/operational risks, among others.
Furthermore, algorithm trading appears to be gaining traction among big IB companies as a means of assuring efficient financial transaction execution and sound investment selections without the need for human interaction.
Adoption of innovative prediction models, advanced statistical approaches, and guaranteeing privacy and data integration are all essential in the IB area. To guarantee that big data enhances competitiveness and supports wider market penetration, a specific set of issues must be properly addressed.
The Next-Generation Frontier:
Robo Advisory
uses high-tech algorithms to give online investment management platforms with safe, quicker, and self-service capabilities. According to market analysts, in the post-COVID era, asset under management utilising Robo Advisory is anticipated to increase by a factor of ten.
Robo Advisory provides for automated changes and rebalancing of portfolio allocation based on algorithms and pre-defined investing criteria with little manual work. The investments are fully automated and have self-learning algorithms, and the cost of operating a robotic automation tool is far lower than performing the same tasks manually.
The Immediate Future of Cashless Transactions: In the face of the present health crisis, IBs are able to improve and supplement existing goods and services, as well as establish new business models, thanks to the greater comfort and safety connected with online cash-less transactions. While social isolation is becoming the new normal in the wake of the coronavirus, financial advisers appear to be reaping the benefits of technological advancements and more cashless transactions.
Without a question, financial behemoths who are first to adopt digital technology have an advantage over their competitors. However, the most significant problem for FinTech is data privacy, as digital transactions are particularly vulnerable to hackers. Nonetheless, in the near future, the digital transition may witness the rise of a digital-first paradigm, assuring a fundamental shift in the value proposition given to customers, with a growing emphasis on digital toolkits and electronic market access. Overall, it’s about how companies refine their transformation goals, incorporate lessons gained from the epidemic, and assess their overall strategic agenda.

Introduction
At Occams Advisory, we recognize that the manufacturing sector is a hotbed of innovation and a cornerstone of economic progress. In an industry where advancements are critical, the Research & Development (R&D) Tax Credit offers a substantial incentive for manufacturers to invest in new technologies and processes. However, many manufacturers are either unaware of the full potential of this credit or unsure how to navigate the complexities involved. In this detailed guide, we aim to shed light on how manufacturing activities qualify for the R&D credit and offer practical insights to maximize these benefits.
The Strategic Importance of the R&D Tax Credit
The R&D Tax Credit, under IRC §41, is designed to reward companies for innovation. For manufacturers, this means substantial tax savings for activities that push the boundaries of what’s possible. This credit not only fuels innovation but also provides the financial flexibility needed to stay competitive in a rapidly evolving market.
Diving Deep into Qualifying Activities
Manufacturers often overlook the wide array of activities that qualify for the R&D tax credit. Here’s a closer look at some specific activities that can qualify:
1.
Product Innovation and Enhancement:
Developing a new product or significantly enhancing an existing one, such as improving durability, efficiency, or sustainability.
2.
Advanced Manufacturing Processes:
Creating new production processes or refining existing ones to improve quality control, reduce costs, or increase output.
3.
Prototype Development:
The iterative process of designing, creating, and testing prototypes, including small-batch trial runs to evaluate feasibility.
4.
Integration of Cutting-Edge Technologies:
Implementing advanced technologies such as AI, IoT, or robotics to enhance manufacturing capabilities.
5.
Material Science Advancements:
Experimenting with innovative materials to achieve better performance, reduce environmental impact, or cut costs.
Key Criteria for Qualifying R&D Activities
To ensure your manufacturing activities qualify for the R&D tax credit, they must meet these critical criteria:
1.
Technological in Nature:
Activities must be grounded in engineering, physical or biological sciences, or computer science.
2.
Elimination of Uncertainty:
Projects must aim to resolve technical uncertainties, such as determining if a product or process can be improved or created.
3.
Systematic Process of Experimentation:
Must include a systematic approach to experimentation, including trials and prototypes, to resolve uncertainties.
4.
Qualified Purpose:
The intent should be to develop or improve the functionality, performance, reliability, or quality of a product, process, or software.
Maximizing the R&D Tax Credit: Practical Steps
To leverage the R&D tax credit fully, manufacturers should take the following strategic steps:
1.
Detailed Documentation:
Keep meticulous records of R&D activities. This includes project plans, timelines, technical drawings, testing protocols, and outcomes.
2.
Expense Tracking:
Accurately track all qualified research expenses (QREs), such as wages for R&D staff, cost of supplies used in research, and third-party contractor costs.
3.
Leverage Technology:
Use specialized software to track and document R&D activities and expenses in real-time, ensuring no qualifying activity goes undocumented.
4.
Engage Experts:
Collaborate with tax advisors who specialize in R&D tax credits. They can help identify qualifying activities, ensure compliance, and maximize your claim.
The Broader Benefits of the R&D Tax Credit
The benefits of the R&D tax credit extend beyond immediate tax savings:
1.
Increased Innovation Capacity:
Financial resources saved through the credit can be reinvested in further research and development.
2.
Enhanced Competitive Edge:
Continuous innovation helps manufacturers stay ahead of competitors and respond to market changes swiftly.
3.
Sustainable Growth:
By funding ongoing innovation, manufacturers can drive long-term growth and sustainability.
Conclusion
At Occams Advisory, our mission is to empower manufacturers to unlock the full potential of the R&D tax credit. By understanding the nuances of qualifying activities and maintaining rigorous documentation, manufacturers can realize substantial financial benefits and drive continuous innovation. The Fundamentals
Introduction
In today’s dynamic business landscape, the saying “together, we’re stronger” could not be more accurate. At Occams Advisory, we believe that our strength lies not just in our expertise but in the partnerships that we cultivate. Our collaborations with affiliates, clients, and strategic partners empower us to provide comprehensive, innovative solutions that help our clients flourish. As the VP of Affiliate Origination & Management at Occams Advisory, I have experienced firsthand how impactful strategic partnerships can be.
Why Partnerships Matter
In this ever-changing environment, no organization can thrive alone. Partnerships are essential for expanding reach, diversifying solutions, and enhancing service quality. By leveraging one another’s strengths, partners can fill gaps, drive necessary innovation, and unlock mutual growth. At Occams Advisory, we seek partnerships that align with our core values and complement our services, such as tax solutions, business or personal finances, and specialized consulting. Our affiliates extend our capabilities, enabling us to meet client needs holistically and deliver superior results. This also enhances affiliate relationships with their clients by providing additional resources that they would otherwise not have access to.
Key Benefits of Strong Partnerships
Enhanced Expertise and Resources
Partnering with specialists, such as CPAs, Wealth Managers, Insurance Experts, Lending Partners and other industry experts, allows us to identify areas where clients need immediate results by using our evidence-based approach and our delivery of customized solutions.For instance, our collaboration with tax filing professionals enables us to share our expertise in tax credits, amendments, and other complex financial strategies to their clients, elevating the value that they already provide. Leveraging our lending partners to assist in capital raising when the client needs funds or guiding them to restore and enhance her credit standing to its optimal state is another way that clients benefit from our strategic partnerships.
Shared Goals and Shared Success
Partnerships are most effective when both parties are working toward a common goal. At Occams Advisory, we emphasize shared success. By creating win-win scenarios, we motivate each partner to invest fully in the relationship, fostering collaboration that benefits all stakeholders. And most importantly, getting our mutual clients the solutions they need to be successful.
Innovative Solutions for Evolving Needs
The business environment is constantly changing, and so are our clients’ needs. Through our partnerships, we can quickly adapt, offering flexible solutions that respond to these emerging challenges. Adaptability has been crucial in providing timely, relevant support, such as expedited ERC (Employee Retention Credit) claims, during recent economic shifts.
Mutual Trust and Long-Term Growth
Sustainable growth is built on trust, transparency, and a shared commitment to excellence. Our partnerships are not just transactional—they are founded on trust and mutual respect, ensuring that each partnership is an opportunity for long-term success. As we look for legacy clients to work with us through each of their business cycles’ needs, we strive for partnerships that are legacy affiliates as well.
The Fundamentals
Building and Nurturing Strategic Partnerships
Creating impactful partnerships starts with finding alliances who share our values and vision. For Occams Advisory, that means identifying and aligning with organizations and affiliates who prioritize integrity, client service, and innovation. As we continue to grow, cultivating these relationships remains at the heart of our mission, allowing us to support our clients’ goals and foster a powerful, interconnected network of expertise. These are simple, back to basics that we continue to foster in our growth.
Looking Ahead
We have all heard the saying that “the future of business belongs to those who build bridges, not walls.” This is also true as we focus on partnerships that enable organizations to innovate faster, reach farther, and achieve more than they could independently. At Occams Advisory, we are proud to be part of a network of exceptional partners, all working to make a difference in the lives of our clients and in the broader business community.If you know a CPA, a financial consultant, or a specialist looking to bring expertise to a
wider audience, we invite you to encourage them to explore the power of a partnership with us. I believe that together, we can achieve remarkable results and redefine what is possible.

A deep dive into the workings of a merchant account.
Oct 05 2020 |
Occams Marketing
101
0
There's no sorting of credit cards themselves. This is where the accounts for merchants come in. The middleman that allows firms to take credit and debit cards in person and online is simply a dealer account. But why are they a required feature of accepting debit cards and credit cards, and in order to process electronic payments, does your company really need one?
Here is a brief overview of how a merchant account runs, what to look for in a merchant account, and how it can be acquired by small companies. Check out our
Credit Card Processing Buyer's Guide
for a more in-depth look at merchant accounts, which will also help you figure out why your company wants a merchant account and how to find the best one for your company.
What is an account for a merchant ?
A retailer account acts as an interface between the bank accounts of consumers and the bank account of your corporation when electronic transfers are handled, including credit card transactions. The merchant account works behind the scenes after a transaction to transfer funds from the customer's bank and deposit them directly into the checking account of the firm. During a refund, the mechanism works the same way.
You can start making credit card and debit card transactions with your customers until a payment processor has set up a merchant account for your company. Usually, you would still require some hardware to do so, which could be available for purchase from your credit card processing partner. In certain cases, to help you get started, the payment provider might also give you a free credit card reader.
How making payments functions ?
Information must be submitted to a payment gateway after a credit card request is accepted to see whether the cardholder has adequate funds. This is normally part of the point-of - sale (POS) computer for typical purchases that reads the data of the cardholder and checks with the credit card issuer to ensure that the transaction can go through. This is known as a form of merchant account, "swiped" or "card-present," which may include grocery, restaurant or lodging merchants.
Card-present purchases are known to be the least vulnerable to theft in general. This means that the prices related to these purchases are also the lowest provided by credit card processors. Card-present transactions, however, are not the only way to accept a client's credit card payments.
Via a payment portal, which ties to the credit card business, a "keyed-in" or "wallet-not-present" purchase is made electronically. A payment gateway is required by any company that wants to take credit cards over the phone or through an online portal. If your clients often put pickup orders ahead of time, you may also hire a payment gateway.
At the same time that your merchant account is created, the credit card processor you partner with will set up a payment gateway for you. However, payment gateways typically cost an extra monthly charge, and transactions with card-not-present generally have higher prices than transactions with card-present.
For e-commerce firms, payment service and merchant accounts
The payment processing business has expanded its scope to e-commerce companies as companies have gone increasingly digital. Since it is not possible to accept cash or checks electronically, e-commerce businesses are in far more dire need of payment processing systems than brick and mortar firms. The kinds of retailer accounts open to e-commerce firms, though, are distinct from those for brick-and - mortar shops. Any of the forms are these:
Direct
: A direct merchant account would be demanded directly from a merchant bank.
Local
: In one's home country, a local merchant account is an account.
Offshore
: An offshore merchant account is also known as an overseas merchant account and is based outside the merchant's country.
High-risk
: A high-risk retailer account is meant for high-percentage chargebacks and returns for online companies.
Third-party
: Linked to a direct credit card payment processor through an external protected payment portal, a third-party merchant account contributes to the processor's function, covering the expenses. For new e-commerce firms, this type is perfect.
Generally, at the time of payment or repayment, merchant purchases are not reported to the record. During the merchant's settlement process, these transactions are normally listed in a batch. The arbitration process may either be personally implemented or scheduled to occur at a given time of day, depending on the organisation and the individual payment gateway.
How to get an account with a merchant
A corporation has to apply and be accepted to get a merchant account. Credit card providers ensure that a cardholder is eligible to receive a promised good or service, i.e. the cardholder is eligible to their money back if the good or service is not provided. This further mitigates the burden the credit card issuer faces as one of the most important concepts of consumer security. Any time it performs a credit card transaction with your company, the payment processor has the opportunity to lose money. Thus, any entities who want a merchant account must apply, and there is a fee for this often.
When applying for these merchant accounts, it's important for companies to remain grounded in reality. When you apply, it should be possible for your prospective processor to have specific answers about the type of paperwork expected and how long the approval process will take. It 's important to be suspicious and have a second look at the business if the processor makes unreasonable blanket pledges or claims.
It 's important to have the financial records when applying for a merchant account in order to take advantage of the best available acceptance terms. Another useful asset that you can use to maximise your application is a good development background. To explain just what the company does and why it merits a merchant account, you should use an old-fashioned cover note.
What costs are paid in respect of merchant accounts?
The costs associated with a merchant account vary from provider to provider. Merchant accounts, in some situations, stick to a set per-transaction payment that comes without any extra costs. Others utilise a business scheme with interchange-plus, which is the payment cost of the credit card issuer plus the markup of the retailer account supplier. Finally, there is the tiered pricing model, which, based on the type of purchase, provides many different prices.
For each model, here's a closer look.
Flat-rate pricing
: The flat-rate pricing approach is most widely used by mobile credit card processing and is easy to understand. You are paid a set amount for any transaction processed. For instance, the processor could take 3 percent of the value of the transaction each time you swipe a debit or credit card. For companies with poor market rates or small-ticket items, this model is ideal.
Interchange-plus pricing
: For small companies, this is one of the most popular pricing models. The payment rate set by the credit card issuer is the interchange rate. This rate plus a margin as a benefit would be paid by a payment processor in interchange-plus pricing. An interchange-plus price system , for example, may appear as "2.75 percent + $0.10 per contract." In this example, the 10 cents are the discount of the processor, while the interchange cost is 2.75 percent.
Tiered pricing
: Tiered pricing splits transactions into three classifications: qualified, non-qualified and mid-qualified transactions. The most favourable rate is granted to eligible transactions, while the most costly are non-qualified transactions. The types of purchases differ in each group, but you would usually consider an eligible transaction to be a card-present transaction at the point of sale with a standard credit or debit card, whereas a smartphone keyed-in credit card number will normally be non-skilled. Mid-qualified transactions might require keyed-in card numbers using an Address Verification Service (AVS) in order to validate the additional identification address of the cardholder.
There are some extra costs beyond the templates of pricing:
Monthly fee
: The monthly fee is paid for the processing of the monthly statement and the availability of customer service, often referred to as a statement fee.
Gateway charge
: You could incur a monthly gateway charge if you use a payment gateway for card-not-present or online purchases.
Minimum monthly fee
: Certain payment providers have a certain amount or volume of transactions that you are expected to make per month. You will be entitled to a monthly subscription fee if you fail to reach this subscription.
PCI enforcement fee
: To reduce the threat of identity theft and fraud, the Payment Card Industry has
computer protection legislation
. As part of setting up and managing your vendor account, several payment providers will assist you to remain legal. For these facilities, certain processors charge PCI approval fees, although they are not often disclosed when you ask about rates.
PCI non-compliance fee
: For companies who do not conform with PCI requirements, certain processors incur penalties. Usually, you have to come into line a few months after signing up, and if you neglect to do so within the timeframe, you could start incurring PCI non-compliance fees.
Batch fee
: Anytime you upload a batch of new purchases, you could be paid a batch fee, which is normally once or twice a day. Usually, these rates are the same as your per-transaction fee, about 10 or 25 cents.
Address verification service fee
: If you are using AVS to validate the address of a cardholder, the processor can charge you this fee. AVS is a metric of fraud protection most widely used by e-commerce firms and enterprises who carry out keyed-in transactions regularly.
Retrieval cost
: When a buyer challenges a charge and their bank demands the documents relating to the sale in question, you may be paid a retrieval cost. This is not the same as a chargeback fee; a c could eventually prevent the retrieval.
Chargeback fee
: Chargeback payments result when consumers challenge a charge effectively and seek a refund. Chargebacks include cancelling a contract that is already made and returning the money to the client. To offset the payment costs involved with the reimbursement, you then have to pay the company a fee.
Cross-border costs
: In general, international transfers come with extra costs to offset the expense of electronically transferring currency.
Any payments are inevitable, but not all are common among the industry's credit card processors. To make sure you are not swept up with fake bills from a shady payment processor, do your due diligence.
You need a Marchant account if you want to accept credit cards.
The bottom line is, if you wish to accept debit and credit cards from your clients, you need to secure a merchant account. Many clients anticipate the opportunity to pay by card in today's world; many don't even bring cash on a regular basis. Refusing to set up a merchant account so that you can accept these types of payments could annoy your clients and potentially lose your company.

Small business owners should follow these five personal finance tips.
Mar 12 2021 |
Occams Marketing
87
0
One of the first principles of entrepreneurship is that the company and personal finances can never be mixed. However, some company owners go so far in the opposite direction, wasting too much time running their business, focusing on their business, and reinvesting money into their business that they ignore their personal finances.
You've probably seen founders like this before—they're smart businesspeople, but they don't manage their own capital well.
A surprising number of company owners, who are among the toughest workers on the planet, get a little careless in their personal finances: they overspend, don't save enough for retirement, and make unnecessarily risky investments (or make the mistake of parking their money in the bank and earning 0 percent interest).
It helps to be smart about your personal finances if you're a company owner. Here are few helpful tips and tactics for making smart financial decisions in your personal life. Indeed, you will discover that improving your personal finances will assist you in becoming more competitive in your company.
1. Put money together for an accident.
According to financial advisors, having three to six months' worth of living costs (after taxes) in an
emergency savings fund
is a safe rule of thumb. Are you up for it? If you own a corporation, you will want to create an even bigger emergency fund in case your company experiences a slowdown or has seasonal cash flow variations.
What if you lose your most important customer and had to reduce your salary? How long do you think your personal emergency fund will last? Hold the emergency fund in an
FDIC-insured cash bank account
rather than losing money in the bond exchange or locking it up in long-term CDs. You aren't looking for a high return on this money; you just need it to be available in an emergency.
Getting an emergency fund would give you more peace of mind, helping you to make more informed business decisions. You'll be able to focus more on running your business if you feel your family is safe in the event of a financial tragedy (car crash, big house repairs, natural catastrophe, medical bills).
2. Take care of your personal credit.
A small business's lifeblood is credit, so make sure your personal credit is in decent condition as well. And sure you pay your bills on time. And if budget is scarce and you can only afford to make a minimum credit card charge, it's preferable to skip a payment or pay late.
Often, keep an eye on your credit usage level, which is the amount of the total credit limits that you're using at any given time during the month. If you can keep this ratio below 30%, you'll have a higher credit score and have an easier time getting personal loans accepted.
Having better personal credit can also benefit your business, particularly if you're still creating credit in your company's name. Keeping track of your mortgage balances and due dates will also help you build a solid financial base.
3. Put money together for retirement.
Small business owners also reinvest a large portion of their earnings back into the company, but there are some excellent ways for them to prepare for retirement. Even if you don't have any workers, consider setting up a
SEP IRA
or other tax-advantaged retirement savings account for your company.
You can find that as a self-employed citizen, you can save more money for retirement than you will as an employee, based on your salary and other qualified factors.
Saving for retirement will help you diversify your investments into a broader range of investment opportunities, such as stocks, shares, ETFs, and money market mutual funds, rather than pouring all of your earnings back into your company. Your organization is now your most valuable commodity. Your income and insurance are already reliant on your company. You don't have to put every penny back into your company; you can also invest in a wider variety of opportunities.
4. Invest in accordance with your risk profile.
Make sure you're invested in a diversified portfolio of investments that are suitable for your time span and risk tolerance after you've begun preparing for retirement. If you are still relatively young and have many decades until retirement, you should focus your portfolio on stocks.
For example, an old asset allocation rule of thumb was that you should divide your age by 100 to calculate the proportion of your portfolio that should be invested in stocks. So, if you were 40 years old, you would deduct 40 from 100 to get your portfolio, which would result in you spending 60% of your money in stocks and 40% in bonds and currency.
However, based on your financial priorities, you will choose to devote a higher proportion of your portfolio to stocks so that you can benefit from their long-term growth prospects before you retire. Stocks are expensive, but they usually have the highest long-term return opportunities.
5. Seek specialist assistance
For more detailed guidance, contact a financial adviser; this column does not constitute legitimate financial advice, but it can help you work about some of your choices so you can make well-informed financial decisions.
You would be more likely to be able to concentrate on running your business with a relaxed and optimistic outlook if you can boost your personal finances—with a solid emergency fund, good personal credit, and a diversified portfolio of investment funds apart from the equity that you own in your business. And for company owners, who are among the busiest individuals on the planet, getting financial peace of mind can be absolutely invaluable.

Background
The 2025 tax season is proving to be a pivotal one, as political change is bringing ramifications for the IRS and the future of tax planning and filing for SME owners. While the Trump administration’s arrival was not expected to immediately trigger sweeping changes this tax season, events such as the resignation of IRS Commissioner Daniel Werfel on Inauguration Day and the unusual delays in IRS website updates signaled early shifts ahead (“What To Know About The Not-So-Usual 2025 Tax Season”). As the Department of Government Efficiency aggressively pursues mass layoffs within the IRS, debates ensue over the extension of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA), and BOI reporting under FinCEN has been terminated, SME owners may struggle to navigate this flurry of changes on top of regular tax planning. This whitepaper explores these developments further and their impact on tax filing and planning for SME owners, as well as the comprehensive tax solutions and bookkeeping services that Occams Advisory offers to help businesses stay compliant in these uncertain times while maximizing available benefits.
Extension or Expiration of TCJA?
One consequential fiscal policy initiative Donald Trump undertook during his first term was signing the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA) into law in 2017, a comprehensive tax reform package that delivered cuts to pass-through businesses, corporations, and individuals. However, the TCJA is set to expire at the end of 2025 unless Congress takes action. Key provisions of the TCJA that concern SMEs include: (“What New Tax Policies Mean for Small Businesses”).
Bonus depreciation that gradually reduced from 100% in 2017 to 40% this year will return to 100% if the TCJA is extended. Bonus depreciation incentivizes SMEs to invest in their businesses and significantly or entirely remove the cost of qualifying assets.
Qualified Business Income Deduction (QBI) of 20% for sole proprietorships or pass-through entities like S-corps.
Tax credit (Section 45S) for employers offering up to 12 weeks of paid family and sick leave to employees.
Capital gains tax cuts for SMEs investing in underserved communities federally designated as Opportunity Zones.
Individual tax cuts for SME owners reporting business income on personal taxes.
Even though the cuts to businesses are substantial, Democratic lawmakers and other critics argue that the top 1 percent of income earners in the United States disproportionately benefited from them. According to the Wall Street Journal, there is more than a $60,000 difference in cuts between the top 1 percent and bottom quintile of income earners. Additionally, fully renewing the TCJA is projected to cost the government $5.5 trillion in deficit spending and increase net interest outlays by $467 billion (“How Trump’s 2017 Tax Cuts Actually Played Out”).
Republican lawmakers’ plan is to use the reconciliation process to extend the TCJA which would bypass filibusters and require just a simple majority of 51 votes in the Senate (“Will Trump and Congress Extend TCJA Tax Cuts?”).
The expiration of certain TCJA provisions may bring significant tax changes, but SME owners do not have to navigate them alone. With Occams Advisory’s expertise in tax filing and planning, you can stay compliant with confidence— allowing you to focus on running core business operations.
Termination of BOI
President Trump and the U.S. Treasury have recently announced that the Beneficial Ownership Information (BOI) filing requirement to FinCEN under the Corporate Transparency Act has been terminated. This news will likely come to the relief of SME owners who found the requirement burdensome and stress-inducing because of complex regulations, having to give out sensitive information, and the threat of heavy fines. The termination comes after a federal district court in Texas blocked the enforcement of BOI and FinCEN granted a 30-day extension until March 21st. However, there is a slim possibility that the CTA will come back to life if the Supreme Court upholds the law in the fall and the Treasury Department is forced to enforce it. SME owners should be on the lookout for such updates (“BOI Filing Requirement is Officially Dead!”).
IRS Mass Layoffs
As part of cost-cutting measures by the newly created Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), Elon Musk’s agency has recently called for the axing of 6,000 IRS employees, with reports suggesting that number can go up to half its workforce. Here is how the tax returns of SME owners and individuals could be impacted: (“IRS Layoffs 2025: How Businesses Will Feel the Impact”).
Processing Delays:
Former IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig stated, “There should not be a significant impact on current filing season operations.” However, with the broad nature of the layoffs, taxpayers could face processing delays on their returns.
Reduced Customer Support:
Taxpayers could have to wait longer for assistance with fewer staff available to pick up calls.
Audit Delays:
Auditing officers at the IRS have declined over the past decade. Additional layoffs would further inhibit their ability to detect tax fraud.
Challenging verification process:
Businesses seeking verification letters such as the S-corp election could face delays in obtaining them.
Upcoming Deadlines
A flurry of tax changes makes it all the more important for SME owners to be secure on the upcoming regular deadlines first:
March 17th, 2025:
Taxes due for businesses set up as partnerships such as S-corps and multi-member LLCs.
April 15th, 2025:
Taxes due for C-corps.
September 15th, 2025:
Final deadline for S-corps and partnerships that applied for an extension.
October 15th, 2025:
Final deadline for C-corps that applied for an extension.
